SUBJECT TO COMPLETION, DATED OCTOBER 23, 1998<br /><br />
PROSPECTUS<br /><br />
XCL LTD.<br /><br />
1,219,199 SHARES OF 9.50%<br /><br />
AMENDED SERIES A, CUMULATIVE CONVERTIBLE PREFERRED STOCK<br /><br />
33,592,721 SHARES OF COMMON STOCK<br /><br />
This Prospectus offers for resale in transactions<br /><br />
registered under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the<br /><br />
"Securities Act"), 1,219,199 issued and outstanding shares<br /><br />
of 9.50% Amended Series A, Cumulative Convertible Preferred<br /><br />
Stock (the "Amended Series A Preferred Stock") of XCL Ltd.<br /><br />
(the "Company"). These shares of Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock were originally issued in transactions intended to<br /><br />
qualify for an exemption from registration under<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Securities Act.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This Prospectus also offers for resale in transactions<br /><br />
registered under the Securities Act, 33,592,721 shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock of the Company which have been or will be<br /><br />
issued in transactions intended to qualify for an exemption<br /><br />
from registration under the Securities Act.<br /><br />
These shares<br /><br />
include shares originally issued in transactions intended to<br /><br />
qualify for an exemption from registration under<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Securities<br /><br />
Act,<br /><br />
shares the Company is<br /><br />
contractually<br /><br />
obligated to issue and shares that may be issued if holders<br /><br />
of convertible preferred stock convert that stock or if<br /><br />
holders of various warrants exercise those warrants.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In this Prospectus, the shares of Common Stock being<br /><br />
registered that will be issued when various warrants are<br /><br />
exercised are referred to as the "Warrant Shares," and the<br /><br />
warrants are referred to as the "Warrants." The shares of<br /><br />
Common<br /><br />
Stock that will be issued when the Company's<br /><br />
convertible preferred stock is converted into Common Stock<br /><br />
are referred to as the "Conversion Stock." The shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock that the Company is contractually required to<br /><br />
issue are referred to as the "Contract Stock." The Amended<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock, Warrant Shares, Conversion Stock<br /><br />
and Contract Stock are collectively referred to as the<br /><br />
"Securities."<br /><br />
<br /><br />
This Prospectus is intended for use by the holders (the<br /><br />
"Selling Security Holders") of the Securities in resale<br /><br />
transactions registered under the Securities Act.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company will not receive any proceeds from the sale of the<br /><br />
Securities (other than proceeds upon exercise of<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Warrants).<br /><br />
See "Selling Security Holders" and "Use of<br /><br />
Proceeds."<br /><br />
The Company will pay the costs of registering<br /><br />
sales of the Securities covered by this Prospectus under the<br /><br />
Securities Act and related costs (although the Selling<br /><br />
Security Holders will pay all applicable stock transfer<br /><br />
taxes, brokerage commissions or other transaction charges or<br /><br />
expenses).<br /><br />
The Company estimates that its expenses in<br /><br />
making this offering will be approximately $152,000.<br /><br />
The Common Stock is quoted on the American Stock<br /><br />
Exchange (the "AMEX") under the symbol "XCL" and on the<br /><br />
London Stock Exchange. On September 30, 1998, the last<br /><br />
reported closing price of the Common Stock on the AMEX was<br /><br />
$3.00.<br /><br />
See "Risk Factors" beginning on page [] of this<br /><br />
Prospectus for a discussion of certain factors that should<br /><br />
be considered in evaluating an investment in the Securities.<br /><br />
THESE SECURITIES HAVE NOT BEEN APPROVED OR DISAPPROVED<br /><br />
BY THE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION OR ANY STATE<br /><br />
SECURITIES COMMISSION NOR HAS THE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE<br /><br />
COMMISSION PASSED UPON THE ACCURACY OR ADEQUACY OF THIS<br /><br />
PROSPECTUS.<br /><br />
ANY REPRESENTATION TO THE CONTRARY IS<br /><br />
A<br /><br />
CRIMINAL OFFENSE.<br /><br />

Information contained herein is subject to completion or<br /><br />
amendment. A registration statement relating to these<br /><br />
securities has been filed with the Securities and Exchange<br /><br />
Commission. These securities may not be sold nor may offers<br /><br />
to buy be accepted prior to the time the registration<br /><br />
statement becomes effective. This prospectus shall not<br /><br />
constitute an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer<br /><br />
to buy nor shall there be any sale of these securities in<br /><br />
any state in which such offer, solicitation or sale would be<br /><br />
unlawful prior to registration or qualification under the<br /><br />
securities laws of any such state.<br /><br />

AVAILABLE INFORMATION<br /><br />
The Company is subject to the informational requirements of the<br /><br />
Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act"), and<br /><br />
files reports, proxy and information statements and other information<br /><br />
with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the "Commission").<br /><br />
Such reports, proxy and information statements and other information can<br /><br />

DISCLOSURE REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS<br /><br />
This Prospectus includes (or incorporates by reference) "forwardlooking statements." All statements made in this Prospectus, other than<br /><br />
historical facts (whether set forth or incorporated by reference), are<br /><br />
forward-looking<br /><br />
statements.<br /><br />
Although the Company<br /><br />
believes<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
statements are reasonable, it can give no assurance that they will prove<br /><br />
to be correct.<br /><br />
It is difficult to estimate quantities of proved oil and natural<br /><br />
gas reserves and to project future rates of production, the timing of<br /><br />
development costs and future net revenues. Those estimates depend upon<br /><br />
many factors the Company cannot control. Reserve engineering involves<br /><br />
estimating underground accumulations of oil and natural gas that cannot<br /><br />
be measured in an exact way. The accuracy of any reserve estimate<br /><br />
depends on the quality of available data, the interpretation of that<br /><br />
data and the judgment of the reserve engineers. As a result, estimates<br /><br />
made by different engineers are often different. Because reserve<br /><br />
estimates are only estimates, the actual amounts of oil and natural gas<br /><br />
recovered are usually different from the estimates. Results of drilling,<br /><br />
testing and production subsequent to the date of an estimate may require<br /><br />
reserve estimates to be revised and may change the schedule of<br /><br />
production and development drilling.<br /><br />
Additional important factors that could cause actual results to<br /><br />
differ materially from the Company's expectations are disclosed under<br /><br />
"Risk Factors" and elsewhere in this Prospectus.<br /><br />

The Company<br /><br />
----------XCL<br /><br />
is<br /><br />
principally engaged in the exploration<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
development of oil and gas in the Zhao Dong Block (the "Zhao Dong<br /><br />
Block") located in the shallow waters of the Bohai Bay in the<br /><br />
People's<br /><br />
Republic of China ("China").<br /><br />
The Company<br /><br />
obtained<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
second production sharing contract covering the Zhang Dong Block<br /><br />
(the "Zhang Dong Block"),<br /><br />
also in the shallow waters of Bohai<br /><br />
Bay,<br /><br />
effective October 1, 1998.<br /><br />
To date the Company has<br /><br />
not<br /><br />
generated any profits from these operations.<br /><br />
The Company's only<br /><br />
historic revenues were derived from its financing activities and<br /><br />
properties<br /><br />
currently held for sale or investment or<br /><br />
previously<br /><br />
sold.<br /><br />
See<br /><br />
"Management's Discussion and Analysis<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Financial<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Condition<br /><br />
and Results of Operations."<br /><br />
The Company is<br /><br />
development stage with respect to its operations in China<br /><br />
not<br /><br />
generated<br /><br />
any<br /><br />
revenues from<br /><br />
operations<br /><br />
related<br /><br />
properties and interests in China.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
has<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Zhao Dong Block is located in one of China's major oilproducing basins. Geologic information suggests that a portion of<br /><br />
the Zhao Dong Block is an extension of the onshore Dagang oil<br /><br />
field<br /><br />
complex<br /><br />
to the west.<br /><br />
Approximately 700 million<br /><br />
barrels<br /><br />
have already been produced from that field and it is still under<br /><br />
production.<br /><br />
The Zhao Dong Block is also about 40 miles northwest<br /><br />
of the Shengli oil field, the largest in the basin, from which<br /><br />
about 4 billion barrels have already been produced.<br /><br />
The Shengli<br /><br />
oil<br /><br />
field<br /><br />
is<br /><br />
still<br /><br />
under production as<br /><br />
well.<br /><br />
Of<br /><br />
course,<br /><br />
production in those fields does not ensure that there will<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
production from the Zhao Dong Block.<br /><br />
In early 1993, XCL became the first foreign company to enter<br /><br />
into<br /><br />
an<br /><br />
onshore Production Sharing Agreement (the<br /><br />
"Contract"),<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
China<br /><br />
National<br /><br />
Oil and Gas Exploration<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Development<br /><br />
Corporation ("CNODC") (which is a Chinese state enterprise).<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Contract provides for exploration, development, and production of<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Zhao<br /><br />
Dong Block. CNODC is the arm of the China National<br /><br />
Petroleum Company ("CNPC"), also a state enterprise, in charge of<br /><br />
all onshore exploration and production activity in China out to<br /><br />
five meters in water depth. CNODC operates in this area through<br /><br />
its subsidiary, Dagang Oilfield (Group) Co. Ltd. ("Dagang").<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Contract provides that the "Foreign Contractor"<br /><br />
(the<br /><br />
Company<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Apache Corporation ("Apache") as a group,<br /><br />
working<br /><br />
through<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
participation agreement) is to pay<br /><br />
all<br /><br />
exploration<br /><br />
costs. The Contract also states that, when a commercial discovery<br /><br />
is made, CNODC may choose to participate in development, with up<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
51%<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
all development and operating costs and<br /><br />
allocable<br /><br />
remainder<br /><br />
oil<br /><br />
and gas production allocated to CNODC<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
remaining<br /><br />
interest<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Foreign<br /><br />
Contractor.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Foreign<br /><br />
Contractor's<br /><br />
share is divided equally between XCL<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Apache.<br /><br />
See "Business -- The Contract" and "Business -- Apache Farmout."<br /><br />
XCL and Apache have successfully tested six of ten wells<br /><br />
drilled to date on the Zhao Dong Block, with total test rates<br /><br />
exceeding 39,500 barrels of oil per day.<br /><br />
Of the four wells not<br /><br />
tested, one (the D-3) was proven productive by wire line samples<br /><br />
and tests in several sands but was not drill-stem tested, while a<br /><br />
second (the F-1) was drilled but not fully evaluated.<br /><br />
Drilling<br /><br />
activities on the F-1 have been abandoned. Development of the CD Field for production is now proceeding.<br /><br />
Based on the report of H.J. Gruy and Associates ("Gruy"),<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
independent<br /><br />
petroleum<br /><br />
engineers,<br /><br />
net<br /><br />
proved<br /><br />
reserves<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
the C-D Field are estimated to be 11.76<br /><br />
million<br /><br />
barrels as of January 1, 1998, and the estimated present value of<br /><br />
future pre-tax net cash flows is $64.8 million.<br /><br />
The standardized<br /><br />
measure<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
discounted<br /><br />
future net<br /><br />
cash<br /><br />
flows<br /><br />
determined<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
accordance with the rules prescribed by FASB No. 69<br /><br />
is<br /><br />
$53.8<br /><br />
million.<br /><br />
Future reserve values are based on year end prices and<br /><br />
operating costs, production and future development costs based on<br /><br />
current costs with no escalation. See "Business -- Oil and Gas<br /><br />
Reserves" and "Supplemental Oil and Gas Information" in the Notes<br /><br />
to the Consolidated Financial Statements.<br /><br />
The Company's Development Program<br /><br />
--------------------------------The C-D Field was discovered by the drilling of the C-1 and<br /><br />
D-1 Wells. The Field has been appraised by the C-2, C-2-2, C-2-2<br /><br />
sidetrack,<br /><br />
C-3,<br /><br />
D-2, and D-3 Wells.<br /><br />
On<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
basis<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
calculated<br /><br />
reserves, Apache and XCL have<br /><br />
prepared<br /><br />
an<br /><br />
Overall<br /><br />
Development<br /><br />
Plan<br /><br />
("ODP")<br /><br />
for the Field.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
ODP<br /><br />
presently<br /><br />
projects the drilling of 45 wells, of which 32 are producers, 8<br /><br />
are water injection wells for the purpose of reservoir pressure<br /><br />
maintenance<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
achieve higher levels of recovery<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
ultimate<br /><br />
reserves<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
5 are water disposal wells.<br /><br />
The ODP<br /><br />
has<br /><br />
been<br /><br />
approved<br /><br />
by<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Joint<br /><br />
Management<br /><br />
Committee<br /><br />
("JMC"),<br /><br />
which<br /><br />
oversees operations on the Zhao Dong Block, and has been approved<br /><br />
<br /><br />
by CNPC subject to certain modifications that XCL and Apache are<br /><br />
studying.<br /><br />
CNODC has given notice that it will participate as to<br /><br />
its full 51% share in the C-D Field.<br /><br />
XCL,<br /><br />
Apache<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
CNODC<br /><br />
are currently<br /><br />
collaborating<br /><br />
on<br /><br />
engineering<br /><br />
studies to refine the ODP, both to reduce<br /><br />
capital<br /><br />
commitments<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
development and to accelerate<br /><br />
production,<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
have, as a result, suggested some revisions to the original ODP.<br /><br />
It<br /><br />
is expected that these studies will assist the parties<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
determining the<br /><br />
most efficient method for development, including<br /><br />
the practicability of beginning production before all development<br /><br />
operations have been completed. The Company has been informed by<br /><br />
CNODC<br /><br />
that they desire that production on the Zhao Dong Block<br /><br />
begin as soon as practicable and the parties are assessing how<br /><br />
that<br /><br />
would<br /><br />
be commercially feasible.<br /><br />
Initial results<br /><br />
indicate<br /><br />
that<br /><br />
1999<br /><br />
production is possible and the Company, Apache<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
CNODC have decided to attempt to commence initial production in<br /><br />
1999.<br /><br />
XCL's current estimate (which is subject to revision as the<br /><br />
project moves forward) of the costs to develop the reserves in<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
C-D Field that are identified in the ODP by Apache<br /><br />
(the<br /><br />
"Operator") (which XCL understands are higher than the<br /><br />
reserves<br /><br />
identified<br /><br />
by<br /><br />
XCL's petroleum engineers) is approximately<br /><br />
$185<br /><br />
million<br /><br />
(of<br /><br />
which<br /><br />
XCL's share would<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
approximately<br /><br />
$45.3<br /><br />
million).<br /><br />
This is less than amounts projected by the Operator in<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
original<br /><br />
ODP<br /><br />
for several reasons.<br /><br />
Cost<br /><br />
reductions<br /><br />
are<br /><br />
expected in part based on design changes that would eliminate one<br /><br />
drilling<br /><br />
platform<br /><br />
and one production platform<br /><br />
from<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
ODP.<br /><br />
While formal Chinese approval for these changes has not yet been<br /><br />
obtained, all parties believe that such approval can be secured.<br /><br />
Further, cost reductions are expected as a result of preliminary<br /><br />
bids that suggest that cost estimates in the ODP have been too<br /><br />
high.<br /><br />
In<br /><br />
addition,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
initial<br /><br />
ODP<br /><br />
included<br /><br />
estimates<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
contingencies<br /><br />
larger than the industry standard.<br /><br />
Finally,<br /><br />
cost<br /><br />
reductions from the Operator's projections are also based on the<br /><br />
assumption that if the project moves forward with dispatch, the<br /><br />
current<br /><br />
weakness of certain Asian currencies<br /><br />
could<br /><br />
result<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
substantial reductions in the costs of steel and fabrication for<br /><br />
the project.<br /><br />
The revised ODP design anticipates that once production and<br /><br />
loading facilities have been installed in the field, wells will<br /><br />
be placed on production as they are drilled.<br /><br />
In this case, cash<br /><br />
flow<br /><br />
from this production would be available to fund part<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
XCL's capital requirements for the development of the C-D Field.<br /><br />
The Company's financial plans include the use of such cash flow<br /><br />
as part of the Company's source of funds.<br /><br />
Production tests of the C-4 Well, announced by XCL on<br /><br />
October 7, 1997, indicate a combined daily rate from 8 zones of<br /><br />
15,359 barrels per day, and 6,107 Mcf of gas, plus a ninth zone<br /><br />
daily rate of 4,600 Mcf and 14 barrels of condensate. This well<br /><br />
suggests a new field discovery on the Zhao Dong Block.<br /><br />
In August<br /><br />
1998,<br /><br />
CNODC,<br /><br />
XCL,<br /><br />
and Apache commenced drilling<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
well<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
appraise the C-4 Well.<br /><br />
If this drilling proves successful, early<br /><br />
production from the two initial wells in the C-4 Well area may<br /><br />
begin by mid-1999; initial feasibility studies indicate that this<br /><br />
is<br /><br />
possible.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
capital<br /><br />
costs attributable<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
early<br /><br />
production are not included in the 1998 work program and budget.<br /><br />
Successful appraisal of the C-4 Well could also cause XCL<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Apache to move promptly toward development of this area.<br /><br />

High Degree of Leverage<br /><br />
- ----------------------The<br /><br />
Company<br /><br />
is<br /><br />
currently<br /><br />
highly<br /><br />
leveraged.<br /><br />
Future<br /><br />
operations<br /><br />
will<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
significantly<br /><br />
affected<br /><br />
by<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
level<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
indebtedness.<br /><br />
Much<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
cash<br /><br />
flow<br /><br />
from<br /><br />
operations<br /><br />
will<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
dedicated<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
interest<br /><br />
payments.<br /><br />
Large<br /><br />
amounts<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
money<br /><br />
will<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
required<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
continue<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
operations in<br /><br />
China.<br /><br />
Covenants<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Indenture<br /><br />
(the<br /><br />
"Indenture")<br /><br />
governing<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
13.50%<br /><br />
Senior<br /><br />
Secured<br /><br />
Notes<br /><br />
due<br /><br />
May<br /><br />
1, 2004 (the "Notes")<br /><br />
require<br /><br />
the<br /><br />

to<br /><br />
meet<br /><br />
certain<br /><br />
financial<br /><br />
tests and<br /><br />
limit<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
ability<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
dispose<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
assets<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
borrow<br /><br />
additional<br /><br />

These<br /><br />

may<br /><br />

business<br /><br />

and<br /><br />

Block, which<br /><br />

to fixed charges<br /><br />

Restrictions Imposed by Terms of the Company's Indebtedness<br /><br />
- ----------------------------------------------------------The<br /><br />
Indenture<br /><br />
restricts,<br /><br />
among<br /><br />
other<br /><br />
things,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
ability<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
incur<br /><br />

pay<br /><br />

or<br /><br />
make<br /><br />

It<br /><br />
also<br /><br />

to<br /><br />

with<br /><br />
affiliates,<br /><br />
enter<br /><br />
into<br /><br />
mergers<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
consolidations,<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
dispose<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
substantially<br /><br />
all<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
assets.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />

to comply<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
covenants<br /><br />
may<br /><br />
be<br /><br />

by<br /><br />

breach<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
any<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
these<br /><br />

First Onshore Production Sharing Agreement Between CNODC and a<br /><br />
Foreign Company<br /><br />
- --------------------------------------------------------------In early 1993 the Company became the first foreign company<br /><br />
to enter into an onshore production agreement with CNODC<br /><br />
(although since that time a number of other foreign companies<br /><br />
have also done so). Because XCL was the first foreign company<br /><br />
to enter into such a contract, there was some uncertainty as to<br /><br />
how it would be administered.<br /><br />
Currency/Exchange Rate Fluctuations<br /><br />
- ----------------------------------For the foreseeable future the Company's only material<br /><br />
revenues will be from its oil and gas activities.<br /><br />
These<br /><br />
revenues will be in U.S. dollars. To the extent that at some<br /><br />
future time revenues are paid to the Company in Chinese Renminbi<br /><br />
rather than in dollars, the Company's earnings, operations and<br /><br />
cash flows would then be subject to currency and exchange rate<br /><br />
fluctuations and to restrictions imposed by<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Chinese<br /><br />
government on the transfer and exchange of funds.<br /><br />
If that<br /><br />
occurs the Company will evaluate the currency requirements of<br /><br />
each venture and, if possible, enter into forward exchange<br /><br />
contracts to hedge foreign currency transactions. There can be<br /><br />
no assurance, however, that such forward exchange contracts will<br /><br />
be available at the time of any such occurrence.<br /><br />
The Company<br /><br />
does not intend to engage in currency speculation.<br /><br />
Renminbi<br /><br />
earnings, if any, must be converted to pay dividends or to make<br /><br />
other payments to the Company in U.S. dollars or other freely<br /><br />
convertible currencies. As of December 1, 1996, as to foreign<br /><br />
investment enterprises, the Renminbi became fully convertible<br /><br />
for current account items, including profit distributions,<br /><br />
interest payments and receipts and expenditures from trade.<br /><br />
Conversion into U.S. dollars is based on the rate set by The<br /><br />
People's Bank of China (which is based on the previous day's PRC<br /><br />
interbank foreign exchange market rate and with reference to<br /><br />
currency exchange rates on the world financial markets). Certain<br /><br />
ministerial approvals are needed to acquire foreign exchange for<br /><br />
a current account transaction. Strict foreign exchange controls<br /><br />
continue for capital account transactions (including repayment<br /><br />
of loan principal and return of direct capital investments and<br /><br />
transactions in investments in negotiable securities).<br /><br />
In the<br /><br />
past, there have been shortages of U.S. dollars or other foreign<br /><br />
currency available for conversion of Renminbi, and it is<br /><br />
possible such shortages could recur, or that restrictions on<br /><br />
conversion could be reimposed in the future at times when the<br /><br />
Company is seeking to convert Renminbi. Prior to 1994, the<br /><br />
Renminbi experienced a significant net devaluation against most<br /><br />
major<br /><br />
currencies, and during certain periods, significant<br /><br />
volatility in the market-based exchange rate.<br /><br />
Since<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
beginning of 1994, the Renminbi to U.S. dollar exchange rate has<br /><br />
largely stabilized. However, there can be no assurance that the<br /><br />
Chinese government will not devalue the Renminbi, that such<br /><br />
exchange rate will otherwise remain stable (particularly in<br /><br />
<br /><br />
light of the recent currency crisis experienced by a number of<br /><br />
other Asian countries), that the Company will continue to be<br /><br />
able to remit foreign currency abroad or that the Company will<br /><br />
be able to convert sufficient amounts of Renminbi in China's<br /><br />
foreign exchange markets to meet its future needs. Additionally,<br /><br />
there<br /><br />
can<br /><br />
be no assurance that approvals for<br /><br />
exchange<br /><br />
transactions will be available in the future or, if available,<br /><br />
will be granted to the Company. The Chinese government has<br /><br />
issued certain international loan procedures (the "Procedures")<br /><br />
that apply to foreign invested enterprises, including Chineseforeign equity and cooperative joint ventures. The Procedures<br /><br />
may require the approval of China's State Administration of<br /><br />
Exchange ("SAFE") for certain international loans to foreign<br /><br />
invested enterprises extended in connection with project finance<br /><br />
transactions, as well as the terms of such transactions.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company plans to obtain funds for certain development projects<br /><br />
through project finance transactions. There can be no assurance<br /><br />
that SAFE approval for such transactions, if necessary, can be<br /><br />
obtained at all or on terms advantageous to the Company.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
failure of the Company to obtain SAFE approval for such<br /><br />
transactions, if required, could adversely affect the Company's<br /><br />
ability to fund its operations.<br /><br />
History of Losses<br /><br />
- ----------------The Company has experienced recurring losses. For the years<br /><br />
ended December 31, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996 and 1997, the Company<br /><br />
recorded net losses of approximately $15.2 million,<br /><br />
$36.6<br /><br />
million,<br /><br />
$87.8<br /><br />
million, $12.1 million and<br /><br />
$14<br /><br />
million,<br /><br />
respectively. See "Selected Consolidated Financial Data." There<br /><br />
can be no assurance that the Company will be profitable in the<br /><br />
future.<br /><br />
See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial<br /><br />
Condition<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Results of Operations" and<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
Consolidated Financial Statements and the notes thereto included<br /><br />
elsewhere in this report.<br /><br />

- ----------------------------In<br /><br />
reporting on the Company's audited consolidated<br /><br />
financial<br /><br />
statements<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
XCL-China's<br /><br />

1997 and 1996, the<br /><br />

contained<br /><br />
an<br /><br />

paragraph<br /><br />
indicating factors which create substantial doubt about the<br /><br />
Company's and XCL-China's ability to continue as a going concern.<br /><br />
Such factors include the Company's ability to generate additional<br /><br />
cash flows to satisfy its development and exploratory<br /><br />

Volatility<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Oil and Gas Prices; Impact<br /><br />
on<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
Profitability<br /><br />
- ----------------------------------------------------------------The Company's revenue, profitability and future rate of<br /><br />
growth are substantially dependent upon prevailing prices for<br /><br />
crude oil and natural gas. Crude oil and natural gas prices can<br /><br />
be extremely volatile and in prior years have been depressed by<br /><br />
excess total supplies. Prices are also affected by actions of<br /><br />
the United States and foreign governments and international<br /><br />
cartels.<br /><br />
Further, prices are often seasonal. There can be no<br /><br />
assurance that current levels for crude oil and natural gas<br /><br />
prices can be sustained. Any substantial or extended decline in<br /><br />
such prices would have a material adverse effect on the Company's<br /><br />
financial condition and results of operations, including reduced<br /><br />
cash flow and borrowing capacity.<br /><br />
Operating Hazards; Uninsured Risks<br /><br />
- ---------------------------------The nature of the crude oil and natural gas business<br /><br />
involves many operating hazards such as crude oil and natural gas<br /><br />
blowouts, explosions, encountering formations with<br /><br />
abnormal<br /><br />
pressures, cratering and crude oil spills and fires,<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
inclement weather. Any of these could result in damage to or<br /><br />
destruction of crude oil and natural gas wells, destruction of<br /><br />
producing facilities, damage to life or property, suspension of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
operations, environmental damage and possible liability to the<br /><br />
Company.<br /><br />
In accordance with customary industry practices, the<br /><br />
Company maintains insurance against some, but not all, of such<br /><br />
risks and losses. The Company does not maintain any insurance<br /><br />
against the risks of expropriation and nationalization of its<br /><br />
business interests in China. The occurrence of such an event not<br /><br />
fully covered by insurance could have a material adverse effect<br /><br />
on the financial condition and results of operations of the<br /><br />
Company.<br /><br />
Competition<br /><br />
- ----------The oil and gas industry is marked by strong competition<br /><br />
from major oil companies and independent operators in acquiring<br /><br />
properties and leases for the exploration for, and production of,<br /><br />
crude oil and natural gas. Competition is particularly intense<br /><br />
with respect to the acquisition of desirable undeveloped crude<br /><br />
oil and natural gas properties. The Company anticipates such<br /><br />
competition in connection with any expansion of its activities in<br /><br />
China.<br /><br />
The principal competitive factors in the acquisition of<br /><br />
such undeveloped crude oil and natural gas properties include the<br /><br />
staff and data necessary to identify, investigate and acquire<br /><br />
interests in such properties, close working relationships with<br /><br />
governmental authorities who control acquisition, exploration,<br /><br />
production and marketing activities in China, and the financial<br /><br />
resources necessary to acquire and develop such properties. Many<br /><br />
of the Company's competitors have substantially greater financial<br /><br />
resources, staff and facilities.<br /><br />
The principal raw materials and resources necessary for the<br /><br />
exploration and production of crude oil and natural gas are<br /><br />
interests in prospective properties, drilling rigs and related<br /><br />
equipment<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
explore for such reserves and knowledgeable<br /><br />
personnel to conduct all phases of crude oil and natural gas<br /><br />
operations. The Company must compete for such raw materials and<br /><br />
resources with both major integrated energy companies<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
independent operators. Although the Company believes that its<br /><br />
current operating and financial resources are adequate<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
preclude any significant disruption of its operations in the<br /><br />
immediate future, the continued availability of such materials<br /><br />
and resources to the Company cannot be assured.<br /><br />
Depletion of Reserves<br /><br />
- --------------------The rate of production from crude oil and natural gas<br /><br />
properties declines as reserves are depleted.<br /><br />
Except to the<br /><br />
extent the Company acquires additional properties containing<br /><br />
proved reserves, conducts successful exploration and development<br /><br />
activities or, through engineering studies, identifies additional<br /><br />
behind-pipe zones or secondary recovery reserves, the proved<br /><br />
reserves of the Company will decline as reserves are produced.<br /><br />
Future crude oil and natural gas production is therefore highly<br /><br />
dependent upon the Company's level of success in acquiring or<br /><br />
finding additional reserves.<br /><br />
Government Regulation<br /><br />
- --------------------The Company's business is subject to certain Chinese and<br /><br />
United States federal, state, and local laws and regulations<br /><br />
relating to the exploration for and development, production and<br /><br />
marketing of crude oil and natural gas, as well as environmental<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
safety<br /><br />
matters.<br /><br />
In addition, the Chinese government<br /><br />
regulates various aspects of foreign company operations in China.<br /><br />
Such laws and regulations have generally become more stringent in<br /><br />
recent years in the United States, often imposing greater<br /><br />
liability on a larger number of potentially responsible parties.<br /><br />
It is not unreasonable to expect that the same trend will be<br /><br />
encountered in China. Because the requirements imposed by such<br /><br />
laws and regulations are frequently changed, the Company is<br /><br />
unable to predict the ultimate cost of compliance. There is no<br /><br />
assurance that laws and regulations enacted in the future will<br /><br />
not adversely affect the Company's financial condition and<br /><br />
results of operations.<br /><br />
Dependence on Key Personnel<br /><br />
- ---------------------------<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company depends to a large extent on Marsden W. Miller,<br /><br />
Jr., its Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer, for<br /><br />
its management and business and financial contacts in China and<br /><br />
its relationship with Chinese authorities. The Company does not<br /><br />
have an employment contract with Mr. Miller or with any other<br /><br />
officer or employee, other than employment agreements or similar<br /><br />
arrangements with certain operational employees of the Company's<br /><br />
subsidiaries. See "Management." The unavailability of Mr. Miller<br /><br />
would have a material adverse effect on the Company's business.<br /><br />
The Company's success is also dependent upon its ability to<br /><br />
retain skilled technical personnel. While the Company has not to<br /><br />
date experienced difficulties in employing or retaining such<br /><br />
personnel, its failure to do so in the future could adversely<br /><br />
affect its business. The Company does not maintain key man life<br /><br />
insurance on any of its executives or other personnel.<br /><br />
Limitations on the Availability of the Company's Net Operating<br /><br />
Loss Carryforwards<br /><br />
- ---------------------------------------------------------------The Company has incurred net operating loss ("NOL")<br /><br />
carryforwards as at December 31, 1997 of $183 million.<br /><br />
Use of<br /><br />
the NOLs by the Company are subject to limitations under Section<br /><br />
382 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 relating to ownership<br /><br />
changes. The various stock offerings made by the Company may have<br /><br />
triggered those limits. Also uncertainties as to the future use<br /><br />
of the NOLs exist under the criteria set forth in Financial<br /><br />
Accounting<br /><br />
Standards<br /><br />
Board ("FASB")<br /><br />
Statement<br /><br />
No.<br /><br />
109,<br /><br />
"Accounting for Income Taxes."<br /><br />
The Company established<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
valuation allowance of $81.1 million and $83.6 million for<br /><br />
deferred tax assets at December 31, 1996 and 1997, respectively.<br /><br />
Lack of Public Market<br /><br />
- --------------------There is no current public market for the Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock other than the limited trading through the<br /><br />
Private Offering, Resales and Trading through Automated Linkage<br /><br />
("PORTAL") Market of the National Association of Securities<br /><br />
Dealers, Inc. and none is expected to develop.<br /><br />
Possible Volatility of Price of the Common Stock<br /><br />
- -----------------------------------------------The market price of the Common Stock and Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock could be subject to wide fluctuations in response<br /><br />
to quarterly variations in the Company's results of operations,<br /><br />
changes in earnings estimates by analysts, conditions in the oil<br /><br />
and gas industry or general market or economic conditions.<br /><br />
No Cash Dividends<br /><br />
- ----------------The Company has not paid any cash dividends to date on the<br /><br />
Common Stock and there are no plans for cash dividend payments on<br /><br />
its Preferred Stock or Common Stock in the foreseeable future.<br /><br />
The Indenture also limits cash dividends on the Company's equity<br /><br />
securities. Dividends on the Company's Preferred Stock have been<br /><br />
paid in kind.<br /><br />
In the event of dividend defaults on the<br /><br />
outstanding shares of Preferred Stock, under the terms of such<br /><br />
Stock the Company would be restricted from paying cash dividends<br /><br />
on the Common Stock for so long as such dividend defaults<br /><br />
continued. See "Price Range of Common Stock," "Dividend Policy,"<br /><br />
"Description of Existing Debt" and "Description of Capital Stock<br /><br />
- -- Preferred Stock."<br /><br />
Possible Delisting of Common Stock<br /><br />
- ---------------------------------The AMEX has, since November 1996, continued to review the<br /><br />
Company's listing eligibility since the Company has not met<br /><br />
certain financial requirements for continued listing. The Company<br /><br />
intends to try to satisfy the Exchange's concerns. In the event<br /><br />
the Common Stock is delisted from the AMEX, the liquidity of the<br /><br />
Securities and the Company's ability to continue funding its<br /><br />
activities through the sale of securities may be significantly<br /><br />
<br /><br />
impaired.<br /><br />
Certain Anti-takeover Provisions<br /><br />
- -------------------------------A Change of Control or other Fundamental Change gives<br /><br />
holders of Amended Series A Preferred Stock special conversion<br /><br />
rights for 45 days. These rights are intended to provide those<br /><br />
holders with limited loss protection in certain circumstances.<br /><br />
The rights may also render more costly or otherwise discourage<br /><br />
certain<br /><br />
takeovers<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
other<br /><br />
business<br /><br />
combinations.<br /><br />
See<br /><br />
"Description of Capital Stock -- Preferred Stock -- Amended<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock -- Special Conversion Rights."<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
Amended and Restated Certificate<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Incorporation contains provisions that the Board of Directors<br /><br />
believes may impede or discourage a takeover of the Company<br /><br />
without the support of the incumbent Board. See "Description of<br /><br />
Capital Stock -- Common Stock -- Special Charter and By-Law<br /><br />
Provisions."<br /><br />
Year 2000 Compliance<br /><br />
- -------------------The Company has conducted a review of its computer systems<br /><br />
to identify the systems that could be affected by the "Year 2000"<br /><br />
issue and has upgraded certain of its software to software that<br /><br />
purports to be Year 2000 compliant. The Year 2000 problem is the<br /><br />
result of computer programs being written using two digits<br /><br />
(rather than four) to define the applicable year and equipment<br /><br />
with time-sensitive embedded components. Any of the Company's<br /><br />
programs that have time-sensitive software or equipment that has<br /><br />
time-sensitive embedded components may recognize a date using<br /><br />
"00" as the year 1900 rather than the year 2000.<br /><br />
This could<br /><br />
result in a major system failure or miscalculations. Although no<br /><br />
assurance can be given because of the potential wide scale<br /><br />
manifestations of this problem which may affect the Company's<br /><br />
business, the Company presently believes that the Year 2000<br /><br />
problem will not pose significant operational problems for its<br /><br />
computer systems. The Company is not able to estimate the total<br /><br />
costs of undertaking Year 2000 remedial activities, if they will<br /><br />
be required. However, based upon information developed to date,<br /><br />
it believes that the total cost of Year 2000 remediation will not<br /><br />
be material to the Company's cash flow, results of operation or<br /><br />
financial condition. The Company also may be vulnerable to other<br /><br />
companies' Year 2000 issues. The Company's current estimates of<br /><br />
the impact of the Year 2000 problem on its operations and<br /><br />
financial results do not include costs that may be incurred as a<br /><br />
result of any vendors' or customers' failure to become Year 2000<br /><br />
compliant on a timely basis. The Company intends to initiate<br /><br />
formal communications with all of its significant vendors and<br /><br />
customers with respect to such persons' Year 2000 compliance<br /><br />
programs and status in the fourth quarter of 1998. The Company<br /><br />
expects to complete its Year 2000 review and, if required,<br /><br />
remediation efforts within a time frame that will enable its<br /><br />
computer-based and embedded chip systems to function without<br /><br />
significant disruption in the Year 2000. However, there can be<br /><br />
no assurance that such other companies will achieve Year 2000<br /><br />
compliance or that any conversions by such companies to become<br /><br />
Year 2000 compliant will be compatible with the Company's<br /><br />
computer system. The inability of the Company or any of its<br /><br />
principal vendors or customers to become Year 2000 compliant in a<br /><br />
timely manner could have a material adverse effect on the<br /><br />
Company's financial condition or results of operations.<br /><br />
FINANCIAL RESTRUCTURING<br /><br />
The Company has recently taken steps to simplify its capital<br /><br />
structure. Effective November 10, 1997, the Company recapitalized<br /><br />
and combined the Series A and E Preferred Stock into an aggregate<br /><br />
of 790,613 shares of Amended Series A Preferred Stock (including<br /><br />
accrued and unpaid dividends paid in kind). As of September 30,<br /><br />
1998 there were 1,181,614 shares of Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock issued and outstanding with an aggregate liquidation<br /><br />
preference of approximately $100 million. Effective January 16,<br /><br />
1998, the Series F Preferred Stock was mandatorily converted into<br /><br />
an aggregate of 633,893 shares of Common Stock. On March 3, 1998,<br /><br />
the Company settled litigation instituted by the holder of its<br /><br />
Series B, Cumulative Preferred Stock (the "Series B Preferred<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Stock").<br /><br />
The holder revoked and withdrew its redemption notice<br /><br />
and sold its shares of Series B Preferred Stock and accompanying<br /><br />
warrants. The purchasers exchanged the stock and warrants for<br /><br />
44,465<br /><br />
shares of Amended Series B, Cumulative Convertible<br /><br />
Preferred Stock ("Amended Series B Preferred Stock") and warrants<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
purchase 250,000 shares of Common Stock,<br /><br />
subject<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
adjustment, and received 2,620 shares of Amended Series B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock in payment of all accrued and unpaid dividends on<br /><br />
the Series B Preferred Stock. See "Business -- Litigation."<br /><br />
As<br /><br />
of September 30, 1998, there were 48,405 shares of Amended Series<br /><br />
B Preferred Stock issued and outstanding with an aggregate<br /><br />
liquidation preference of approximately $4.8 million.<br /><br />
For a<br /><br />
description of the material terms of the Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock and the Amended Series B Preferred Stock, see<br /><br />
"Description of Capital Stock -- Preferred Stock -- Amended<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock" and "--Amended Series B Preferred<br /><br />
Stock."<br /><br />
USE OF PROCEEDS<br /><br />
Each Selling Security Holder will receive all of the net<br /><br />
proceeds from the sale of the Securities owned by such Selling<br /><br />
Security Holder. The Company will not receive any proceeds from<br /><br />
the sale of any Securities, although the Company will receive the<br /><br />
proceeds from any exercise of the Warrants. However, there can<br /><br />
be no assurance that the Warrants will be exercised.<br /><br />
Assuming<br /><br />
all of the Warrants are exercised, the net proceeds to the<br /><br />
Company would be approximately $63 million. The proceeds from<br /><br />
such Warrant exercises, if any, will be used by the Company to<br /><br />
fund its China projects and for general working capital purposes.<br /><br />

AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS<br /><br />
The following discussion and analysis should be read<br /><br />
together with the Consolidated Financial Statements, the notes<br /><br />
thereto and the supplemental data included in this Prospectus.<br /><br />
References to Notes in this section of the Prospectus are to the<br /><br />
notes to the audited Consolidated Financial Statements. See also<br /><br />
the discussion on page [3] entitled "Disclosure Regarding ForwardLooking Statements."<br /><br />

- ---------------------------------------------------<br /><br />

$<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Background<br /><br />
---------The Company's management decided in the fourth quarter of<br /><br />
1995 to focus on the Company's operations in China and to sell<br /><br />
its other assets. The excellent well test results on the Zhao<br /><br />
Dong Block and the Company's reserve assessments support this<br /><br />
decision. The Company has focused on (i) raising funds to meet<br /><br />
capital requirements for Chinese operations, (ii) selling its<br /><br />
other properties and (iii) simplifying its capital structure to<br /><br />
make it easier to raise capital. The Company intends to continue<br /><br />
these activities and to work with Apache and CNODC to refine the<br /><br />
ODP<br /><br />
to reduce expenditures and accelerate production. The<br /><br />
Company's only historic revenues have been from the Company's<br /><br />
financing activities and from properties previously sold and<br /><br />
those currently held for sale or investment. The Company is in<br /><br />
the development stage with respect to its operations in China and<br /><br />
has not generated any revenues from operations related to its<br /><br />
properties and interests in China.<br /><br />
The Company has made significant capital expenditures since<br /><br />
acquiring its interest in the Zhao Dong Block in 1992.<br /><br />
Despite<br /><br />
incurring losses since 1992, the Company, because of the high<br /><br />
quality of the Zhao Dong Block, has been able to obtain all<br /><br />
required funds for the exploration and development of the Zhao<br /><br />
Dong Block.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On August 20, 1998, the Company entered into a production<br /><br />
sharing contract with CNODC for the 12,000-acre Zhang Dong Block<br /><br />
and on September 15, 1998, the contract was approved by the<br /><br />
Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation of China,<br /><br />
effective October 1, 1998.<br /><br />
Liquidity and Capital Resources<br /><br />
------------------------------The Company offered and sold $75 million of Notes and $25<br /><br />
million of equity on May 20, 1997. During 1997 such funds were<br /><br />
used to pay costs of the offering, the Company's 1997 exploration<br /><br />
and development costs and $38 million of debt. At June 30, 1998,<br /><br />
the Company had an unrestricted operating cash balance of $11.4<br /><br />
million and restricted cash held in escrow for the payment of<br /><br />
interest on the Notes of $5.2 million. The Company had net<br /><br />
working capital of $6.0 million. These cash balances are not<br /><br />
sufficient to cover the Company's working capital requirements<br /><br />
and capital expenditure obligations on the Zhao Dong Block during<br /><br />
the remainder of 1998 and through 1999.<br /><br />
As a result of the Company's decision to focus on China and<br /><br />
sell its U.S. assets, the Company presently has no source of<br /><br />
material revenues. Revenues for 1997 were $0.2 million versus<br /><br />
$1.1 million in 1996. The Company incurred a loss for fiscal<br /><br />
1997 of $14.0 million and expects to incur a loss in 1998 as well<br /><br />
because production and related cash flow from the Zhao Dong and<br /><br />
Zhang Dong Blocks are not expected until 1999.<br /><br />
For the six<br /><br />
months ended June 30, 1998, the Company had a net loss of $4.1<br /><br />
million.<br /><br />
Management's Plan<br /><br />
----------------The Company's unrestricted cash will be required for working<br /><br />
capital and exploration, development and production expenditures<br /><br />
on the Zhao Dong and Zhang Dong Blocks.<br /><br />
With respect to the Zhao Dong Block, CNODC has given written<br /><br />
notice that it will participate as to its full 51% share of the CD Field and has urged that production begin as soon as reasonably<br /><br />
practicable.<br /><br />
Except for certain exploratory wells on which<br /><br />
Apache has an obligation to pay for the Company's costs, the<br /><br />
Company is required to fund 50% of all exploration expenditures<br /><br />
and 24.5% of all development and production expenditures.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company<br /><br />
estimates<br /><br />
that its share of<br /><br />
actual<br /><br />
development<br /><br />
expenditures for the C-D Field for the remainder of 1998 will be<br /><br />
<br /><br />
approximately $2.0 million. The Company estimates that its share<br /><br />
of unpaid exploration expenses for the remainder of 1998 will be<br /><br />
approximately $5.0 million. The Company estimates that its share<br /><br />
of development expenses for 1999 will be approximately $22<br /><br />
million. The Company estimates its share of exploration expenses<br /><br />
of the remaining two obligatory wells to be drilled in 1999 is<br /><br />
approximately $6.0 million. The Company anticipates that in<br /><br />
addition to the two obligatory exploration wells to be drilled in<br /><br />
1999, additional exploration wells may be drilled during 1999.<br /><br />
The Company presently projects and plans that these funds will be<br /><br />
available from the sale or refinancing of domestic oil and gas<br /><br />
properties held for sale and/or investment in land, project<br /><br />
financing, increasing the amount of senior secured<br /><br />
notes,<br /><br />
supplier financing, additional equity, including the exercise of<br /><br />
currently outstanding warrants to buy common stock,<br /><br />
joint<br /><br />
ventures with other oil companies and proceeds from production.<br /><br />
Based<br /><br />
on<br /><br />
continuing discussions with major<br /><br />
stockholders,<br /><br />
investment bankers, potential purchasers and other oil companies,<br /><br />
the Company believes that such required funds will be available.<br /><br />
However, there is no assurance that such funds will be available<br /><br />
and, if available, on commercially reasonable terms.<br /><br />
Any new<br /><br />
debt could require approval of the holders of the Company's Notes<br /><br />
and there is no assurance that such approval could be obtained.<br /><br />
See "Risk Factors."<br /><br />
Due to the successful results of the D-3 and C-4 Wells, the<br /><br />
1998 work program and budget exceed the Company's initial<br /><br />
preliminary projections earlier in 1997. This results from the<br /><br />
necessity of drilling at least one appraisal well offsetting the<br /><br />
C-4 exploratory well and the decision to extend the Contract into<br /><br />
its third exploratory period because of the successful drilling<br /><br />
of the D-3 and C-4 wells. XCL, Apache, and CNODC are working<br /><br />
together to reduce capital costs for the Zhao Dong Block and to<br /><br />
determine whether the commencement of production from the C-4<br /><br />
Well area can be accelerated into the first half of 1999.<br /><br />
This<br /><br />
work has already resulted in reductions of estimated capital<br /><br />
costs of approximately $35 million based on a change in the<br /><br />
conceptual design, and a determination that it is possible to<br /><br />
commence production from the C-4 well area in the first half of<br /><br />
1999. It is the Company's understanding that the Company, Apache<br /><br />
and CNODC have now all agreed to make every effort to achieve<br /><br />
initial production in the first half of 1999. The $28 million<br /><br />
estimated to be necessary for exploration and development in 1999<br /><br />
does not include the entire cost of accelerating production from<br /><br />
the C-4 Well area into the first part of 1999. The Company<br /><br />
estimates<br /><br />
this<br /><br />
would require additional<br /><br />
expenditures<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
approximately $960,000, which the Company believes it can obtain<br /><br />
from the sources described above.<br /><br />
The Company is the operator of the Zhang Dong Block and, as<br /><br />
such, is required to cover the costs of initial appraisal<br /><br />
drilling, upgrading production facilities and additional studies<br /><br />
of seismic data. The contract commits the Company to drill at<br /><br />
least one well during the first year. Under the contract, the<br /><br />
Company is entitled to 49% of the production. The Company<br /><br />
estimates that its minimum capital requirements over the next<br /><br />
year to satisfy the terms of the Zhang Dong contract are<br /><br />
approximately $8 million. Funds are expected to come from the<br /><br />
previously mentioned sources.<br /><br />
Longer term liquidity is dependent upon the Company's future<br /><br />
performance, including commencement of production in China, as<br /><br />
well as continued access to capital markets. In addition, the<br /><br />
Company's efforts to secure additional financing could<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
impaired if its Common Stock is delisted from the AMEX.<br /><br />
If funds for the purposes described above are not available,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company may be required substantially to curtail its<br /><br />
operations or to sell or surrender all or part of its interest in<br /><br />
the Zhao Dong or the Zhang Dong Blocks and/or its other interests<br /><br />
in China in order to meet its obligations and continue as a going<br /><br />
concern.<br /><br />
The Company is not obligated<br /><br />
capital payments to its lubricating<br /><br />
<br /><br />
to make any additional<br /><br />
oil and coalbed methane<br /><br />
<br /><br />
projects.<br /><br />
The Company is in discussions with the Chinese about<br /><br />
expansion of their lube oil venture. If these discussions are<br /><br />
successfully concluded, additional capital investments will be<br /><br />
required by the Company; however, at this time it is not known<br /><br />
what the extent or timing for such investments might be.<br /><br />
Similarly, if the Company's coalbed methane project becomes<br /><br />
active and is successful, the Company may make additional<br /><br />
investments in that business. Again, the extent and timing of<br /><br />
such investment, if any, is unknown at this time.<br /><br />

Year 2000 Compliance<br /><br />
- -------------------The Company has conducted a review of its computer systems<br /><br />
to identify the systems that could be affected by the "Year 2000"<br /><br />
issue and has upgraded certain of its software to software that<br /><br />
purports to be Year 2000 compliant. The Year 2000 problem is the<br /><br />
result of computer programs being written using two digits<br /><br />
(rather than four) to define the applicable year and equipment<br /><br />
with time-sensitive embedded components. Any of the Company's<br /><br />
programs that have time-sensitive software or equipment that has<br /><br />
time-sensitive embedded components may recognize a date using<br /><br />
"00" as the year 1900 rather than the year 2000.<br /><br />
This could<br /><br />
result in a major system failure or miscalculations. Although no<br /><br />
assurance can be given because of the potential wide scale<br /><br />
manifestations of this problem which may affect the Company's<br /><br />
business, the Company presently believes that the Year 2000<br /><br />
problem will not pose significant operational problems for its<br /><br />
computer systems. The Company is not able to estimate the total<br /><br />
costs of undertaking Year 2000 remedial activities, if they will<br /><br />
be required. However, based upon information developed to date,<br /><br />
it believes that the total cost of Year 2000 remediation will not<br /><br />
be material to the Company's cash flow, results of operations or<br /><br />
financial condition.<br /><br />
The Company also may be vulnerable to other companies' Year<br /><br />
2000 issues. The Company's current estimates of the impact of<br /><br />
the Year 2000 problem on its operations and financial results do<br /><br />
not include costs that may be incurred<br /><br />
as a<br /><br />
result of<br /><br />
any vendors' or customers' failure to become Year 2000 compliant<br /><br />
on a timely basis.<br /><br />
The Company intends to initiate formal<br /><br />
communications with all of its significant vendors and customers<br /><br />
with respect to such persons' Year 2000 compliance programs and<br /><br />
status in the fourth quarter of 1998. The Company expects to<br /><br />
complete its Year 2000 review and, if required, remediation<br /><br />
efforts within a time frame that will enable its computer-based<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
embedded chip systems to function without significant<br /><br />
disruption in the Year 2000. However, there can be no assurance<br /><br />
that such other companies will achieve Year 2000 compliance or<br /><br />
that any conversions by such companies to become Year 2000<br /><br />
compliant will be compatible with the Company's computer system.<br /><br />
The inability of the Company or any of its principal vendors or<br /><br />
customers to become Year 2000 compliant in a timely manner could<br /><br />
have a material adverse effect on the Company's financial<br /><br />
condition or results of operations.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
BUSINESS<br /><br />
The Company's principal business is the exploration for and<br /><br />
development and production of crude oil and natural gas. Building<br /><br />
on the success of its first such project in China, the joint<br /><br />
venture on the Zhao Dong Block (see "Prospectus Summary -- The<br /><br />
Company"), the Company's strategy is to expand those operations<br /><br />
and, selectively, to enter into additional energy-related joint<br /><br />
ventures.<br /><br />
Published information shows that the undeveloped<br /><br />
energy resources of China are extensive and that China's energy<br /><br />
needs are growing at a high rate. The Chinese government,<br /><br />
further, has recently encouraged foreign participation in the<br /><br />
development of its energy resources, and has demonstrated a<br /><br />
willingness to include independent oil and gas exploration<br /><br />
companies such as the Company in additional energy-related joint<br /><br />
ventures. The Company's excellent relationship with the Chinese<br /><br />
energy-related industry representatives should assist it in<br /><br />
remaining competitive in that country. See "The Zhao Dong Block,"<br /><br />
below. On August 20, 1998, the Company entered into a production<br /><br />
sharing contract with CNODC, effective October 1, 1998, for the<br /><br />
12,000-acre Zhang Dong Block. See "Zhang Dong Block," below.<br /><br />
To expand its energy-related activities in China, on July<br /><br />
17, 1995 the Company signed a contract with CNPC United Lube Oil<br /><br />
Corporation to engage in the manufacturing, distribution, and<br /><br />
marketing of lubricating oil in China and in southeast Asian<br /><br />
markets. See "United/XCL Lube Oil Joint Venture," below. And on<br /><br />
December<br /><br />
14,<br /><br />
1995, the Company signed a<br /><br />
Memorandum<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Understanding with the China National Administration of Coal<br /><br />
Geology ("CNACG"), pursuant to which the parties have begun<br /><br />
cooperative exploration and development of coalbed methane in two<br /><br />
areas of China. See "Coalbed Methane Project," below.<br /><br />
