Coast area of the United States. Formerly The Exploration Company<br /><br />
of Louisiana, Inc., XCL Ltd. was incorporated in Delaware in<br /><br />
1987. It is the successor to a Louisiana corporation of the same<br /><br />
name, incorporated in 1981. The Company's principal executive<br /><br />
offices are at 110 Rue Jean Lafitte, 2nd Floor, Lafayette,<br /><br />
Louisiana 70508. Its telephone number is (318) 237-0325.<br /><br />
As of June 30, 1998, the Company's employees totaled 26. No<br /><br />
employees are subject to any union contracts. The Company<br /><br />
believes it maintains good relations with its employees.<br /><br />
The Zhao Dong Block<br /><br />
- ------------------Geology<br /><br />
------The Zhao Dong Block extends from the shoreline of the Dagang<br /><br />
oil field complex on Bohai Bay to water depths of approximately 5<br /><br />
meters. It encompasses approximately 197 square km (roughly<br /><br />
50,000 gross acres). Geologic information suggests that a portion<br /><br />
of the Zhao Dong Block is a seaward extension of the Dagang oil<br /><br />
field complex which is one of China's largest.<br /><br />
According to<br /><br />
statistics published by Wood McKenzie in the Southeast Asia<br /><br />
Report, Dagang has produced over 700 million barrels of oil and<br /><br />
has an estimated ultimate recovery of substantially more.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company has not verified this published information.<br /><br />
Tertiary formations constitute a major portion of the Zhao<br /><br />
Dong Block's production, its geology being in many respects<br /><br />
similar to the U.S. Gulf Coast. Bohai Bay sediments are however<br /><br />
non-marine and oil prone, while the U.S. Gulf Coast sediments are<br /><br />
open-marine and gas and condensate prone. Seismic and subsurface<br /><br />
data appear to indicate a thick, structured sedimentary section<br /><br />
in the contract area. Proximity to producing fields and highly<br /><br />
productive test results from the wells which have been drilled<br /><br />
suggest excellent source rock.<br /><br />
Seismic<br /><br />
-------<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Seismic data were acquired in and around the Zhao Dong Block<br /><br />
by shallow water and transition zone seismic crews from 1986 to<br /><br />
1988. While the original processing of the data was fair in<br /><br />
reflection continuity, the Company's initial evaluation involved<br /><br />
reprocessing 721 km, resulting in dramatic improvement for both<br /><br />
structural and stratigraphic interpretation. This reprocessing,<br /><br />
plus 390 km of new seismic data (outlined below), make available<br /><br />
a current total of 1,111 km of 2D seismic data in and around the<br /><br />
Zhao Dong Block.<br /><br />
From 1993 through 1995 the Company acquired an additional<br /><br />
390 km of 2D seismic data shot by Dagang Geophysical, a Chinese<br /><br />
firm, all of which assisted the Company in assessing the Zhao<br /><br />
Dong Block's potential.<br /><br />
A 1997 3-D seismic program was designed to delineate<br /><br />
development well locations in the C-D Field and to better define<br /><br />
exploration prospects on the remainder of the Zhao Dong Block.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
program covered approximately 100 square km and cost<br /><br />
approximately $5.5 million; the Company's share was approximately<br /><br />
$2.75 million. A similar program (at a comparable cost) will be<br /><br />
undertaken in 1998 to cover most of the rest of the Zhao Dong<br /><br />
Block.<br /><br />
Drilling Results<br /><br />
---------------Mapping of seismic events on shallow, medium, and deep<br /><br />
reflections delineated possibly productive lead areas. Subsequent<br /><br />
exploratory drilling resulted in three successful discoveries<br /><br />
along<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Zhao Bei fault system. Appraisal<br /><br />
tests<br /><br />
have<br /><br />
structurally and stratigraphically delineated the aerial extent<br /><br />
of both the "C" and the "D" segments of the C-D Field.<br /><br />
Hydrocarbons have been found in the Lower Minghuazhen (Pliocene),<br /><br />
the Guantao (Miocene), and the Shahejie (Oligocene) formations.<br /><br />
Appraisal drilling commenced in 1998 to delineate the extent of<br /><br />
the 1997 C-4 discovery located northeast of the C-D Field. The C4<br /><br />
well<br /><br />
is<br /><br />
productive from the Shahejie Formation<br /><br />
and,<br /><br />
additionally, from Jurassic and Permian Age sediments.<br /><br />
The Company's drilling programs, year by year, have been as<br /><br />
follows:<br /><br />
1994 Drilling<br /><br />
------------Zhao Dong C-1. The first of three Phase 1 exploratory<br /><br />
wells, C-1 was spudded in April 1994, and drilled to a depth<br /><br />
of 9,843 feet. Oil was tested in two Pliocene sands of the<br /><br />
Lower Minghuazhen Formation, from perforations shot between<br /><br />
4,278 and 4,462 feet, and yielded a combined test rate of<br /><br />
2,160 BOPD with no water. Total net pay for the zones tested<br /><br />
was 97 feet.<br /><br />
Zhao Dong C-2. Spudded and drilled in October 1994, the<br /><br />
C-2 appraisal well was drilled to a depth of 7,134 feet and<br /><br />
confirmed the C-1 discovery. Tested from four intervals,<br /><br />
between 4,267 and 4,481 feet, the combined rate of three of<br /><br />
the zones was 3,640 BOPD with no water. Total net pay for<br /><br />
the zones tested was 47 feet.<br /><br />
1995 Drilling<br /><br />
------------Zhao Dong C-2-2. Drilled directionally in April 1995 to<br /><br />
a measured depth of 5,625 feet (5,034 feet true vertical<br /><br />
depth), the C-2-2 appraisal was shaled out for prospective<br /><br />
sands<br /><br />
in the Minghuazhen and then plugged back<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
sidetracked as C-2-2A.<br /><br />
Zhao Dong C-2-2A. After plugging and abandoning the<br /><br />
bottom section of the C-2-2 well, the C-2-2A sidetrack well<br /><br />
was drilled structurally updip of the original wellbore to a<br /><br />
measured depth of 5,084 feet (4,956 true vertical depth).<br /><br />
Although Minghuazhen prospective sands were present and not<br /><br />
shaled out, the objective sands were water wet. Accordingly,<br /><br />
the well was plugged and abandoned.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Zhao Dong D-1. Designed to test the Ordovician<br /><br />
Carbonate section, the D-1 exploratory well reached a depth<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
8,784 feet in June 1995. Although no hydrocarbon<br /><br />
potential was found in the Ordovician Carbonates, oil was<br /><br />
found in the Lower Minghuazhen, proving this shallower<br /><br />
section to be productive upthrown to the Zhao Bei fault<br /><br />
system. Drill-stem testing, with perforations at 4,185 to<br /><br />
4,205 feet, confirmed hydrocarbons with an initial rate of<br /><br />
1,330 BOPD. The net pay for this zone was 20 feet.<br /><br />
Although the D-1 was designed primarily to test deeper<br /><br />
Paleozoic objectives, from 3,523 to 6,268 feet it yielded<br /><br />
another 15 sands ranging in age from Pliocene Minghuazhen to<br /><br />
Permian with hydrocarbon shows in mudlogs and/or sidewall<br /><br />
cores. One Permian sand tested water with a trace of 30<br /><br />
gravity oil; one Minghuazhen sand tested water with 2% oil.<br /><br />
Located on the eastern edge of the C-D structural<br /><br />
complex, the D-1 was not optimally placed to explore the<br /><br />
shallower hydrocarbon-containing sands. But the fact that it<br /><br />
tested 1,330 BOPD from one sand, tested water with smaller<br /><br />
amounts of oil from two other sands, and had shows in<br /><br />
numerous additional sands, suggests proximity to the limits<br /><br />
of a significant oil accumulation. Accordingly, the D-2<br /><br />
well, discussed under 1996 Drilling, below, was designed to<br /><br />
appraise the D-1 discovery at a much higher structural<br /><br />
position. See also the discussion, immediately below, of a<br /><br />
parallel relationship between and among the C-3, C-2, and C1 wells.<br /><br />
Zhao Dong C-3. Although scheduled to be drilled to<br /><br />
5,004 feet,<br /><br />
this appraisal well, drilled in July 1995,<br /><br />
reached a total depth of 6,773 feet. Analysis of geological<br /><br />
information during drilling had shown that the C-3 was<br /><br />
structurally higher than both the C-1 and C-2, and so<br /><br />
drilling continued to test the Shahejie Formation until, at<br /><br />
approximately 6,595 feet, the Zhao Bei fault was crossed.<br /><br />
Eight different sands had drill-stem tests; seven were found<br /><br />
to be productive, as compared to only three and two for the<br /><br />
C-2 and C-1. (The C-1 and C-2 did however have oil shows in<br /><br />
several sands found to be productive in the C-3.) Cumulative<br /><br />
rate potential was 5,830 BOPD and 460 Mcfpd; one Shahejie<br /><br />
sand tested oil at 1,356 BOPD until water production began.<br /><br />
(Initial analysis indicates the water was coned due to<br /><br />
pressure draw-down during testing.) Total net pay for the<br /><br />
zones tested was 143 feet.<br /><br />
The C-3 thus indicates that Shahejie Formation sands<br /><br />
are<br /><br />
oil<br /><br />
productive<br /><br />
with significant<br /><br />
appraisal<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
exploration potential, both in the C-D Field and over much<br /><br />
of the as yet undrilled portion of the Zhao Dong Block.<br /><br />
Initial seismic stratigraphic analysis indicates additional<br /><br />
lacustrine fan systems could be present downdip.<br /><br />
1996 Drilling<br /><br />
------------Zhao Dong D-2. Spudded in November 1996, the D-2<br /><br />
appraisal<br /><br />
well was designed to test the<br /><br />
Minghuazhen<br /><br />
(Pliocene) and Guantao (Miocene) sands upthrown to the Zhao<br /><br />
Bei fault system, as well as the Shahejie (Oligocene)<br /><br />
Formation downthrown to a bifurcated fault of the same fault<br /><br />
system. It was drilled to a measured depth of 7,501 feet<br /><br />
(6,180 feet true vertical depth), on an upthrown fault<br /><br />
closure approximately 1.5 km west of and structurally higher<br /><br />
than the D-1 discovery well.<br /><br />
Five intervals (six drill-stem tests) from perforations<br /><br />
at 3,285 to 5,445 feet (3,277 to 4,950 feet true vertical<br /><br />
depth) tested at a combined rate of 11,571 BOPD, confirming<br /><br />
the lateral productivity of several sands previously seen<br /><br />
productive and, in the Guantao Formation, establishing<br /><br />
production in several new sands. This well also demonstrated<br /><br />
much higher initial flow rates without the need<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
artificial lift, one zone flowing 4,370 BOPD with 774 Mcfpd<br /><br />
of gas, and a second zone flowing 2,471 BOPD with 168 Mcfpd<br /><br />
of gas.<br /><br />
Sands seen productive in this well appear to be present<br /><br />
over the entire area, adding significantly to the overall<br /><br />
<br /><br />
potential of the C-D Field as well as the rest of the Zhao<br /><br />
Dong Block.<br /><br />
Total net pay for the zones tested was 243<br /><br />
feet.<br /><br />
1997 Drilling<br /><br />
------------Zhao Dong F-1. Planned as an exploratory well to<br /><br />
fulfill Phase I drilling commitments, the F-1 was designed<br /><br />
to test an 1,800+ foot thick section of the Shahejie<br /><br />
Formation on a four-way dip structural closure.<br /><br />
This<br /><br />
exploratory<br /><br />
well<br /><br />
was spudded in<br /><br />
October<br /><br />
1996<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
directionally drilled, from a drill pad built at the<br /><br />
shoreline, to a measured depth of 14,501 feet (10,968 true<br /><br />
vertical depth). Severe mechanical problems prevented the<br /><br />
well from being fully evaluated, and two sidetrack attempts<br /><br />
were unsuccessful. Drilling operations under a turnkey<br /><br />
contract have been abandoned. A number of Shahejie sands<br /><br />
were encountered, with some apparent oil shows.<br /><br />
Zhao Dong D-3. The second appraisal well for the D-1<br /><br />
discovery, and located approximately 1 km north of the D-1,<br /><br />
the D-3 was spudded in June 1997 and drilled to a depth of<br /><br />
5,740 feet. Although no drill-stem tests were performed<br /><br />
(since the data collected were sufficient to confirm the<br /><br />
productive nature of the reservoirs and since the rig was<br /><br />
needed to drill the C-4 Well), using wireline tools, oil was<br /><br />
recovered from several sands, most of which had tested oil<br /><br />
in the D-2 and D-1 wells, as well as from three new<br /><br />
productive sands for the "D" segment. Total net pay for the<br /><br />
productive zone was 89 feet. The D-3 Well thus solidified<br /><br />
structural interpretation and confirmed productive areas.<br /><br />
Zhao Dong C-4. An exploratory well designed to test PreTertiary and Shahejie Formations, the C-4 was spudded in<br /><br />
July 1997, on a separate structure approximately 2 km<br /><br />
northeast of the C-1, and was drilled to a depth of 8,993<br /><br />
feet. Eight zones tested at a combined rate of 15,349 BOPD,<br /><br />
6,107 Mcfpd of gas, and 14 barrels of condensate per day.<br /><br />
Total net pay for the zones tested was 209 feet.<br /><br />
The C-4 proved the presence and productivity of<br /><br />
multiple Oligocene Age Shahejie sands on the Zhao Dong<br /><br />
Block's northern portion. The C-4 also found multiple highquality Cretaceous and Jurassic sands, not encountered in<br /><br />
previous drilling, present and productive, indicating that<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
sands may be present and prospective elsewhere.<br /><br />
Significantly, the Shahejie, Cretaceous and Jurassic sands<br /><br />
contained higher gravity oil (28 to 38 degree API) and more<br /><br />
gas, indicating higher reservoir energy than previously<br /><br />
encountered. All zones tested exhibited natural flow.<br /><br />
1998 Drilling<br /><br />
------------Zhao Dong C-4-2. An appraisal well for the C-4 (the C4-2), located approximately 1.3 km south of the C-4, was<br /><br />
spudded in August 1998. The C-4-2 well is being drilled to<br /><br />
delineate the size of the reservoir encountered in the C-4<br /><br />
well.<br /><br />
The well is expected to be drilled to a depth of<br /><br />
approximately 9,700 feet to test the Shahejie, Cretaceous<br /><br />
and Jurassic Sands encountered in the C-4 well.<br /><br />
Zhao Dong C-5.<br /><br />
Also in August 1998, the<br /><br />
C-5<br /><br />
exploration well located approximately 3 km southwest of the<br /><br />
D-2 well commenced drilling. The C-5 well was drilled to a<br /><br />
depth of 7,646 feet.<br /><br />
No commercial oil and gas was<br /><br />
encountered and the well was plugged and abandoned.<br /><br />
Exploration Potential<br /><br />
- --------------------Reconnaissance seismic surveys on the Zhao Dong Block have<br /><br />
led the Company's independent petroleum engineers to identify, in<br /><br />
addition to the C-D Field and the C-4 discovery, twenty-six<br /><br />
prospective areas with exploratory potential. Seismic data over<br /><br />
these prospective areas have been analyzed and the potential<br /><br />
reserves are being evaluated.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Future Drilling Plans<br /><br />
- --------------------The Company, Apache, and CNODC have approved a five-well<br /><br />
drilling program for 1998, which will include an appraisal well<br /><br />
(the Zhao Dong C-4-2, referred to above, which commenced drilling<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
August 1998) to appraise the C-4 discovery and<br /><br />
four<br /><br />
exploratory wells, at least two of which will be in the "C" and<br /><br />
"D" segments (and one of which was the Zhao Dong C-5, referred to<br /><br />
above.<br /><br />
At least two of these wells are expected to be drilled<br /><br />
during the 1999 drilling season.<br /><br />
The Contract<br /><br />
- -----------The Company acquired the rights to the exploration,<br /><br />
development and production of the Zhao Dong Block by executing a<br /><br />
Production<br /><br />
Sharing Agreement with CNODC, a Chinese<br /><br />
state<br /><br />
enterprise, effective May 1, 1993 (the "Contract"). The Contract<br /><br />
includes the following terms:<br /><br />
The Foreign Contractor (the Company and Apache as a group,<br /><br />
working through a participation agreement) must pay for all<br /><br />
exploration costs. If a commercial discovery is made and if<br /><br />
CNODC exercises its option to participate, development and<br /><br />
operating costs and allocable remainder oil and gas production<br /><br />
are shared up to 51% by CNODC and the remainder by the Foreign<br /><br />
Contractor.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
work under the Contract is divided into three<br /><br />
categories,<br /><br />
Exploration,<br /><br />
Development<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Production.<br /><br />
Exploration, Development and Production operations can occur<br /><br />
concurrently on different areas of the Zhao Dong Block.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Contract is not to continue beyond 30 consecutive years.<br /><br />
All<br /><br />
exploration work must be completed during the Exploration Period<br /><br />
(which expires April 30, 2000). The Production Period for each<br /><br />
oil field covered by the Contract is 15 years, starting with the<br /><br />
date of first production for that field.<br /><br />
Exploration Period<br /><br />
-----------------Work performed and expenses incurred during this period,<br /><br />
consisting of three phases totaling seven contract years and<br /><br />
beginning as of May 1, 1993, are the exclusive responsibility of<br /><br />
the Foreign Contractor. The Contract mandates certain minimal<br /><br />
requirements for drilling, seismic and expenditures during each<br /><br />
phase of the Exploration Period. The Foreign Contractor has<br /><br />
elected to enter the third exploration phase (expiring April 30,<br /><br />
2000). The minimum work requirements for seismic and the minimum<br /><br />
expenditures for the balance of the Contract have been met. This<br /><br />
leaves only the drilling requirements left to be satisfied.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Foreign Contractor is required to drill three exploratory wells<br /><br />
prior to the expiration of the Exploration Period.<br /><br />
This will<br /><br />
complete its requirements in the Exploration Period. These three<br /><br />
wells are approved in the 1998 work program and budget and,<br /><br />
subject to rig availability (and, as to one of the wells,<br /><br />
location approval), are expected to be drilled in 1998 or 1999.<br /><br />
Development Period<br /><br />
------------------The Development Period for any field discovered during the<br /><br />
Exploration Period commences on the date the requisite Chinese<br /><br />
governmental authority approves the development plan for an oil<br /><br />
and/or gas field.<br /><br />
The C-D Field is now in the Development<br /><br />
Period.<br /><br />
Production Period<br /><br />
----------------The Production Period for any oil and/or gas field covered<br /><br />
by the Contract (the "Contract Area") will be 15 consecutive<br /><br />
years (each of 12 months), commencing for each such field on the<br /><br />
date of commencement of commercial production (as determined<br /><br />
under the terms of the Contract). However, prior to<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Production Period, and during the Development Period, oil and/or<br /><br />
gas may be produced and sold during a long-term testing period.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Relinquishment<br /><br />
-------------The Company expects that no relinquishment will be required<br /><br />
until Exploration Phase 3 has been concluded. After April 30,<br /><br />
2000, the portions of the Contract area, not including areas in<br /><br />
which<br /><br />
development and/or production activities<br /><br />
have<br /><br />
been<br /><br />
undertaken, must be relinquished.<br /><br />
Termination of the Contract<br /><br />
--------------------------The Contract may be terminated by the Foreign Contractor at<br /><br />
the end of each phase of the Exploration Period, without further<br /><br />
obligation. The parties have elected to go into the third phase<br /><br />
of the Exploration Period.<br /><br />
Post-Production Operating and Exploration Costs<br /><br />
----------------------------------------------After commercial production has begun, the operating costs<br /><br />
incurred in any given calendar year for an oil field shall be<br /><br />
recovered in kind from 60% of that year's oil production. After<br /><br />
recovery of operating costs, the 60% is applied to exploration<br /><br />
costs. Unrecovered operating costs shall be carried forward.<br /><br />
After recovery of operating and exploration costs for any<br /><br />
field, development costs shall be recovered by the Foreign<br /><br />
Contractor and CNODC from 60% of the remaining oil production,<br /><br />
plus deemed interest at 9%.<br /><br />
Natural gas shall be allocated according to the same general<br /><br />
principles, but in order to ensure reasonable benefit for the<br /><br />
Foreign Contractor the allocation percentages shall be adjusted<br /><br />
in the light of actual economic conditions.<br /><br />
Annual gross production ("AGP") of each oil and gas field<br /><br />
shall be allocated in kind in the following sequences and<br /><br />
percentages:<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
taxes.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5 percent of AGP shall be allocated to pay Chinese<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
The Chinese government shall receive a sliding<br /><br />
scale royalty, determined on a field by field basis, calculated<br /><br />
as follows (as amended by the Ministry and State Taxation Bureau,<br /><br />
effective January 1, 1995):<br /><br />
METRIC TONS OF ANNUAL<br /><br />
CRUDE OIL PRODUCTION<br /><br />
ROYALTY RATE<br /><br />
(One metric ton is roughly equivalent to seven<br /><br />
barrels of crude oil)<br /><br />
Up to and including 1,000,000..................<br /><br />
1,000,000 to 1,500,000 ........................<br /><br />
1,500,000 to 2,000,000 ........................<br /><br />
2,000,000 to 3,000,000 ........................<br /><br />
3,000,000 to 4,000,000 ........................<br /><br />
Over 4,000,000.................................<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Zero<br /><br />
4%<br /><br />
6%<br /><br />
8%<br /><br />
10%<br /><br />
12.5%<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
60% of AGP shall be deemed "cost recovery oil" and<br /><br />
used for cost recovery, first of operating costs, and second for<br /><br />
exploration and development costs (including deemed interest).<br /><br />
Cost recovery oil shall not be reduced by any royalty due the<br /><br />
Chinese government.<br /><br />
(4)<br /><br />
After recovery of operating, exploration, and<br /><br />
development costs (including deemed interest), the remainder of<br /><br />
AGP shall be considered "remainder oil," which shall then be<br /><br />
further divided into "allocable remainder oil" and "Chinese share<br /><br />
oil." Allocable remainder oil shall be calculated for each field,<br /><br />
based upon a sliding scale formula applied to each such field's<br /><br />
annual production, and shall be shared by the parties in<br /><br />
proportion to their respective interests under the Contract. All<br /><br />
oil remaining after the above allocations shall be designated<br /><br />
Chinese share oil and allocated to CNODC or other Chinese<br /><br />
government designee.<br /><br />
Administration of the Contract; Arbitration<br /><br />
<br /><br />
- ------------------------------------------The Contract is administered by the JMC, consisting of an<br /><br />
equal number of representatives designated by CNODC and by the<br /><br />
Foreign Contractor. Disputes must be resolved, first through<br /><br />
negotiation, and then arbitration (though CNODC may have the<br /><br />
right to seek resolution in Chinese courts). CNODC has not waived<br /><br />
sovereign immunity in any proceedings commenced in China.<br /><br />
If accepted by the parties, arbitration will be conducted by<br /><br />
the China International Economic and Trade Commission under its<br /><br />
provisional rules. If that is not accepted by the parties,<br /><br />
disputes may be arbitrated by a panel of three arbitrators, each<br /><br />
party to appoint one and the third appointed by the two thus<br /><br />
chosen or, failing such appointment, by the Arbitration Institute<br /><br />
of the Stockholm (Sweden) Chamber of Commerce. Arbitration shall<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
conducted<br /><br />
under the rules of the UN<br /><br />
Commission<br /><br />
on<br /><br />
International Trade Law of 1976 (subject however to such rules as<br /><br />
expressly provided in the Contract). Awards shall be final and<br /><br />
binding on the parties. The Contract is governed by Chinese law.<br /><br />
Apache Farmout<br /><br />
- -------------In March 1994, by means of a participation agreement<br /><br />
("Participation Agreement"), the Company farmed out a one-third<br /><br />
interest in the Foreign Contractor's interest in the Zhao Dong<br /><br />
Block to Apache in exchange for certain cash payments and<br /><br />
Apache's agreement to assume its pro rata share of expenditures<br /><br />
and liabilities with respect to exploration and development.<br /><br />
As<br /><br />
required by the Participation Agreement, in June 1994, Apache and<br /><br />
the Company entered into a Joint Operating Agreement (the<br /><br />
"Operating<br /><br />
Agreement').<br /><br />
To further reduce<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
exploration capital requirements and accelerate the development<br /><br />
of the Zhao Dong Block, the Company and Apache entered into an<br /><br />
agreement on May 10, 1995 (the "Second Participation Agreement")<br /><br />
pursuant to which Apache increased its interest in the Contract<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
50%<br /><br />
of the Foreign Contractor's interest and assumed<br /><br />
operatorship, obligating itself to pay 100% of the costs of<br /><br />
drilling and testing four exploratory wells (the "Carried Wells")<br /><br />
on the Zhao Dong Block. The drilling and testing of the C-3, D1, D-2 and F-1 wells will satisfy the obligations regarding the<br /><br />
four Carried Wells. All of these wells have been drilled and<br /><br />
tested with the exception of the F-1 Well, drilling operations on<br /><br />
which have been abandoned. The Company does not believe that such<br /><br />
operations on the F-1 Well to date satisfy Apache's obligations<br /><br />
to deliver a fourth Carried Well. The amounts advanced by Apache<br /><br />
for the Company's share of the Carried Wells are recoverable from<br /><br />
a portion of the Company's share of cost recovery revenues from<br /><br />
the Zhao Dong Block. In addition, Apache obligated itself to pay<br /><br />
the Company 16.667% of the value of the recoverable proved<br /><br />
reserves attributable to the portion of the Zhao Dong Block<br /><br />
delineated by the drilling of the C-1 and C-2 and C-3 wells, the<br /><br />
combined area designated in the agreement as the "C Field," all<br /><br />
as<br /><br />
agreed<br /><br />
to by the Company and Apache in the<br /><br />
Second<br /><br />
Participation Agreement. Payment for this purchase will be<br /><br />
computed in accordance with evaluation methodology as set forth<br /><br />
in the Second Participation Agreement and made to the Company<br /><br />
from time to time as each segment of the field is placed on<br /><br />
production.<br /><br />
In consideration of the above described payments, Apache<br /><br />
assumed operatorship of the Zhao Dong Block and increased its<br /><br />
interest from 33.33% to 50% of the Foreign Contractor's share.<br /><br />
All future exploration expenditures in excess of the Carried<br /><br />
Wells will be borne 50% each by the Company and Apache.<br /><br />
Under<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Operating Agreement, approval of a successor operator<br /><br />
requires<br /><br />
the vote of not less than 55% of the<br /><br />
Foreign<br /><br />
Contractor's interest; if the operator reduces its participating<br /><br />
interest to less than 25%, a committee established under the<br /><br />
Operating Agreement comprised of Apache and XCL (the "Operating<br /><br />
Committee") shall vote on whether a successor operator should be<br /><br />
named.<br /><br />
The appointment of a successor or replacement operator<br /><br />
requires government approval. CNODC has the right to become<br /><br />
operator<br /><br />
of production operations in certain circumstances<br /><br />
described in the Contract.<br /><br />
All work under the Contract must be pursuant to a work<br /><br />
program and budget approved by the JMC. Each year, the Operating<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Committee must submit a proposed work program and budget to the<br /><br />
JMC.<br /><br />
Operating Committee approval of this work program and<br /><br />
budget requires the vote of not less than 55% of the Foreign<br /><br />
Contractor's interest.<br /><br />
If 55% of the Foreign Contractor's<br /><br />
interest does not vote in favor of a proposed work program and<br /><br />
budget, the operator must submit the minimum work program and<br /><br />
budget necessary to meet the contractual obligations of the<br /><br />
Foreign Contractor under the Contract.<br /><br />
Under<br /><br />
the Participation Agreement and the Operating<br /><br />
Agreement, Apache and the Company each has a right of first<br /><br />
refusal with respect to any sale or transfer of interest in the<br /><br />
Foreign Contractor's share of the Contract. In addition, under<br /><br />
the Participation Agreement Apache and the Company each has a<br /><br />
right of first refusal with respect to the sale of 50% or more of<br /><br />
outstanding voting capital stock of their respective subsidiaries<br /><br />
party to the Contract and the Participation Agreement. In<br /><br />
addition, each party has the option to purchase the other party's<br /><br />
interest in the Contract upon the occurrence of certain "option<br /><br />
events." Option events include the failure more than twice in one<br /><br />
year to pay sums due under the Operating Agreement, after<br /><br />
receiving written notice of default and failing to cure within<br /><br />
any applicable cure period provided by the Operating Agreement<br /><br />
(if nonpayment is the subject of dispute and arbitration under<br /><br />
the Operating Agreement, it does not constitute a "failure to<br /><br />
pay"<br /><br />
until an arbitral decision is rendered against<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
nonpayor), the inability of a party to pay its debts as they fall<br /><br />
due or a final unappealable order by a court of competent<br /><br />
jurisdiction liquidating the party or appointing a receiver to<br /><br />
take possession of all of the party's assets, the transfer of<br /><br />
more than 49% of the voting shares of the Apache subsidiary<br /><br />
holding Apache's interest in the Zhao Dong Block or XCL-China<br /><br />
Ltd. ("XCL-China"), the XCL subsidiary holding XCL's interest in<br /><br />
the Zhao Dong Block, by their respective parents, or certain<br /><br />
other defaults under the Operating Agreement or the Contract.<br /><br />
The consideration to be paid on the exercise of the option to<br /><br />
purchase is the fair market value of the interest assigned.<br /><br />
If<br /><br />
the parties cannot agree on the fair market value of the<br /><br />
interest, it is to be determined by arbitration.<br /><br />
This option<br /><br />
runs only to the benefit of Apache and XCL-China and may not be<br /><br />
transferred by either of them to any third party.<br /><br />
United/XCL Lube Oil Joint Venture<br /><br />
- --------------------------------On<br /><br />
<br /><br />
July 17, 1995, the Company signed a contract with CNPC<br /><br />
United Lube Oil Corporation to form a joint venture company to<br /><br />
engage in the manufacturing, distribution and marketing of<br /><br />
lubricating oil in China and southeast Asian markets. The joint<br /><br />
venture has a 30-year life unless extended.<br /><br />
The registered<br /><br />
capital of the joint venture is $4.9 million, with the Company to<br /><br />
contribute<br /><br />
$2.4 million for its 49% interest,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
last<br /><br />
installment of which was paid in late 1997. As its investment<br /><br />
for 51% of the stock, the Chinese contributed an existing<br /><br />
lubricating oil blending plant in Langfang, China, with a Chinese<br /><br />
government appraised value of $2.5 million. The registration of<br /><br />
the joint venture was approved by Chinese authorities and the<br /><br />
effective date of the joint venture is January 1, 1998. In a<br /><br />
letter of intent executed contemporaneously with the contract,<br /><br />
the parties have agreed to consider the feasibility of (i)<br /><br />
contributing to the joint venture a second existing plant in<br /><br />
southwest China and (ii) other projects, including constructing<br /><br />
oil terminals on the north and south coasts of China and engaging<br /><br />
in upgrading certain existing refineries within China.<br /><br />
The Langfang plant is located 50 km southeast of Beijing.<br /><br />
The facility is built on a 10-acre site and has been evaluated on<br /><br />
the basis of U.S. Gulf Coast costs at a replacement value of $7.0<br /><br />
million, without taking into account the land value. The plant<br /><br />
currently produces and markets approximately 5,000 metric tons of<br /><br />
lube oil per year. Approximately $1.5 million of the Company's<br /><br />
investment has been allocated to the physical upgrading of the<br /><br />
facility, including the installation of automated filling lines<br /><br />
and packaging systems. Upon completion of the upgrading, the<br /><br />
plant's production capacity will be approximately 20,000 metric<br /><br />
tons per year, assuming one eight hour shift, five days per week.<br /><br />
Additional capacity will be available by adding shifts and<br /><br />
expanding the work week. Further capital improvements estimated<br /><br />
to cost $15 million could increase capacity to approximately<br /><br />
<br /><br />
100,000 metric tons per year.<br /><br />
It is the Company's opinion that an essential element to the<br /><br />
success of the lube oil business in China will be the ability to<br /><br />
distribute the product. In order to assure adequate distribution<br /><br />
of the joint venture's products, the Company has entered into a<br /><br />
memorandum of understanding with the Coal Ministry in China which<br /><br />
is expected to be reduced to a formal distribution contract. The<br /><br />
Coal Ministry operates 125 major integrated distribution centers<br /><br />
throughout China and the Company expects to market the joint<br /><br />
venture's products through this system.<br /><br />
Coalbed Methane Project<br /><br />
- ----------------------On March 31, 1995, the Company signed an agreement with the<br /><br />
CNACG, pursuant to which the parties will commence cooperation<br /><br />
for the exploration and development of coalbed methane in two<br /><br />
areas in China.<br /><br />
During the study period contemplated by the<br /><br />
agreement, the Company will evaluate the properties, after which<br /><br />
the parties are expected to enter into a comprehensive agreement<br /><br />
as to the specifically designated areas, which may provide the<br /><br />
basis for coalbed methane development in other areas of China.<br /><br />
On December 14, 1995, the Company signed a Memo of Understanding<br /><br />
with CNACG to develop a contract for exploration, development and<br /><br />
utilization of coalbed methane in the two areas. The March 31,<br /><br />
1995 agreement expired by its terms on December 31, 1996;<br /><br />
however, the Company has been informally advised that CNACG will<br /><br />
extend the term of the agreement.<br /><br />
Zhang Dong Block<br /><br />
- ---------------On August 20, 1998, XCL (through its subsidiary XCL-Cathay<br /><br />
Ltd.) signed a production sharing contract with CNODC for the<br /><br />
12,000-acre Zhang Dong Block. On September 15, 1998, the contract<br /><br />
was approved by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic<br /><br />
Cooperation of China, effective October 1, 1998. The Zhang Dong<br /><br />
Block is located North and adjacent to the Zhao Dong Block in the<br /><br />
offshore area of Bohai Bay. Dagang Petroleum (the subsidiary of<br /><br />
CNPC that operates onshore fields in this area) has drilled and<br /><br />
tested nine wells in the offshore block. All but one of these<br /><br />
wells have been drilled from an artificial island or a causeway<br /><br />
extending into the bay. All nine wells were tested with five<br /><br />
having commercial oil production rates, one well with gas<br /><br />
production, two wells with low oil production rates and one well<br /><br />
which<br /><br />
produced water.<br /><br />
The Company's review of production<br /><br />
information suggests that the wells were drilled with mud weights<br /><br />
that were considerably higher than necessary, which damaged the<br /><br />
producing formation and restricted the flow rates.<br /><br />
Under the<br /><br />
contract, the Company is required in the next year at its expense<br /><br />
to drill one well, upgrade both the island and the causeway and<br /><br />
reprocess and reinterpret certain seismic data. If the Company<br /><br />
elects to extend the appraisal phase of the contract beyond the<br /><br />
first year, it may do so by committing to an additional two wells<br /><br />
during each of the next two-year periods (for a total commitment<br /><br />
of five wells over a five-year period). Development costs and<br /><br />
production will be shared 49% by the Company and 51% by CNODC.<br /><br />
XCL is designated as the operator.<br /><br />
Domestic Properties<br /><br />
- ------------------U.S. Exploration and Production Activities. The Company has<br /><br />
sold substantially all of its U.S. producing properties except<br /><br />
for an interest in the Berry R. Cox Field (the "Cox Field") in<br /><br />
South Texas and is seeking to sell or joint venture its interest.<br /><br />
The Company holds a 60% to 100% working interest in 1,265 acres<br /><br />
in this field on which there are currently four producing wells<br /><br />
(3.45 net wells). The Company's 1997, 1996 and 1995 annual net<br /><br />
sales of natural gas from the Company's interest in the Cox Field<br /><br />
was 72,200, 467,000 and 522,000 Mcf, respectively on a sale<br /><br />
basis.<br /><br />
The December 1997, 1996 and 1995 gas price for the<br /><br />
Company's remaining domestic properties was $2.28, $1.84 and<br /><br />
$1.33 per Mcf, respectively.<br /><br />
During 1996, litigation<br /><br />
was<br /><br />
instituted against the Company in connection with the Cox Field<br /><br />
which has effectively impeded the Company's ability to consummate<br /><br />
a sale of such property. Upon resolution of the litigation, the<br /><br />
Company will continue its efforts to divest itself of these<br /><br />
<br /><br />
properties.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
See "-- Litigation" below.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Lutcher Moore Tract. The Company holds, in partnership with<br /><br />
one of its subsidiaries, a fee interest in a 62,500 acre<br /><br />
undeveloped tract of Louisiana fee property located in Ascension,<br /><br />
St. James and St. John the Baptist Parishes, Louisiana (the<br /><br />
"Lutcher Moore Tract"). Expressions of interest to purchase the<br /><br />
property have been received from several parties.<br /><br />
The Company<br /><br />
is also evaluating the possibility of developing the property<br /><br />
into a source of wetland mitigation credits. In connection with<br /><br />
the acquisition of the Lutcher Moore Tract, the Company's indirect<br /><br />
ownership of such tract is subject to a first mortgage, with a<br /><br />
current principal balance of approximately $1.5 million, and a<br /><br />
number of sellers' notes, with an aggregate current principal<br /><br />
balance of approximately $0.5 million (collectively, the "Lutcher<br /><br />
Moore Debt"). Recourse by the holder of the first mortgage and<br /><br />
the holders of the sellers' notes is limited to the Lutcher Moore<br /><br />
Tract,<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
neither<br /><br />
the Company<br /><br />
nor<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
wholly-owned<br /><br />
subsidiaries, XCL-Land Ltd. and The Exploration Company of<br /><br />
Louisiana, Inc., liable for the debt.<br /><br />
Oil and Gas Reserves<br /><br />
- --------------------Based on the report of Gruy, the Company's independent<br /><br />
engineering firm, net proved reserves in the C-D Field are<br /><br />
estimated to be 11.76 million barrels as of January 1, 1998.<br /><br />
CNODC has exercised its option to pay 51% of all development<br /><br />
costs and receive 51% of oil production. Consequently, the<br /><br />
Company's present value of estimated future pre-tax net cash<br /><br />
flows is approximately $64.8 million. The standarized measure of<br /><br />
discounted future net cash flows determined in accordance with<br /><br />
the rules prescribed by FASB No. 69 is $53.8 million. Future<br /><br />
reserve values are based on year end prices and operating costs,<br /><br />
production and future development costs based on current costs<br /><br />
with no escalation. See "Risk Factors -- Reliance on Estimates<br /><br />
of Proved Reserves and Future Net Revenue" and "Supplemental Oil<br /><br />
and Gas Information" in the Notes to the Consolidated Financial<br /><br />
Statements.<br /><br />
Gruy has been preparing reserve estimates for the Company's<br /><br />
oil and gas reserves since August 1996. Gruy was selected by the<br /><br />
Company for this task based upon its reputation, experience and<br /><br />
expertise in this area.<br /><br />
Gruy is an international petroleum<br /><br />
consulting firm with offices in Houston and Dallas, Texas. Their<br /><br />
staff includes petroleum engineers and geologic consultants.<br /><br />
Services they provide include reserve estimates, fair value<br /><br />
appraisals, geologic studies, expert witness testimony<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
arbitration. In 1997 the Company paid Gruy approximately $68,400<br /><br />
in fees for reserve report valuations and other services.<br /><br />
No<br /><br />
instructions were given and no limitations were imposed by the<br /><br />
Company on the scope of or methodology to be used in preparing<br /><br />
the reserve estimates.<br /><br />
Offices<br /><br />
- ------On March 31, 1997, the Company sold its office building<br /><br />
located at 110 Rue Jean Lafitte, Lafayette, Louisiana for<br /><br />
$900,000. On the same day, the Company entered into a lease with<br /><br />
the purchaser for one floor (approximately 9,500 square feet) of<br /><br />
the two-story building for a term of 22 months with an option to<br /><br />
extend for an additional eight-month period, at a monthly rental<br /><br />
of $7,500 for the first 21 months and $6,039 for the last month<br /><br />
(which is offset against mortgage payments due from the new owner<br /><br />
of the building).<br /><br />
The outstanding balance of the underlying<br /><br />
mortgage was repaid in full upon the sale of the building. In<br /><br />
March 1998, the Company entered into a lease for approximately<br /><br />
3,400 square feet of office space located at 5487 San Felipe,<br /><br />
Suite 2110 in Houston, Texas. The lease expires December 31,<br /><br />
2000 and has a monthly rental of $5,166. On July 15, 1998, the<br /><br />
Company entered into a lease for approximately 1,649 square feet<br /><br />
of office space located at No. 1013, Office Tower 1, 138 Wang Fu<br /><br />
Jing Da Jie, Beijing, China. The lease expires July 15, 2000<br /><br />
(with an option to extend for an additional two years) and has a<br /><br />
monthly rental of $3,297 (payable in Chinese Renminbi).<br /><br />
Litigation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
- ---------During December 1993, the Company and two of its whollyowned subsidiaries, XCL-Texas, Inc. and XCL Acquisitions, Inc.,<br /><br />
were<br /><br />
sued<br /><br />
in separate lawsuits entitled Ralph Slaughter,<br /><br />
Secretary of the Department of Revenue and Taxation, State of<br /><br />
Louisiana versus The Exploration Company of Louisiana, Inc. (15th<br /><br />
Judicial District, Parish of Lafayette, Louisiana, Docket No. 935449); Ralph Slaughter, Secretary of the Department of Revenue<br /><br />
and Taxation, State of Louisiana versus XCL-Texas, Incorporated<br /><br />
(15th Judicial District, Parish of Lafayette, Louisiana, Docket<br /><br />
No. 93-5450); and Ralph Slaughter, Secretary, Department of<br /><br />
Revenue and Taxation vs. XCL Acquisitions, Inc. (15th Judicial<br /><br />
District, Parish of Lafayette, Louisiana, Docket No. 93-5337) by<br /><br />
the Louisiana Department of Revenue for Louisiana State corporate<br /><br />
franchise and income taxes for the 1987 through 1991 fiscal years<br /><br />
in an aggregate amount (including penalties and interest through<br /><br />
September 1, 1993) of approximately $2.2 million.<br /><br />
Statutory<br /><br />
interest at the rate of 15% per annum on the principal will<br /><br />
continue to accrue from September 1, 1993 until paid. The<br /><br />
Louisiana Department of Revenue has also assessed additional<br /><br />
Louisiana State franchise tax against the Company and/or XCL<br /><br />
Acquisitions, Inc. for the tax years 1991 through 1996 and<br /><br />
additional income tax against XCL Acquisitions, Inc. for the tax<br /><br />
years 1991 and 1995 on the same basis as those set forth in the<br /><br />
lawsuits.<br /><br />
The Company protested the assessments and small<br /><br />
adjustments were made by the Department of Revenue.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
additional income tax assessment for the 1991 and 1995 tax years<br /><br />
is $89,688 and the additional franchise tax assessment for the<br /><br />
tax years 1991 through 1996 totals $1.6 million plus statutory<br /><br />
interest of 15% per annum from the due date until paid and<br /><br />
penalties not to exceed 25% of the total tax due. The Company<br /><br />
believes that these assessments have been adequately provided for<br /><br />
in the consolidated financial statements. The Company has filed<br /><br />
answers to each of these suits and intends to defend them<br /><br />
vigorously. The Company intends to continue to protest the<br /><br />
assessments. The Company believes that it has<br /><br />
meritorious<br /><br />
defenses and has instructed its counsel to contest these claims.<br /><br />
On<br /><br />
<br /><br />
July 26, 1996, three lawsuits were filed against XCLTexas, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, entitled<br /><br />
Stroman Ranch Company Ltd., el al. v. XCL-Texas, Inc. (229th<br /><br />
Judicial District, Jim Hogg County, Texas, Cause No. 4550), Frank<br /><br />
Armstrong, et al. v. XCL-Texas, Inc. (229th Judicial District,<br /><br />
Jim Hogg County, Texas, Cause No. 4551), and Stroman Ranch<br /><br />
Company Ltd., et al. v. XCL-Texas, Inc. (229th Judicial District,<br /><br />
Jim Hogg County, Texas, Cause No. 4552). The lawsuits allege<br /><br />
various claims, including a claim that one of the oil and gas<br /><br />
leases in the Berry R. Cox Field should be terminated. The<br /><br />
Company believes the claims made in the lawsuits are without<br /><br />
merit and intends to vigorously defend itself. The lawsuits have<br /><br />
prevented the Company from selling its interest in the Cox Field.<br /><br />
In July 1997, China Investment and Development Corporation<br /><br />
("CIDC"), holders of the Company's Series B Preferred Stock sued<br /><br />
the Company and each of its directors in an action entitled China<br /><br />
Investment and Development Corporation vs. XCL Ltd.; Marsden W.<br /><br />
Miller, Jr.; John T. Chandler; David A. Melman; Fred Hofheinz;<br /><br />
Arthur<br /><br />
W. Hummel, Jr.; Michael Palliser; and Francis<br /><br />
J.<br /><br />
Reinhardt, Jr. (Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware in and<br /><br />
for New Castle County, Civil Action No. 15783-NC).<br /><br />
The suit<br /><br />
alleged breach of (i) contract, (ii) corporate charter, (iii)<br /><br />
good faith and fair dealing and (iv) fiduciary duty with respect<br /><br />
to the alleged failure of the Company to redeem CIDC's Series B<br /><br />
Preferred shares for a claimed aggregate redemption price of<br /><br />
approximately $5.0 million. Effective December 31, 1997, the<br /><br />
Company and CIDC entered into an interim settlement agreement<br /><br />
pursuant to which the Company paid CIDC $1 million as a deposit<br /><br />
in anticipation of a final settlement and dismissal of the<br /><br />
lawsuit. On March 3, 1998, the final settlement took place and,<br /><br />
shortly thereafter, the deposit was returned to XCL. On March 9,<br /><br />
1998, the lawsuit was dismissed with prejudice.<br /><br />
On<br /><br />
<br /><br />
January 24, 1997, a subsidiary of the Company filed an<br /><br />
action<br /><br />
captioned L.M. Holding Associates, L.P. v. LaRoche<br /><br />
Chemicals, Inc. (23rd Judicial District Court, St. James Parish,<br /><br />
Louisiana, No. 24, 338, Section A). The lawsuit claims that<br /><br />
LaRoche failed to properly maintain its 8" brine line that runs<br /><br />
10 miles across the subsidiary's property in St. James Parish,<br /><br />
Louisiana, discharged brine from this line onto the subsidiary's<br /><br />
<br /><br />
property and no longer has the right to operate said line.<br /><br />
In<br /><br />
1998, the court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining LaRoche<br /><br />
from discharging brine onto the subsidiary's property<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
enjoining LaRoche from continued operation of the 8" brine line<br /><br />
without a scientific system for early detection of leaks and<br /><br />
without periodic monitoring of the line. The Company is seeking<br /><br />
damages and cancellation of LaRoche's right to operate the brine<br /><br />
line.<br /><br />
No trial date has been set. The Company intends to<br /><br />
vigorously prosecute the lawsuit.<br /><br />
Other than as disclosed above, as of the date hereof, there<br /><br />
are no material pending legal proceedings to which either the<br /><br />
Company or any of its subsidiaries is a party or to which any of<br /><br />
their properties are subject which would have a material adverse<br /><br />
effect on the business or properties of the Company, taken as a<br /><br />
whole.<br /><br />

Under Delaware law and the Bylaws, incumbent directors have<br /><br />

however occurring, whether by an increase in the number of<br /><br />
directors,<br /><br />
death, resignation, retirement, disqualification,<br /><br />
removal from office or otherwise. Any director elected by the<br /><br />
Board to fill a vacancy would hold office for the unexpired term<br /><br />
of the director whose place has been filled except that a<br /><br />
director elected to fill a newly-created directorship resulting<br /><br />
from an increase in the number of directors, whether elected by<br /><br />
the Board or shareholders, would hold office for the remainder of<br /><br />
the full term of the class of directors in which the new<br /><br />
directorship was created or the vacancy occurred and until his<br /><br />
successor is elected and qualified. If the size of the Board is<br /><br />

Biographical Information<br /><br />
- -----------------------MARSDEN W. MILLER, JR., Chairman, has been Chief Executive<br /><br />
Officer and a director since the Company's incorporation in 1981.<br /><br />
He has engaged in the independent domestic and international oil<br /><br />
business since 1964 on an individual basis, as a stockholder and<br /><br />
officer in several companies and as a practicing attorney.<br /><br />
In<br /><br />
addition to the U.S. and China, he has been involved in various<br /><br />
aspects of the oil business in Southeast Asia, Africa, Europe,<br /><br />
South America, several former Soviet Republics and Canada. Mr.<br /><br />
Miller graduated from Louisiana State University in 1964.<br /><br />
JOHN T. CHANDLER is Vice Chairman of the Board and Chairman<br /><br />
and Chief Executive Officer of XCL-China. He joined the Company<br /><br />
in June 1982, becoming a director in May 1983. From 1976 until<br /><br />
he joined the Company he was the Managing Partner of the Oil and<br /><br />
Gas Group of GSA Equity, Inc., New York and director of Executive<br /><br />
Monetary Management, Inc., the parent company of GSA Equity, Inc.<br /><br />
From 1972 to 1976, he was director and Vice President of<br /><br />
Exploration and Production of Westrans Petroleum, Inc. and a<br /><br />
director of a number of its subsidiaries. During 1971 and 1972,<br /><br />
he was a petroleum consultant and manager of the oil department<br /><br />
of Den norske Creditbank in Oslo, Norway. Mr. Chandler was Vice<br /><br />
President and Manager of the Petroleum Department of the Deposit<br /><br />
Guaranty National Bank in Jackson, Mississippi from 1969 to<br /><br />
August 1971 and, from 1967 to February 1969, was a petroleum<br /><br />
engineer first for First National City Bank (now known as<br /><br />
Citibank, N.A.) and then The Bank of New York. From March 1963 to<br /><br />
July 1967, he was employed by Ashland Oil and Refining Company as<br /><br />
a petroleum engineer.<br /><br />
From 1959 to 1963, he held the same<br /><br />
position with United Producing Company, Inc., which was acquired<br /><br />
by Ashland Oil.<br /><br />
Mr. Chandler graduated from the Colorado School of Mines<br /><br />
with a Professional degree in petroleum engineering and is a<br /><br />
Registered Professional Engineer in the States of Colorado and<br /><br />
Texas, a member of the Society of Petroleum Evaluation Engineers<br /><br />
and a member of AIME.<br /><br />
DANNY M. DOBBS is the President and Chief Operating Officer<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
the Company effective December 17, 1997.<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Dobbs<br /><br />
previously served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating<br /><br />
Officer of the Company and prior to that as Vice PresidentExploration of XCL Exploration &amp; Production, Inc., a wholly-owned<br /><br />
subsidiary of the Company, having joined the Company in 1985 as<br /><br />
Senior Exploration Geologist. From 1981 to 1985 Mr. Dobbs was a<br /><br />
consulting geologist. From 1976 to 1981, he held the position of<br /><br />
Exploration Geologist in the South Louisiana District for Edwin<br /><br />
L. Cox in Lafayette, Louisiana. He served in various geologic<br /><br />
positions with Texaco, Inc. from 1971 to 1976, his experience<br /><br />
encompassing management, structural and stratigraphic mapping,<br /><br />
coordination of seismic programs and budget evaluation and<br /><br />
preparation. Mr. Dobbs holds B.S. and M.S. degrees in geology<br /><br />
from the University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Alabama.<br /><br />
BENJAMIN B. BLANCHET is Executive Vice President and<br /><br />
director of the Company. Prior to joining the Company in August<br /><br />
1997, and since 1983, he was a partner in the law firm of Gordon,<br /><br />
Arata, McCollam &amp; Duplantis, L.L.P. in its Lafayette, Louisiana<br /><br />
office.<br /><br />
During that time, he practiced in the areas<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
commercial litigation, corporate mergers and acquisitions, oil<br /><br />
and gas transactions, secured financings, securities, tax and<br /><br />
international<br /><br />
law matters. Since 1985,<br /><br />
he<br /><br />
has<br /><br />
provided<br /><br />
substantial legal services to the Company, and has been the<br /><br />
Company's lead attorney in China. He served on the Management<br /><br />
Committee of Gordon, Arata, McCollam &amp; Duplantis, L.L.P. from<br /><br />
1991 to 1997 and as the Managing Partner of the firm for four<br /><br />
years from 1992 through 1995. He practiced law with the firm of<br /><br />
Monroe &amp; Lemann in New Orleans from 1978 through 1983. He is a<br /><br />
member of the Louisiana Bar and admitted to practice before the<br /><br />
United States Tax Court. Mr. Blanchet holds a B.A. degree, with<br /><br />
highest<br /><br />
distinction, from the University<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Southwestern<br /><br />
Louisiana and a J.D., cum laude, from Harvard Law School.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
RICHARD K. KENNEDY is Vice President of Engineering and<br /><br />
responsible for certain engineering aspects of the Company's oil<br /><br />
and gas operations. From 1987, until he joined the Company in<br /><br />
1989, he was an operations engineer for Wintershall Corporation.<br /><br />
From 1981 to 1986 he was with Borden Energy, originally as a<br /><br />
petroleum engineer and later as regional operations manager.<br /><br />
From 1979 to 1981, Mr. Kennedy was employed with Marathon Oil<br /><br />
Company as a reservoir engineer, then as a drilling engineer. He<br /><br />
was employed with Shell Oil Company as a petroleum engineer and<br /><br />
reservoir engineer from 1977 to 1979. Mr. Kennedy graduated from<br /><br />
Louisiana Tech University with a B.S. degree in petroleum<br /><br />
engineering.<br /><br />
He is a registered professional engineer in the<br /><br />
State of Louisiana and a member of the Society of Petroleum<br /><br />
Engineers.<br /><br />
R. CARTER CLINE is Vice President-Land, having joined the<br /><br />
Company in October 1990. He has over 20 years of exploration and<br /><br />
management experience. From 1982, until joining the Company, he<br /><br />
was employed by Pacific Enterprises Oil Company (USA), successor<br /><br />
by merger to Sabine Corporation, as East Gulf Coast Regional Land<br /><br />
Manager in Houston, Texas. From 1979 to 1982, he served as Vice<br /><br />
President-Land for Dynamic Exploration, Inc.<br /><br />
in Lafayette,<br /><br />
Louisiana.<br /><br />
From 1974 to 1979, he served as Region Landman in<br /><br />
Dallas and Division Land Manager in Houston, Texas, for Sabine<br /><br />
Corporation, and from 1971 to 1974 was employed by Getty Oil<br /><br />
Company in Houston, Texas and New Orleans, Louisiana. Mr. Cline<br /><br />
holds a B.B.A.<br /><br />
degree in Petroleum Land Management from the<br /><br />
University of Texas at Austin and is a Certified Petroleum<br /><br />
Landman.<br /><br />
HERBERT F. HAMILTON is Vice President Operations of XCLChina, having joined the Company in 1995. Mr. Hamilton has more<br /><br />
than 30 years of experience in the fields of engineering,<br /><br />
construction, construction management and consulting on heavy<br /><br />
civil<br /><br />
works,<br /><br />
offshore platforms, submarine pipelines<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
construction equipment in over 35 countries. From 1990 to 1993,<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Hamilton served as Senior Project Manager for Earl and<br /><br />
Wright in Houston, Texas. From 1993 to 1994, he served as<br /><br />
President and a consultant to Planterra, Inc. in Houston, Texas<br /><br />
and from 1994 until joining the Company he was an independent<br /><br />
consultant.<br /><br />
Mr. Hamilton is a Registered Professional Engineer<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
holds a B.S.<br /><br />
in Architectural Engineering from<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
University of Texas at Austin.<br /><br />
JOSEPH T. K. CHAN is Vice President of XCL-China LubeOil<br /><br />
Ltd., having joined the Company in 1998. Mr. Chan has more than<br /><br />
20 years experience in the oil industry with major American oil<br /><br />
companies. From August 1994 until joining the Company, Mr. Chan<br /><br />
was an agent and consultant for Asian importers of U.S. made<br /><br />
chemical, petrochemical and industrial products. From 1991 to<br /><br />
1994 he was Regional Manager of Sun Oil Far East, Inc. and Head<br /><br />
of Technical Support of China Sun Lubeoil joint venture plant in<br /><br />
Skekou, China and was responsible for regional sales, marketing<br /><br />
and production operations in Asia and the Pacific Rim under Sun<br /><br />
Oil Trading, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Sun Oil Corp.<br /><br />
From 1988 to 1990, Mr. Chan was Marketing Director to De Huns<br /><br />
International Ltd. with chemicals and garment manufacturing<br /><br />
investments and operations in China. From 1986 to 1988, he<br /><br />
served as General Manager of Sales &amp; Marketing and Technical<br /><br />
Services for U.K. based Castrol Oil Hong Kong. Mr. Chan served as<br /><br />
Divisional Import Manager for Li &amp; Fung Trading in Taiwan,<br /><br />
Marketing Director of CDW Manufacturing Group in Hong Kong and<br /><br />
Project Manager of Cha Chi Ming (China Investment) Ltd. from 1982<br /><br />
to 1986.<br /><br />
From 1976 to 1981, he served as Industrial Sales &amp;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Marketing Manager for Caltex Oil Hong Kong, a joint venture of<br /><br />
Chevron and Texaco in Asia. From 1975 to 1976 he was Senior<br /><br />
Sales<br /><br />
Engineer and Area Sales Manager for Drew<br /><br />
Chemical<br /><br />
Corporation. Mr. Chan was employed with Esso Standard Oil Hong<br /><br />
Kong as International Sales Supervisor from 1972 to 1975 and as a<br /><br />
Marine and Aviation Sales and Technical Representative from 1970<br /><br />
to 1972. Mr. Chan holds a Bachelor of Commercial Science degree<br /><br />
from CH University of Hong Kong and has completed the Masters<br /><br />
Study Program from Caltex Management Institute in Indonesia. Mr.<br /><br />
Chan<br /><br />
has also attended comprehensive training in<br /><br />
lubeoil<br /><br />
engineering from the Esso Research Center in Abington Oxford, and<br /><br />
leadership and refinery operations programs with Texaco and<br /><br />
Chevron.<br /><br />
JOHN H. HASLAM is Treasurer, having joined the Company in<br /><br />
1990.<br /><br />
From 1988 until joining the Company, he was employed by<br /><br />
United Gas Pipeline as Credit Manager. From 1986 to 1988, he<br /><br />
served as Director of Internal Audit for TransAmerican Natural<br /><br />
Gas Corporation. From 1981 to 1986 he was the Audit Manager for<br /><br />
ENSTAR Corporation. He was with Getty Oil from 1963 until 1981,<br /><br />
as Audit Manager of Joint Venture Operations and various other<br /><br />
accounting positions. Mr. Haslam holds a B.B.A.<br /><br />
degree in<br /><br />
Marketing from Baylor University.<br /><br />
LISHA FALK is Corporate Secretary, having joined the Company<br /><br />
in 1981. Since joining the Company Ms. Falk has served in various<br /><br />
administrative positions, most recently as Assistant Secretary.<br /><br />
R. THOMAS FETTERS, JR. is an independent oil and gas<br /><br />
consultant. He has over 25 years of exploration, production and<br /><br />
management experience, both domestic and foreign. From 1995 to<br /><br />
1997 Mr. Fetters was Senior Vice President of Exploration of<br /><br />
National Energy Group, Inc., Dallas, Texas, and from February<br /><br />
1990, until September 1995, he was Vice President of Exploration<br /><br />
of XCL Ltd., and President of XCL-China Ltd. During 1989, until<br /><br />
joining the Company, he served as Chairman and Chief Executive<br /><br />
Officer of Independent Energy Corporation. From 1984 to 1989, he<br /><br />
served as President and Chief Executive Officer of CNG Producing<br /><br />
Company in New Orleans, Louisiana, and from 1983 to 1984 as<br /><br />
General Manager of the Planning and Technology Division of<br /><br />
Consolidated Natural Gas Service Co. in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.<br /><br />
From 1966 to 1983, he served in various positions, from Geologist<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
Exploration Manager, with several divisions of<br /><br />
Exxon,<br /><br />
primarily<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
the Gulf Coast region<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
U.S.<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
internationally, in Malaysia and Australia. Mr. Fetters holds<br /><br />
B.S. and M.S. degrees in geology from the University<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Tennessee.<br /><br />
FRED HOFHEINZ is an attorney at law in Houston, Texas. From<br /><br />
1984<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
1987, he served as President of Energy<br /><br />
Assets<br /><br />
International Corporation, a fund management company, now a<br /><br />
subsidiary of Torch Energy Advisors, serving as a consultant to<br /><br />
Torch Energy Advisors until 1989. Mr. Hofheinz also served as the<br /><br />
Mayor of Houston, Texas from 1974 to 1978. He, along with his<br /><br />
family, developed the Astrodome in Houston, and owned the Houston<br /><br />
Astros baseball team until 1974. He is founder and director of<br /><br />
United Kiev Resources, Inc., an oil and gas production company<br /><br />
operating in the Republic of the Ukraine in the name of its<br /><br />
wholly-owned<br /><br />
subsidiary, Carpatsky Petroleum Company.<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Hofheinz earned a Ph.D. degree in Economics from the University<br /><br />
of Texas and his law degree from the University of Houston.<br /><br />
He<br /><br />
was appointed as a director by the Board at a meeting held March<br /><br />
21, 1991.<br /><br />
ARTHUR W. HUMMEL, JR., a director since April 1994, is the<br /><br />
former U.S. Ambassador to the People's Republic of China during<br /><br />
the period 1981 to 1985. Since his 1985 retirement from the<br /><br />
State Department, after 35 years of service, he has been active<br /><br />
in consulting with firms doing business in East Asia, and<br /><br />
participating in academic and scholarly conferences in the U.S.<br /><br />
and in the East Asia region. He is a member and trustee of many<br /><br />
academic, business, and philanthropic organizations involved in<br /><br />
international affairs.<br /><br />
Mr. Hummel was born in China. After education in the U.S.<br /><br />
he returned to China prior to Pearl Harbor. Interned by the<br /><br />
Japanese, he escaped and fought with Chinese guerrillas behind<br /><br />
the Japanese lines in north China until the end of the war.<br /><br />
He obtained an M.A. (Phi Beta Kappa) in Chinese studies from<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
University of Chicago in 1949, and joined the State<br /><br />
Department in 1950. His early foreign assignments include Hong<br /><br />
Kong, Japan and Burma. He was Deputy Director of the Voice of<br /><br />
America in 1961-1963; Deputy Chief of Mission of the American<br /><br />
Embassy in Taiwan, 1965-1968; Ambassador to Burma, 1968-1970;<br /><br />
Ambassador to Ethiopia, 1975-1976; Ambassador to Pakistan, 19771981; and Ambassador to the Peoples Republic of China, 1981-1985.<br /><br />
He was Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia 1976-1977. He<br /><br />
has received numerous professional awards from within and outside<br /><br />
the Government.<br /><br />
SIR MICHAEL PALLISER, a director since April 1994, was from<br /><br />
1984 to 1993 Chairman of Samuel Montagu &amp; Co. Limited, the London<br /><br />
merchant bank which was owned by Midland Bank, of which he was<br /><br />
Deputy Chairman from 1987 to 1991, and which is now part of the<br /><br />
Hong Kong &amp; Shanghai Banking Corporation. He was Vice Chairman<br /><br />
of Samuel Montagu from 1993 to 1996. He is a former Director of<br /><br />
BAT Industries, Bookers, Eagle Star, Shell and United Biscuits.<br /><br />
In 1947, he joined the British Diplomatic Service and served<br /><br />
in a variety of overseas and Foreign Office posts before becoming<br /><br />
head of the Planning Staff in 1964-1966, Private Secretary to the<br /><br />
Prime Minister, 1966-1969, Minister in the British Embassy in<br /><br />
Paris, 1969-1971, and the British Ambassador and Permanent<br /><br />
Representative to the European Communities in Brussels from 19711975.<br /><br />
He was, from 1975 until his retirement in 1982, Permanent<br /><br />
Under-Secretary of State in the Foreign and Commonwealth Office,<br /><br />
and Head of the Diplomatic Service. From April to July 1982, he<br /><br />
was a special adviser to the Prime Minister in the Cabinet Office<br /><br />
during the Falklands War. He was appointed a Member of the Privy<br /><br />
Council in 1983.<br /><br />
Effective December 31, 1995, Mr. Palliser<br /><br />
resigned as President of the China-Britain Trade Group and a<br /><br />
director of the UK-Japan 2000 Group, and effective February 29,<br /><br />
1996, he resigned as Deputy Chairman of British Invisibles.<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Palliser is a former member of the Trilateral Commission, a<br /><br />
director of the Royal National Theatre. He is currently Chairman<br /><br />
of the Major Projects Association, designed to assist in and for<br /><br />
the handling of major industrial projects. Mr. Palliser also<br /><br />
serves as Vice-Chairman of the Salzburg Seminar, a center for<br /><br />
intellectual exchange based in Middlebury, Vermont, with its<br /><br />
conference center in Salzburg, Austria.<br /><br />
Sir Michael Palliser was educated at Wellington College and<br /><br />
Merton College, Oxford. He saw wartime service in the British<br /><br />
Army with the Coldstream Guards.<br /><br />
FRANCIS J. REINHARDT, JR., is a partner in the New York<br /><br />
investment banking firm of Carl H. Pforzheimer &amp; Co.<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Reinhardt has been a partner in the firm for over 30 years and<br /><br />
has held various positions, specializing in independent oil and<br /><br />
gas<br /><br />
securities,<br /><br />
mergers<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
acquisitions,<br /><br />
placements<br /><br />
participation and institutional sales since 1956. Mr. Reinhardt<br /><br />
holds a B.S. degree from Seton Hall University and received his<br /><br />
M.B.A. from New York University. Mr. Reinhardt is a member of<br /><br />
the New York Society of Security Analysts, a member of and has<br /><br />
previously served as president of the Oil Analysts Group of New<br /><br />
York, a member and past president of the National Association of<br /><br />
Petroleum Investment Analysts and a member of the Petroleum<br /><br />
Exploration Society of New York. Mr. Reinhardt also serves as a<br /><br />
director of Mallon Resources Corporation, a Nasdaq<br /><br />
traded<br /><br />
petroleum and mining company, as well as several privately held<br /><br />
companies.<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Reinhardt was appointed as a director of the<br /><br />
Company at a Board meeting held December 11, 1992.<br /><br />
PETER F. ROSS, was appointed Chairman of Dawnay Day Capital<br /><br />
Markets in March 1998. Dawnay Day &amp; Co. is a London based<br /><br />
private investment banking firm. Mr. Ross retired as Chairman of<br /><br />
Henderson Crosthwaite Institutional Brokers on December 31, 1996,<br /><br />
after holding that position since 1987. Under Mr. Ross' term as<br /><br />
Chairman, Henderson Crosthwaite became one of the leading firms<br /><br />
in London in the area of oil and gas placements. From 1977 to<br /><br />
1986 he was head of Henderson Crosthwaite's institutional sales<br /><br />
department, with special responsibility for the oil and gas<br /><br />
division, until its acquisition by Guinness Mahon Bank in 1986.<br /><br />
Mr. Ross was commissioned into the British Army serving with<br /><br />
the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards, his last posting being<br /><br />
to Libya where he retired and set up an industrial services<br /><br />
business. Following the Islamic Revolution in 1971, he returned<br /><br />
to the United Kingdom and joined London stockbrokers Northcote &amp;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Co.<br /><br />
In 1974, he joined George Henderson &amp; Co., becoming<br /><br />
partner in 1975, upon the merger with Fenn and Crosthwaite.<br /><br />
Mr.<br /><br />
Ross was appointed as a director of the Company at a meeting of<br /><br />
the Board held April 7, 1998.<br /><br />
