<br /><br />
Stock Options<br /><br />
- ------------The Company currently maintains one stock option plan which<br /><br />
was adopted by shareholders in 1992 and was amended and restated<br /><br />
in 1997. The plan is administered by the Compensation Committee<br /><br />
and provides for the granting of options to purchase shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock to key employees and directors of the Company, and<br /><br />
certain other persons who are not employees of the Company but<br /><br />
who from time to time provide substantial advice or other<br /><br />
assistance or services to the Company.<br /><br />
On June 2, 1992, shareholders approved the Long-Term Stock<br /><br />
Incentive Plan ("1992 LTSIP"). The 1992 LTSIP was adopted with<br /><br />
the view of conforming the Company's prior plans to certain<br /><br />
regulatory changes adopted by the Commission and affording<br /><br />
holders of previously granted options the opportunity to exchange<br /><br />
their options for equivalent options under the 1992 LTSIP.<br /><br />
By<br /><br />
action of the Board of Directors, effective June 1, 1997, the<br /><br />
1992 LTSIP was amended and restated, and certain awards were<br /><br />
granted thereunder, all subject to approval by shareholders which<br /><br />
was secured at the Company's Special Meeting in Lieu of Annual<br /><br />
Meeting of Shareholders held on December 17, 1997.<br /><br />
1997 LTSIP Restatement<br /><br />
---------------------Nature of Awards.<br /><br />
The 1997 LTSIP Restatement makes<br /><br />
available to the Compensation Committee the power to grant<br /><br />
certain awards ("Awards") to acquire shares of the Company's<br /><br />
Preferred Stock as well as shares of Common Stock.<br /><br />
In common<br /><br />
with the 1992 LTSIP, the 1997 LTSIP Restatement makes available<br /><br />
to the Compensation Committee a number of incentive devices in<br /><br />
addition to Incentive Stock Options ("ISOs") (which are not<br /><br />
available with respect to Preferred Stock) and Nonqualified Stock<br /><br />
Options ("NSOs"), including reload options ("ROs") (which are not<br /><br />
available with respect to Preferred Stock), restricted stock<br /><br />
awards ("RSAs"), and performance units ("PUs") or appreciation<br /><br />
options ("AOs") (which were not authorized under the 1992 LTSIP),<br /><br />
each<br /><br />
of which is described below and in the 1997 LTSIP<br /><br />
Restatement. NSOs to acquire Preferred Stock, a new feature, may<br /><br />
include an accrued dividend feature. The Board believes that<br /><br />
these award alternatives will enable the Committee to tailor the<br /><br />
type of compensation to be granted to key personnel to meet both<br /><br />
the Company's and such employee's requirements in the most<br /><br />
efficient manner possible.<br /><br />
Number of Awards.<br /><br />
For Common Stock Awards, the 1997<br /><br />
LTSIP Restatement authorizes an aggregate of 4 million shares (as<br /><br />
adjusted for the Reverse Stock Split) of Common Stock for<br /><br />
issuance pursuant to awards granted thereunder, including grants<br /><br />
to non-employee directors. For Preferred Stock Awards, the 1997<br /><br />
LTSIP Restatement authorizes an aggregate of 200,000 shares of<br /><br />
the Company's Amended Series A Preferred Stock, or any other<br /><br />
series of Preferred Stock of the Company as designated by the<br /><br />
Committee with respect to an Award.<br /><br />
Description of Awards. As set forth above, and like the<br /><br />
1992<br /><br />
LTSIP,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
1997 LTSIP Restatement<br /><br />
authorizes<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Compensation Committee to grant NSOs, ISOs, ROs (i.e., the<br /><br />
granting of additional options, where an employee exercises an<br /><br />
option with previously owned stock, covering the number of shares<br /><br />
tendered as part of the exercise price), RSAs (i.e., stock<br /><br />
awarded to an employee, subject to forfeiture in the event of a<br /><br />
premature termination of employment, failure of the Company to<br /><br />
meet certain performance objectives or other conditions), PUs<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(i.e., share-denominated units credited to the employee's account<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
delivery or cash-out at some future date based upon<br /><br />
performance<br /><br />
criteria to be determined by the Compensation<br /><br />
Committee), and "tax-withholding" (i.e., where the employee has<br /><br />
the option of having the Company withhold shares on exercise of<br /><br />
an award to satisfy tax withholding requirements). AOs (i.e.,<br /><br />
awards in which payments are based upon appreciation in shares or<br /><br />
other criteria determined by the Compensation Committee) are a<br /><br />
new<br /><br />
feature added to the 1992 LTSIP by the 1997<br /><br />
LTSIP<br /><br />
Restatement.<br /><br />
Outside Director Awards. The 1997 LTSIP Restatement also<br /><br />
authorizes the Board to grant Awards to non-employee directors<br /><br />
and to set the terms and conditions of such Awards, without the<br /><br />
restrictions previously set forth in the 1992 LTSIP which were<br /><br />
required by certain federal securities law rules since abolished.<br /><br />
Administration of Plan. In keeping with the provisions of<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
1992<br /><br />
LTSIP, the Compensation Committee will<br /><br />
develop<br /><br />
administration guidelines from time to time which will define<br /><br />
specific eligibility criteria, the types of awards to<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
employed, whether such awards relate to Common Stock or Preferred<br /><br />
Stock, and the value of such awards. Specific terms of each<br /><br />
Award will be provided in individual Award agreements granted<br /><br />
each Award recipient. Key employees and other individuals who in<br /><br />
the judgment of the Committee may provide a valuable contribution<br /><br />
to the success of the Company and its affiliates will be<br /><br />
eligible.<br /><br />
The Committee may establish different general Award<br /><br />
eligibility criteria for Awards involving Preferred Stock which<br /><br />
may require a higher level of management responsibility and<br /><br />
authority.<br /><br />
Change in Control Provisions. The 1997 LTSIP Restatement<br /><br />
contains change-in-control provisions which provide that the<br /><br />
threshold for determining if a "change in control of XCL" has<br /><br />
occurred as a result of a person or entity acquiring Company<br /><br />
stock has been lowered from 30% to 20% (disregarding the<br /><br />
acquisition of such stock by certain shareholders of<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company).<br /><br />
The 1997 LTSIP Restatement retains the 1992 LTSIP's<br /><br />
provisions pursuant to which a "change in control of XCL" will be<br /><br />
deemed to occur as a result of certain contested Board of<br /><br />
Director elections.<br /><br />
If a "change in control of XCL" occurs<br /><br />
pursuant to the provisions described above, ISOs and NSOs then<br /><br />
outstanding will become exercisable in full, the forfeiture<br /><br />
restrictions on any RSAs to the extent then applicable will lapse<br /><br />
and amounts payable with respect to PUs and AOs then outstanding<br /><br />
will become payable in full. Also, under certain Awards<br /><br />
made<br /><br />
under the 1997 LTSIP Restatement (see discussion below) the<br /><br />
occurrence of a "change in control of XCL" could obligate the<br /><br />
Company with respect to making payments with respect to Awards in<br /><br />
cash rather than in kind, or in obligating the Company to<br /><br />
repurchase individuals' shares of Common Stock or Preferred Stock<br /><br />
received under certain 1997 LTSIP Restatement Awards.<br /><br />
Under<br /><br />
certain circumstances which are unforeseen at this time, the<br /><br />
existence of the change in control protections for individuals<br /><br />
receiving Awards under the 1997 LTSIP Restatement and resulting<br /><br />
obligations to the Company may impede the consummation of a<br /><br />
change in control of the Company.<br /><br />
Option Exercise Price. Under the 1997 LTSIP Restatement,<br /><br />
the Compensation Committee shall determine the option price of<br /><br />
all NSOs and ISOs; provided, however, in the case of ISOs, the<br /><br />
option price shall not be less than the fair market value of the<br /><br />
Common Stock on the date of grant. Such "fair market value" is<br /><br />
the average of the high and low prices of a share of Common or<br /><br />
Preferred Stock traded on the relevant date, as reported on the<br /><br />
Exchange, or other national securities exchange, or an automated<br /><br />
quotation system, or pursuant to a good faith determination by<br /><br />
the Board of Directors, if not so traded in a public market.<br /><br />
The 1997 LTSIP Restatement does not extend the term of the<br /><br />
1992 LTSIP and, therefore, the 1997 LTSIP Restatement will<br /><br />
terminate (and no further awards thereunder will be granted<br /><br />
after) June 2, 2002. In view of the fact that there is no public<br /><br />
market for the Amended Series A Preferred Stock, the fair market<br /><br />
value of the Amended Series A Preferred Stock on November 10,<br /><br />
1997, determined in good faith by the Board of Directors based<br /><br />
upon the last bid price of the Amended Series A Preferred Stock<br /><br />
in the PORTAL Market, as reported to the Company by Jefferies,<br /><br />
was $80.00 per share.<br /><br />

(1)<br /><br />
The Appreciation Option Agreement provides Mr. Miller<br /><br />
with the right, upon his payment of the Exercise Price (as<br /><br />
defined below), to additional compensation (payable in cash or in<br /><br />
shares of Common Stock or Preferred Stock or a combination<br /><br />
thereof, as elected by the Company) based upon 5% of the<br /><br />
difference between the market capitalization of the Company as of<br /><br />
June 1, 1997 and the market capitalization of the Company as of<br /><br />
the date that Mr. Miller exercises the Appreciation Option. For<br /><br />
purposes of the Appreciation Option, the Company's<br /><br />
market<br /><br />
capitalization is the total fair market value of the Company's<br /><br />
outstanding<br /><br />
shares of Common Stock, Preferred<br /><br />
Stock<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
outstanding options and warrants. In general, fair market value<br /><br />
is determined based on the trading price of marketable securities<br /><br />
and by the Board of Directors as to the fair market value for<br /><br />
securities for which there is no ready market. Fair market value<br /><br />
as of the date of exercise of the Option is based on the average<br /><br />
fair market value of the 30-day period immediately preceding the<br /><br />
date of the Appreciation Option exercise. On June 1, 1997 and<br /><br />
December 31, 1997, the aggregate market capitalization of the<br /><br />
Company was $161,547,223 and $177,572,416, respectively.<br /><br />
Upon<br /><br />
exercise of his Option, in the event the Company elects to settle<br /><br />
the Option with shares of Stock, Mr. Miller must pay the Company<br /><br />
twenty percent (20%) of the amount he is entitled to receive upon<br /><br />
exercise of the Appreciation Option (before any reduction as<br /><br />
hereinafter set forth), or any increment thereof, up to an<br /><br />
aggregate maximum of $5 million (the "Exercise Price") in cash.<br /><br />
In the event the Company elects to settle the Option in cash, the<br /><br />
amount of cash Mr. Miller will receive will be reduced by the<br /><br />
amount of the Exercise Price. Because Mr. Miller's Appreciation<br /><br />
Option contemplates compensation determined with reference to<br /><br />
increases<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
the Company's market capitalization<br /><br />
without<br /><br />
restriction, there is no effective limit on the amount of<br /><br />
compensation which may become payable thereunder. Mr. Miller may<br /><br />
exercise his Appreciation Option as of any June 1 or December 1<br /><br />
commencing June 1, 2002, upon 45 days written notice, in whole or<br /><br />
in 10% increments. In the event that Mr. Miller exercises his<br /><br />
Appreciation Option for less than the total amount available<br /><br />
thereunder, the percentage increment as to which it is exercised<br /><br />
will cease to be available to create additional compensation<br /><br />
opportunity for Mr. Miller based upon subsequent appreciation in<br /><br />
the Company's market capitalization. Mr. Miller's Appreciation<br /><br />
Option expires on June 1, 2007 and will remain exercisable at any<br /><br />
time prior to such expiration notwithstanding his termination of<br /><br />
employment with the Company unless such employment is terminated<br /><br />
by the Company for "cause" or is terminated by Mr. Miller without<br /><br />
"good reason." In keeping with the provisions of the 1997 LTSIP<br /><br />
Restatement discussed in "1997 LTSIP Restatement - Change of<br /><br />
Control Provisions," in the event of a "change in control of XCL"<br /><br />
the Appreciation Option will become immediately exercisable and<br /><br />
the Company will be obligated to pay Mr. Miller, in cash, upon<br /><br />
any exercise of his Appreciation Option, at least 40% of the net<br /><br />
amount payable. This obligation may impede the consummation of a<br /><br />
change of control of the Company.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Material Federal Income Tax Effects<br /><br />
- ----------------------------------The following is a general summary of the material federal<br /><br />
income tax effects to the Company under current law of the<br /><br />
various awards which may be granted under the 1997 LTSIP<br /><br />
Restatement.<br /><br />
These descriptions do not purport to cover all<br /><br />
potential tax consequences.<br /><br />
Section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as<br /><br />
amended<br /><br />
(the<br /><br />
"Code"),<br /><br />
limits<br /><br />
deductibility<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
certain<br /><br />
compensation for the Company's Chief Executive Officer and the<br /><br />
additional four executive officers of the Company who are highest<br /><br />
paid and employed at year end to $1 million per year unless<br /><br />
certain conditions are met which result in compensation being<br /><br />
characterized as "performance-based." Awards under the Plan will<br /><br />
not satisfy the conditions necessary to cause the compensation<br /><br />
earned under them to qualify as "performance-based" compensation,<br /><br />
which is not subject to the deductibility limit of Section 162(m)<br /><br />
of the Code. It is the position of the Board of Directors that<br /><br />
the approach necessary for the design of incentive compensation<br /><br />
that will satisfy the criteria under Section 162(m) of the Code<br /><br />
would compromise the best interests of the Company and its<br /><br />
shareholders.<br /><br />
Certain provisions in the 1997 LTSIP Restatement may afford<br /><br />
the recipient of an Award under the 1997 LTSIP Restatement with<br /><br />
special protections or payments which are contingent upon a<br /><br />
change in the ownership or effective control of the Company or in<br /><br />
the ownership of a substantial portion of the Company's assets.<br /><br />
To the extent that they are triggered by the occurrence of any<br /><br />
such event, these special protections or payments may constitute<br /><br />
"parachute payments" which, when aggregated with other "parachute<br /><br />
payments" received by the recipient, could result in<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
recipient receiving "excess parachute payments."<br /><br />
The Company<br /><br />
would not be allowed a deduction for any such "excess parachute<br /><br />
payments" and the recipient of such "excess parachute payments"<br /><br />
would be subject to a nondeductible 20% excise tax upon such<br /><br />
payments in addition to income tax otherwise owed with respect to<br /><br />
such payments.<br /><br />
Section 401(k) Plan<br /><br />
- ------------------In 1989, the Company adopted an employee benefit plan under<br /><br />
Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code for the benefit of<br /><br />
employees meeting certain eligibility requirements. The Company<br /><br />
has obtained a favorable determination from the Internal Revenue<br /><br />
Service regarding the tax-favored status of this plan. Employees<br /><br />
can contribute up to 10% of their compensation. The Company, at<br /><br />
its discretion and subject to certain limitations, may contribute<br /><br />
up to 75% of the contributions of each participant. The Company<br /><br />
did not make any contributions to the 401(k) Plan in 1997.<br /><br />

incurred in attending meetings of the Board<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Directors.<br /><br />

directors were paid a fee of $1,000 for each committee meeting<br /><br />
attended.<br /><br />

<br /><br />

Compensation Committee Interlocks and Insider Participation<br /><br />
- ----------------------------------------------------------For the year ended December 31, 1997, the following<br /><br />
nonexecutive directors of the Company, served as members of the<br /><br />
Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors: Messrs.<br /><br />
M.<br /><br />
Palliser, A.W. Hummel, Jr., F. Hofheinz (Chairman) and F.J.<br /><br />
Reinhardt, Jr. None of the members of the Compensation Committee<br /><br />
were formerly, nor are any members currently, officers or<br /><br />
employees of the Company or any of its subsidiaries.<br /><br />
Compensation Committee Report on Executive Compensation<br /><br />
------------------------------------------------------The Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors<br /><br />
("Committee") establishes the general compensation policies of<br /><br />
the Company, establishes the compensation plans and specific<br /><br />
compensation levels for executive officers and certain other<br /><br />
managers, and administers the Stock Option Plans and Long Term<br /><br />
Stock Incentive Plan. The Committee currently consists of four<br /><br />
independent, nonemployee directors: Messrs. F. Hofheinz, who<br /><br />
serves as Chairman, M. Palliser, Arthur W. Hummel, Jr. and<br /><br />
Francis J. Reinhardt, Jr.<br /><br />
Compensation Policies and Philosophy<br /><br />
- -----------------------------------The Committee has determined that the compensation program<br /><br />
of the Company should not only be adequate to attract, motivate<br /><br />
and retain executives, key employees and other individuals who<br /><br />
the Company believes may make significant contributions to the<br /><br />
Company's results, but should also be linked to the value<br /><br />
delivered to shareholders as reflected in the price of the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Company's Common Stock.<br /><br />
The Committee believes that the cash compensation of<br /><br />
executive officers, as well as other key employees, should be<br /><br />
competitive with other similarly situated companies while, within<br /><br />
the Company, being fair and discriminating on the basis of<br /><br />
personal performance.<br /><br />
In general, in establishing total cash<br /><br />
compensation for its executives, the Committee has taken into<br /><br />
account the median cash compensation of executives employed by<br /><br />
competitors including some of the companies reflected in the peer<br /><br />
group identified in the Performance Graph set forth below, which<br /><br />
the Committee believes represent the Company's most direct<br /><br />
competition<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
executive talent. The Committee<br /><br />
receives<br /><br />
recommendations from management as to executive compensation and,<br /><br />
in light of the Company's performance and the economic conditions<br /><br />
facing the Company, determines appropriate compensation levels<br /><br />
for recommendation to the Board of Directors. The Committee does<br /><br />
not assign relative weights to individual factors and criteria<br /><br />
used in determining executive compensation and does not use<br /><br />
quantifiable targets in determining compensation. For 1997, the<br /><br />
Company did not retain the services of a compensation consulting<br /><br />
firm.<br /><br />
Awards of stock options are intended both to retain<br /><br />
executives, key employees and other individuals who the Company<br /><br />
believes may make significant contributions to the Company's<br /><br />
results and to motivate them to improve long-term stock market<br /><br />
performance. Options are granted at or above the prevailing<br /><br />
market price and will have value only if the price of the<br /><br />
Company's Common Stock increases.<br /><br />
Effective January 1, 1994, Section 162(m) of the Internal<br /><br />
Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Code") generally denies a tax<br /><br />
deduction to any publicly held corporation for compensation that<br /><br />
exceeds $1 million paid to certain senior executives in a taxable<br /><br />
year,<br /><br />
subject<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
an<br /><br />
exception<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
"performance-based<br /><br />
compensation" as defined in the Code and subject to certain<br /><br />
transition provisions. Gains on the exercise of nonqualified<br /><br />
stock options granted through December 31, 1994, will be tax<br /><br />
deductible under the transition rules. Restricted stock awards<br /><br />
by<br /><br />
definition granted after February 17, 1993,<br /><br />
are<br /><br />
not<br /><br />
deductible. At present the Committee does not intend to recommend<br /><br />
amendment to the Stock Option Plans to meet the restrictive<br /><br />
requirements of the Code.<br /><br />
The Committee believes that annual incentive awards should<br /><br />
be commensurate with performance. It further believes that in<br /><br />
order to meet this objective it needs to have the ability to<br /><br />
exercise its judgment or discretion to evaluate performance<br /><br />
against qualitative criteria. It is the Committee's opinion that<br /><br />
the benefits to the Company of the use of a qualitative approach<br /><br />
to the compensation of senior executives such as the Chairman<br /><br />
outweigh the nonmaterial loss of a portion of the deductions<br /><br />
associated with that compensation.<br /><br />
In recognition of the efforts and sacrifices of management<br /><br />
that had enabled the Company in mid-1997 to be on track to meet<br /><br />
its 1997 goals, the need to retain existing management and the<br /><br />
need to attract qualified and competent personnel, in June 1997,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Board of Directors reassessed the need for adjusting<br /><br />
management's compensation to provide for additional incentives to<br /><br />
management.<br /><br />
As a result of this reassessment, the Board of<br /><br />
Directors approved amendments to and a restatement of the<br /><br />
Company's 1992 LTSIP subject to shareholders approval, which was<br /><br />
obtained on December 17, 1997. These amendments generally made<br /><br />
available to the Committee the authority to grant Awards to<br /><br />
executives employed by the Company entitling such executives to<br /><br />
acquire shares of the Company's Preferred Stock and Common Stock.<br /><br />
They also made available to the Committee the authority to grant<br /><br />
appreciation awards. As described in greater detail in "Awards<br /><br />
to Management," the Board of Directors made, subject to the<br /><br />
approval of the shareholders of the Company, which was obtained<br /><br />
on December 17, 1997, certain Awards under the 1997 LTSIP<br /><br />
Restatement effective as of June 1, 1997 (except for awards to<br /><br />
the CFO and an Executive Vice President which were effective<br /><br />
October 6 and August 1, 1997, respectively).<br /><br />
The Committee<br /><br />
believes that the 1997 LTSIP Restatement and the Awards granted<br /><br />
thereunder effectively encourage retention and continuity of<br /><br />
management,<br /><br />
appropriately reward management for<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
past<br /><br />
performance and align the interests of management with those of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the Company's shareholders by providing management with<br /><br />
opportunity to share in the creation of the Company's value.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On December 17, 1997, the Committee reviewed the Company's<br /><br />
1997 financial results and 1997 nonfinancial goals and determined<br /><br />
that, in light of (i) the Company's continued successful drilling<br /><br />
results in the Zhao Dong Block in the Bohai Bay in China, (ii)<br /><br />
the fact that top officials in China's oil industry have<br /><br />
indicated that the Company will be offered additional exploration<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
development rights in China and (iii) the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
successful placement in May 1997 of $100 million of Preferred<br /><br />
Stock and Notes, the proceeds of which allowed the Company to<br /><br />
commence<br /><br />
achieving its objectives in China, the Company's<br /><br />
financial and operating goals for 1997 had been met and exceeded.<br /><br />
Company Performance and Chief Executive Officer Compensation<br /><br />
- -----------------------------------------------------------The<br /><br />
Committee,<br /><br />
in connection with determining<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
appropriate compensation for Marsden W. Miller, Jr. as Chief<br /><br />
Executive Officer ("CEO"), took into account the financial<br /><br />
condition of the Company, including its liquidity requirements.<br /><br />
It determined that the CEO had been successful in disposing of<br /><br />
assets and raising capital throughout the year. Taking into<br /><br />
consideration the performance of the CEO, as well as the<br /><br />
Company's current cash position and near term requirements, the<br /><br />
adoption of the 1997 LTSIP Restatement and the<br /><br />
NSO<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Appreciation Option awarded to the CEO under the 1997 LTSIP<br /><br />
Restatement, the Committee decided that the 1997 awards should<br /><br />
serve in lieu of a cash salary increase or bonus to the CEO for<br /><br />
the present time.<br /><br />
Compensation of Other Executive Officers<br /><br />
- ---------------------------------------The Committee, in consultation with the CEO, applied the<br /><br />
information and other factors outlined above in reviewing and<br /><br />
approving the compensation of the Company's other executive<br /><br />
officers.<br /><br />

DESCRIPTION OF EXISTING DEBT<br /><br />
General<br /><br />
- ------The Company's only outstanding long-term indebtedness is<br /><br />
represented by the Notes issued in connection with the Note<br /><br />
Offering concluded on May 20, 1997. The Notes are limited in<br /><br />
aggregate principal amount to $75 million. The Notes represent<br /><br />
senior obligations of the Company and rank pari passu in right of<br /><br />
payment with all indebtedness of the Company and senior to any<br /><br />
indebtedness that is expressly subordinated to the Notes.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Notes are secured by (i) a pledge of all the capital stock of XCLChina and any other future restricted subsidiary and (ii) the<br /><br />
subsidiary guarantees of XCL-China (which has given a full and<br /><br />
unconditional guaranty) and any other Subsidiary Guarantor.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Notes will mature on May 1, 2004. The Notes bear interest at the<br /><br />
rate of 13.50% per annum, payable semiannually on May 1 and<br /><br />
November 1 of each year, commencing November 1, 1997.<br /><br />
The Notes were issued pursuant to the terms of the Indenture<br /><br />
with Fleet National Bank as the original Trustee. The Trustee is<br /><br />
now State Street Bank and Trust Company of Connecticut N.A. The<br /><br />
terms of the Indenture are also governed by certain provisions<br /><br />
contained in the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Indenture contains customary representations and warranties by<br /><br />
the Company as well as certain affirmative and negative covenants<br /><br />
briefly described elsewhere in this Prospectus.<br /><br />
See "Risk<br /><br />
Factors -- Restrictions Imposed by Terms of the Company's<br /><br />
Indebtedness."<br /><br />

DESCRIPTION OF CAPITAL STOCK<br /><br />
The authorized capital stock of XCL consists of 500,000,000<br /><br />
shares of common stock, par value $0.01 per share ("Common<br /><br />
Stock"), and 2,400,000 shares of preferred stock, par value $1.00<br /><br />
per<br /><br />
share ("Preferred Stock"), 70,000 of which have been<br /><br />
designated Amended Series B, Cumulative Convertible Preferred<br /><br />
Stock, and 2,085,000 of which have been designated Amended Series<br /><br />
A, Cumulative Convertible Preferred Stock.<br /><br />
Common Stock<br /><br />
------------General<br /><br />
- ------As of September 30, 1998, there were 22,926,333 shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock outstanding, excluding 69,471 shares held<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
treasury, held by approximately 3,480 stockholders of record.<br /><br />
Common Stock is not redeemable, does not have any conversion<br /><br />
rights and is not subject to call. Holders of shares of Common<br /><br />
Stock have no preemptive right to maintain their percentage of<br /><br />
ownership in future offerings or sales of stock of XCL.<br /><br />
Holders<br /><br />
of shares of Common Stock have one vote per share in all<br /><br />
elections of directors and on all other matters submitted to a<br /><br />
vote of stockholders of XCL. The holders of Common Stock are<br /><br />
entitled to receive dividends, if any, as and when declared from<br /><br />
time to time by the Board of Directors of XCL out of funds<br /><br />
legally available therefor (subject to restrictions in the<br /><br />
Indenture<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
any<br /><br />
credit agreement).<br /><br />
Upon<br /><br />
liquidation,<br /><br />
dissolution, or winding up of the affairs of XCL, the holders of<br /><br />
Common Stock will be entitled to participate equally and ratably,<br /><br />
in proportion to the number of shares held, in the net assets of<br /><br />
XCL available for distribution to holders of Common Stock.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
shares of Common Stock currently outstanding are, and the shares<br /><br />
of Common Stock underlying the Warrants offered hereby when<br /><br />
issued will be, fully paid and nonassessable.<br /><br />
Effective December 17, 1997, the Company effected a one-forfifteen reverse stock split of its outstanding shares of Common<br /><br />
Stock.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
<br /><br />
United States registrar and transfer agent for the<br /><br />
Common<br /><br />
Stock is ChaseMellon Shareholder Services,<br /><br />
L.L.C.,<br /><br />
Overpeck Centre, 85 Challenger Road, Ridgefield Park, New Jersey<br /><br />
07660 (Telephone No. 1-800-851-9677). The transfer agent for<br /><br />
the Common Stock in the United Kingdom is IRG plc, Balfour House,<br /><br />
390/398 High Road, Ilford, Essex IG1 1NQ, England (Telephone No.<br /><br />
0181-478-8241).<br /><br />
Special Charter and By-Law Provisions<br /><br />
- ------------------------------------General Effect.<br /><br />
The Board of Directors of the Company<br /><br />
believes that certain provisions in its Amended and Restated<br /><br />
Certificate<br /><br />
of Incorporation, as amended ("Certificate<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Incorporation") and the Amended and Restated By-Laws of XCL (the<br /><br />
"By-Laws") will effectively reduce the possibility that a third<br /><br />
party could effect a sudden or surprise change of majority<br /><br />
control of the Company's Board of Directors or successfully<br /><br />
complete a takeover of XCL without the support of the incumbent<br /><br />
Board of Directors.<br /><br />
Certain provisions in the Certificate of Incorporation and<br /><br />
By-Laws of XCL may have significant effects on the ability of the<br /><br />
stockholders of XCL to change the composition of the incumbent<br /><br />
Board of Directors and to benefit from certain transactions that<br /><br />
are opposed by the incumbent Board of Directors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
XCL has adopted a number of provisions in its Certificate of<br /><br />
Incorporation and By-Laws that might discourage certain types of<br /><br />
transactions that involve an actual or threatened change of<br /><br />
control of XCL. The provisions may make it more difficult and<br /><br />
time consuming to change majority control of the Board of<br /><br />
Directors, and thus reduce the vulnerability of XCL to an<br /><br />
unsolicited offer to acquire XCL, particularly an offer that does<br /><br />
not contemplate the acquisition of all of XCL's outstanding<br /><br />
shares. As more fully described below, the Board believes that,<br /><br />
as a general rule, such unsolicited offers are not in the best<br /><br />
interests of XCL and its stockholders at this time.<br /><br />
The Board of Directors of XCL believes that the threat of<br /><br />
removal of XCL's management, in the case of a takeover bid,<br /><br />
severely curtails its ability to negotiate effectively with a<br /><br />
potential purchaser of XCL or its subsidiaries.<br /><br />
In such a<br /><br />
situation, management is deprived of the time and information<br /><br />
necessary to evaluate the takeover proposal, to study alternative<br /><br />
proposals, and to help ensure that the best transaction involving<br /><br />
XCL is ultimately undertaken. The Board believes a takeover of<br /><br />
XCL without prior negotiation with XCL's management would be<br /><br />
detrimental to XCL and its stockholders. Consequently, the Board<br /><br />
thinks that the benefits of protecting its ability to negotiate<br /><br />
with the proponent of an unfriendly or unsolicited proposal to<br /><br />
take over or restructure XCL outweigh the disadvantages of<br /><br />
discouraging such proposals. The Certificate of Incorporation<br /><br />
makes it more difficult for a holder of a substantial block of<br /><br />
Common Stock to acquire control of, or to remove, the incumbent<br /><br />
Board and could thus have the effect of entrenching incumbent<br /><br />
management. At the same time, the anti-takeover provisions help<br /><br />
ensure that the Board, if confronted by a surprise proposal from<br /><br />
a third party who has recently acquired a block of Common Stock,<br /><br />
will have sufficient time to review the proposal and alternatives<br /><br />
to it and to seek better proposals for its stockholders,<br /><br />
employees, suppliers, customers, and others.<br /><br />
The anti-takeover provisions are intended to encourage<br /><br />
persons seeking to acquire control of XCL to initiate such an<br /><br />
acquisition<br /><br />
through<br /><br />
arm's-length negotiations<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
XCL's<br /><br />
management<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
Board of Directors.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Certificate<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Incorporation could have the effect of discouraging a third party<br /><br />
from making a tender offer or otherwise attempting to obtain<br /><br />
control of XCL, even though such an attempt might be beneficial<br /><br />
to XCL and its stockholders.<br /><br />
Fair Price Provision. The purchaser in corporate takeovers<br /><br />
often pays cash to acquire a controlling equity interest in a<br /><br />
corporation and then arranges a transaction to acquire the<br /><br />
balance of the shares for a lower price or less desirable<br /><br />
consideration (frequently securities of the purchaser that do not<br /><br />
have an established trading market at the time of issue) or both.<br /><br />
This practice is known as "two-tier pricing" and tends (and may<br /><br />
be designed) to cause stockholders to accept the initial offer<br /><br />
for fear of becoming minority stockholders in a controlled<br /><br />
corporation or being forced to accept a lower price or less<br /><br />
favorable consideration for their shares.<br /><br />
To alleviate this<br /><br />
problem, XCL has included in its Certificate of Incorporation a<br /><br />
provision (the "Fair Price Provision") designed to assure that<br /><br />
all stockholders of XCL will receive substantially the same price<br /><br />
for their shares in transactions in which XCL is acquired in two<br /><br />
or more steps.<br /><br />
The Fair Price Provision discourages two-step acquisitions<br /><br />
of XCL by requiring that mergers and certain other business<br /><br />
combinations involving XCL and any Interested Stockholder (as<br /><br />
hereinafter defined) either (1) meet certain minimum price and<br /><br />
procedural requirements, (2) be approved by a majority of the<br /><br />
members of XCL's Board of Directors who are unaffiliated with the<br /><br />
Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder and who were directors before<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Interested Stockholder became a 20% stockholder, (3) be approved<br /><br />
by the favorable vote of at least 67% of the voting power of the<br /><br />
Voting Stock and a majority of the outstanding shares of Voting<br /><br />
Stock (as hereinafter defined) held by persons who are neither<br /><br />
Interested<br /><br />
Stockholders<br /><br />
nor<br /><br />
affiliates<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Interested<br /><br />
Stockholders, or (4) be approved by the holders of at least 80%<br /><br />
of the outstanding shares of Voting Stock.<br /><br />
from<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Fair Price Provision is designed to prevent a purchaser<br /><br />
utilizing two-tier pricing and similar tactics in an<br /><br />
<br /><br />
attempted takeover of XCL. It has the overall effect of making<br /><br />
it more difficult to acquire and exercise control of XCL and may<br /><br />
provide officers and directors with enhanced ability to retain<br /><br />
their position in the event of a takeover bid.<br /><br />
It is not<br /><br />
designed to prevent or discourage all tender offers for control<br /><br />
of XCL.<br /><br />
The Fair Price Provision does not preclude an offeror<br /><br />
from making a tender offer for some of the shares of XCL's stock<br /><br />
without proposing a Business Combination (as defined below) in<br /><br />
which the remaining shares of stock are purchased. Except for<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
restrictions on Business Combinations, the Fair Price<br /><br />
Provision will not prevent a holder of a controlling interest of<br /><br />
the XCL Common Stock from exercising control over XCL or<br /><br />
increasing its interest in XCL. The Board will support or oppose<br /><br />
any future takeover proposal, whether or not the proposal<br /><br />
satisfies the fair price requirements for the Fair<br /><br />
Price<br /><br />
Provision, if the Board determines that its support or opposition<br /><br />
is in the best interests of XCL's stockholders.<br /><br />
The Fair Price Provision will not limit the ability of a<br /><br />
third party to effect a Business Combination, as long as such<br /><br />
third party owns (or can obtain the affirmative votes of) at<br /><br />
least 80% of the outstanding shares of all classes of capital<br /><br />
stock entitled to vote generally in the election of directors<br /><br />
(the "Voting Stock").<br /><br />
Certain Definitions Used in the Fair Price Provision.<br /><br />
An<br /><br />
"Interested Stockholder" is defined in the Fair Price Provision<br /><br />
as anyone who is the beneficial owner of 20% or more of the<br /><br />
Voting Stock, and includes any person who, in a transaction not<br /><br />
involving a public offering, is an assignee of or has succeeded<br /><br />
to any shares of Voting Stock of XCL that were at any time within<br /><br />
the prior two-year period beneficially owned by an Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder.<br /><br />
The term "beneficial owner" includes<br /><br />
persons<br /><br />
directly and indirectly owning or having the right to acquire or<br /><br />
vote the stock. The Board of Directors of XCL considers that a<br /><br />
20%<br /><br />
holding,<br /><br />
which is four times the minimum<br /><br />
ownership<br /><br />
requirement<br /><br />
imposed in connection with<br /><br />
various<br /><br />
reporting<br /><br />
requirements under the Exchange Act for stockholders of public<br /><br />
companies, is appropriate to define an Interested Stockholder.<br /><br />
A<br /><br />
"Business<br /><br />
Combination"<br /><br />
includes<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
following<br /><br />
transactions: (1) a merger or consolidation of XCL or any<br /><br />
subsidiary with an Interested Stockholder or with any other<br /><br />
company or entity that is, or after such merger or consolidation<br /><br />
would be, an affiliate of an Interested Stockholder; (2) the sale<br /><br />
or other disposition by XCL or a subsidiary of assets having an<br /><br />
aggregate fair market value equal to 10% or more of the net<br /><br />
assets of XCL or more if an Interested Stockholder (or an<br /><br />
affiliate thereof) is a party to the transaction; (3) the<br /><br />
issuance or transfer of stock or other securities of XCL or of a<br /><br />
subsidiary to a person or entity that, immediately before such<br /><br />
issuance, is an Interested Stockholder (or an affiliate thereof)<br /><br />
in exchange for cash or property (including stock or other<br /><br />
securities) having an aggregate fair market value equal to 10% or<br /><br />
more of the net assets of XCL; (4) the adoption of any plan or<br /><br />
proposal for the liquidation or dissolution of XCL proposed by or<br /><br />
on behalf of an Interested Stockholder (or an affiliate thereof);<br /><br />
or (5) any reclassification of securities, recapitalization,<br /><br />
merger with a subsidiary or other transaction that has the<br /><br />
effect, directly or indirectly, of increasing the proportionate<br /><br />
share of the outstanding stock (or securities convertible into<br /><br />
stock) of any class of XCL or any of its subsidiaries owned by an<br /><br />
Interested Stockholder or affiliate.<br /><br />
A "Disinterested Director" is a member of the Board of<br /><br />
Directors of XCL who is not affiliated with or a nominee of an<br /><br />
Interested Stockholder and was a director of XCL immediately<br /><br />
before the time the Interested Stockholder became an Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder, and any successor to such Disinterested Director who<br /><br />
is not affiliated with or a nominee of an Interested Stockholder<br /><br />
and was recommended for nomination or election to the Board by a<br /><br />
majority of the Disinterested Directors then on the Board.<br /><br />
Requirements for Certain Business Combinations Without the<br /><br />
Fair Price Provision. If XCL's Certificate of Incorporation did<br /><br />
not include the Fair Price Provision, mergers, consolidations,<br /><br />
the sale of substantially all of the assets of XCL, the adoption<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
a plan of dissolution of XCL and reclassification of<br /><br />
securities and recapitalizations of XCL involving amendments to<br /><br />
the Certificate of Incorporation would require approval by the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
holders of a majority of the voting power of the Voting Stock.<br /><br />
Certain<br /><br />
other transactions, such as sales of<br /><br />
less<br /><br />
than<br /><br />
substantially all of the assets of XCL, certain mergers involving<br /><br />
a wholly owned subsidiary of XCL and recapitalizations and<br /><br />
reclassifications not involving amendments to the Certificate of<br /><br />
Incorporation would not require stockholder approval.<br /><br />
Requirements for Certain Business Combinations Under the<br /><br />
Fair Price Provision. Under the Fair Price Provision, it will be<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
condition to a Business Combination with an Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder that the transaction either (1) meet certain price<br /><br />
criteria and procedural requirements (discussed below), or (2) be<br /><br />
approved by a majority of the Disinterested Directors, or (3) be<br /><br />
approved by the favorable vote of at least 67% of the voting<br /><br />
power of the Voting Stock and a majority of the outstanding<br /><br />
shares of Voting Stock held by persons who are neither Interested<br /><br />
Stockholders or affiliates of Interested Stockholders, or (4) be<br /><br />
approved by the favorable vote of at least 80% of the voting<br /><br />
power of the Voting Stock. If the minimum price criteria and<br /><br />
procedural requirements are met or the requisite approval of the<br /><br />
Disinterested Directors is obtained with respect to a particular<br /><br />
Business Combination, then the normal requirements of Delaware<br /><br />
law will apply, and only a majority vote of the outstanding<br /><br />
Voting Stock will be required or, for certain transactions as<br /><br />
noted above, no stockholder vote will be necessary.<br /><br />
If the<br /><br />
minimum price criteria and procedural requirements are not met or<br /><br />
the requisite approval of the Disinterested Directors is not<br /><br />
obtained, or the requisite vote of shareholders not affiliated<br /><br />
with the Interested Stockholder is not obtained, then a Business<br /><br />
Combination with an Interested Stockholder will require an 80%<br /><br />
stockholder vote. One consequence of the Fair Price Provision,<br /><br />
therefore, is that additional time and expense would be required<br /><br />
to effect certain Business Combinations due to the need to hold a<br /><br />
special stockholders' meeting.<br /><br />
Exceptions to Higher Vote Requirements under the Fair Price<br /><br />
Provision. The 80% affirmative stockholder vote contemplated by<br /><br />
the Fair Price Provision will be required only if (1) the minimum<br /><br />
price criteria and procedural requirements described under (a)<br /><br />
and (b) below are not satisfied or (2) the transaction is not<br /><br />
approved by a majority of the Disinterested Directors or (3) the<br /><br />
requisite vote of shareholders not affiliated with the Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder is not obtained.<br /><br />
(a)<br /><br />
Minimum Price Criteria. In a Business Combination<br /><br />
involving cash or other consideration paid to XCL's stockholders,<br /><br />
the consideration must be either cash or the same type of<br /><br />
consideration used by the Interested Stockholder in acquiring the<br /><br />
largest portion of its Voting Stock before the first public<br /><br />
announcement of the terms of the proposed Business Combination<br /><br />
(the "Announcement Date"). In addition, the fair market value<br /><br />
(calculated in accordance with the Fair Price Provision) of the<br /><br />
consideration to be paid on the date the Business Combination was<br /><br />
consummated (the "Consummation Date") must meet certain minimum<br /><br />
price criteria described herein.<br /><br />
In the case of payments to holders of Common Stock and<br /><br />
Preferred Stock, the fair market value per share of such payments<br /><br />
must be at least equal in value to the higher of (1) the highest<br /><br />
price per share (including brokerage commissions, transfer taxes<br /><br />
and soliciting dealers' fees) paid by the Interested Stockholder<br /><br />
in acquiring any shares of such class or series of stock during<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
two years before the Announcement Date (even if the<br /><br />
Interested Stockholder was not an Interested Stockholder at the<br /><br />
time of any such acquisitions) or in the transaction in which it<br /><br />
became an Interested Stockholder (whichever is higher), or (2)<br /><br />
the fair market value per share of such class or series of stock<br /><br />
on the Announcement Date or on the date on which the Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder became an Interested Stockholder (the "Determination<br /><br />
Date"), whichever is higher; provided, however, the holders of<br /><br />
Preferred Stock shall be entitled to receive an amount at least<br /><br />
equal<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
highest preferential amount<br /><br />
payable<br /><br />
upon<br /><br />
dissolution, liquidation or winding up of XCL applicable thereto<br /><br />
if the Interested Stockholder has not previously purchased shares<br /><br />
of Preferred Stock or such price paid for Preferred Stock is<br /><br />
lower<br /><br />
than<br /><br />
such preferential amount.<br /><br />
If the<br /><br />
Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder purchased any shares of Common Stock during the twoyear period before the Announcement Date, the minimum price might<br /><br />
be fixed based on a purchase occurring as long as two years<br /><br />
before the Announcement Date. If the Determination Date was more<br /><br />
<br /><br />
than two years before the Announcement Date, then the minimum<br /><br />
price could be set as of such earlier date. If the Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder did not purchase any shares of Common Stock during<br /><br />
the two-year period before the Announcement Date or in the<br /><br />
transaction on the Determination Date in which it became an<br /><br />
Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder (e.g., if it became an<br /><br />
Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder through the acquisition of shares of another class of<br /><br />
Voting Stock), the minimum price would be as determined under (2)<br /><br />
above.<br /><br />
For example, if the acquisition by an Interested Stockholder<br /><br />
of its Common Stock interest was by cash purchases in open market<br /><br />
transactions and the highest price paid per share of Common Stock<br /><br />
during the previous two years (including in the transaction in<br /><br />
which it became an Interested Stockholder) was $5.00, and<br /><br />
assuming that the fair market values per share of Common Stock on<br /><br />
the Determination Date and on the Announcement Date were $4.00<br /><br />
and $4.50, respectively, the amount required to be paid to the<br /><br />
holders of Common Stock would be the amount per share in cash<br /><br />
equal to the higher of (1) $5.00 (the highest price paid), and<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
$4.50 (fair market value on the Announcement<br /><br />
Date).<br /><br />
Accordingly, in order to comply with the Fair Price Provision's<br /><br />
minimum price criteria, the Interested Stockholder would be<br /><br />
required to pay at least $5.00 per share in cash to holders of<br /><br />
Common Stock in the Business Combination. If the Interested<br /><br />
Stockholder did not purchase any shares of Common Stock during<br /><br />
the two-year period before becoming an Interested Stockholder<br /><br />
(e.g., if it became an Interested Stockholder through the<br /><br />
acquisition of shares of another class of Voting Stock), the<br /><br />
minimum price payable under the Fair Price Provision for shares<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Common Stock would be the fair market value on<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Announcement Date or on the Determination Date, whichever is<br /><br />
higher, resulting in a price, in the foregoing example, of $4.50<br /><br />
per share in cash. All such prices shall be subject to an<br /><br />
appropriate adjustment in the event of any stock dividend, stock<br /><br />
split, subdivision, combination of shares or similar event.<br /><br />
In the case of payments to holders of any class or series of<br /><br />
XCL's Voting Stock other than Common Stock, the fair market value<br /><br />
per share of such payments must be at least equal to the higher<br /><br />
of (a) the highest price per share determined with respect to<br /><br />
such class or series of stock in the same manner as described in<br /><br />
clauses (1) and (2) of the preceding paragraphs, or (b) the<br /><br />
highest preferential amount per share to which the holders of<br /><br />
such class or series of Voting Stock are entitled in the event of<br /><br />
a voluntary or involuntary liquidation of XCL.<br /><br />
Under the minimum price requirements, the fair market value<br /><br />
of non-cash consideration to be received by holders of shares of<br /><br />
any class of Voting Stock in a Business Combination is to be<br /><br />
determined in good faith by the Board of Directors of XCL.<br /><br />
Under the Fair Price Provision, the Interested Stockholder<br /><br />
is required to meet the minimum price with respect to each class<br /><br />
of stock before proposing the Business Combination.<br /><br />
If the<br /><br />
minimum price criteria and the procedural requirements (discussed<br /><br />
below) are not met with respect to each class of Voting Stock,<br /><br />
then an 80% vote of stockholders will be required to approve the<br /><br />
Business Combination unless the transaction is approved by the<br /><br />
favorable vote of at least 67% of the voting power of the Voting<br /><br />
Stock and a majority of the outstanding shares of Voting Stock<br /><br />
held by persons who are neither Interested Stockholders nor<br /><br />
affiliates of Interested Stockholders, or by a majority of the<br /><br />
Disinterested Directors.<br /><br />
If the proposed Business Combination does not involve<br /><br />
receipt by the other stockholders of XCL of cash or other<br /><br />
property, such as a sale of assets or an issuance of XCL's<br /><br />
securities to an Interested Stockholder, then the price criteria<br /><br />
discussed above will not apply and an 80% vote of stockholders<br /><br />
will be required unless the transaction is approved by the<br /><br />
favorable vote of at least 67% of the voting power of the Voting<br /><br />
Stock and a majority of the outstanding shares of Voting Stock<br /><br />
held by persons who are neither Interested Stockholders nor<br /><br />
affiliates of Interested Stockholders, or by a majority of the<br /><br />
Disinterested Directors.<br /><br />
(b)<br /><br />
Procedural Requirements. Under the Fair Price<br /><br />
Provision, unless the Business Combination is approved by a<br /><br />
majority of the Disinterested Directors, the Business Combination<br /><br />
<br /><br />
will be subject to the 80% stockholder vote requirement, even if<br /><br />
it satisfies the minimum price criteria, in each of the following<br /><br />
situations:<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
If XCL, after the Interested Stockholder became<br /><br />
an Interested Stockholder, (i) reduced the rate of dividends<br /><br />
paid on the Common Stock (unless such reduction<br /><br />
was<br /><br />
necessary to reflect any subdivision of the Common Stock),<br /><br />
or (ii) failed to increase the rate of dividends as<br /><br />
necessary to reflect any reclassification (including any<br /><br />
reverse stock split), recapitalization, reorganization or<br /><br />
any similar transaction which has the effect of reducing the<br /><br />
number of outstanding shares of Common Stock, unless such<br /><br />
reduction was approved by a majority of the Disinterested<br /><br />
Directors.<br /><br />
This provision is designed to prevent<br /><br />
an<br /><br />
Interested Stockholder from attempting to depress the market<br /><br />
price of the Common Stock before proposing a Business<br /><br />
Combination by reducing dividends on the Common Stock, and<br /><br />
thereby reducing the consideration required to be paid<br /><br />
pursuant to the minimum price provisions of the Fair Price<br /><br />
Provision.<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
If the Interested Stockholder acquired any<br /><br />
additional shares of Voting Stock except in the transaction<br /><br />
pursuant to which it became an Interested Stockholder. This<br /><br />
provision is intended to prevent an Interested Stockholder<br /><br />
from purchasing additional shares of Voting Stock without<br /><br />
compliance with the provisions of the Fair Price Provision.<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
If the Interested Stockholder, at any time<br /><br />
after it became an Interested Stockholder, whether in<br /><br />
connection<br /><br />
with the proposed Business Combination<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
otherwise, received the benefits of any loss or other<br /><br />
financial assistance or tax advantage provided by XCL (other<br /><br />
than proportionately as a stockholder). This provision is<br /><br />
intended to deter an Interested Stockholder from selfdealing or otherwise taking advantage of its equity position<br /><br />
in XCL by using XCL's resources to finance the proposed<br /><br />
Business Combination or otherwise for its own purposes in a<br /><br />
manner not proportionately available to all stockholders.<br /><br />
Under the Fair Price Provision, unless the Business<br /><br />
Combination is approved by a majority of the Disinterested<br /><br />
Directors, to avoid the 80% stockholder vote requirement even if<br /><br />
the other conditions described above are met, a proxy or<br /><br />
information statement disclosing the terms and conditions of the<br /><br />
proposed Business Combination and complying with the requirements<br /><br />
of the proxy rules promulgated under the Exchange Act will have<br /><br />
to be mailed to all stockholders of XCL at least 30 days before<br /><br />
the consummation of a Business Combination. This provision is<br /><br />
intended to ensure that XCL's stockholders will be fully informed<br /><br />
of the terms and conditions of the proposed Business Combination<br /><br />
even if the Interested Stockholder is not otherwise legally<br /><br />
required to disclose such information to stockholders.<br /><br />
NONE OF THE MINIMUM PRICE OR PROCEDURAL REQUIREMENTS<br /><br />
DESCRIBED ABOVE WILL APPLY IN THE CASE OF A BUSINESS COMBINATION<br /><br />
APPROVED BY A MAJORITY OF THE DISINTERESTED DIRECTORS OR THE<br /><br />
FAVORABLE VOTE OF 67% OF THE OUTSTANDING SHARES AND A MAJORITY OF<br /><br />
THE SHARES HELD BY PERSONS WHO ARE NEITHER THE INTERESTED<br /><br />
STOCKHOLDER NOR AFFILIATES OF THE INTERESTED STOCKHOLDER, AND, IN<br /><br />
THE ABSENCE OF SUCH APPROVAL, ALL OF SUCH REQUIREMENTS WILL HAVE<br /><br />
TO BE SATISFIED TO AVOID THE 80% STOCKHOLDER VOTE REQUIREMENT.<br /><br />
Classified Board. XCL's Board of Directors is divided into<br /><br />
three classes of directors serving staggered three-year terms,<br /><br />
with one class of directors to be elected at each annual meeting<br /><br />
of shareholders to hold office until the end of their term or<br /><br />
until their successors have been elected and qualified. Directors<br /><br />
may not be removed without cause except upon the affirmative vote<br /><br />
of the holders of 67% of the outstanding shares of Voting Stock.<br /><br />
This provision makes it more difficult to effect an involuntary<br /><br />
change in incumbent management.<br /><br />
No<br /><br />
Cumulative<br /><br />
Voting.<br /><br />
Neither the Certificate<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
Incorporation nor the By-Laws permit cumulative voting. Thus, a<br /><br />
purchaser of a block of Common Stock representing less than a<br /><br />
majority of the outstanding shares will have no assurance of<br /><br />
proportional representation on the Board of Directors.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
No Action by Stockholder Consent. Delaware law provides<br /><br />
that, unless a corporation's certificate of incorporation denies<br /><br />
the right, stockholders may act by a written consent executed by<br /><br />
the holders of a majority of the outstanding shares of voting<br /><br />
stock<br /><br />
without<br /><br />
holding a special or<br /><br />
annual<br /><br />
meeting<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
stockholders. The Certificate of Incorporation prohibits action<br /><br />
that is required or permitted to be taken at any annual or<br /><br />
special meeting of stockholders of XCL from being taken by the<br /><br />
written<br /><br />
consent of stockholders without a meeting<br /><br />
unless<br /><br />
authorized by a majority of the Disinterested Directors.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
intent of this provision is to provide an open forum at a<br /><br />
stockholders' meeting for all stockholders to have a chance to<br /><br />
attend and be heard. This provision could have an anti-takeover<br /><br />
effect and tend to entrench management by forcing the holder or<br /><br />
holders of a majority of the outstanding stock to exercise their<br /><br />
prerogatives of majority ownership only by<br /><br />
voting<br /><br />
at<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
stockholders' meeting rather than by written consent.<br /><br />
Supermajority Voting.<br /><br />
The Fair Price Provision may be<br /><br />
altered, amended, or repealed only if the holders of 80% or more<br /><br />
of the outstanding shares of Voting Stock entitled to vote<br /><br />
thereon or 67% or more of the outstanding shares voting together<br /><br />
with a majority of the outstanding shares held by persons other<br /><br />
than the Interested Stockholder and its affiliates, vote in favor<br /><br />
of such action. The other anti-takeover provisions and certain<br /><br />
other provisions in the Certificate of Incorporation may be<br /><br />
altered, changed, amended, or repealed only if the holders of 67%<br /><br />
or more of the outstanding shares of voting stock of XCL entitled<br /><br />
to vote thereon vote in favor of such action.<br /><br />
Without this<br /><br />
supermajority voting, the beneficial effects of the provisions<br /><br />
requiring such greater percentage of vote could be nullified by<br /><br />
subsequent amendments approved by a vote of the holders of only a<br /><br />
majority of Common Stock.<br /><br />

Dividend Rights<br /><br />
--------------Holders of the Amended Series A Preferred Stock are entitled<br /><br />
to receive when, as and if declared by the Board of Directors,<br /><br />
out of the funds of the Company legally available therefor, an<br /><br />
annual dividend of $8.075 per share, payable semi-annually on May<br /><br />
1 and November 1 in each year, commencing November 1, 1997.<br /><br />
Dividends are payable in additional shares of Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock (valued at $85.00 per share) through November 1,<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2000, and thereafter in cash, or at the Company's election, in<br /><br />
shares of Amended Series A Preferred Stock (valued at $85.00 per<br /><br />
share). Dividends on the Amended Series A Preferred Stock are<br /><br />
cumulative from May 20, 1997, and will be payable, when, as and<br /><br />
if declared, to holders of record on the applicable record date<br /><br />
as shall be fixed by the Board of Directors. Dividends in arrears<br /><br />
may be declared and paid at any time, without reference to any<br /><br />
regular dividend payment date, to holders of record on such date<br /><br />
not exceeding 60 days preceding the payment date thereof, as may<br /><br />
be fixed by the Board of Directors. Accrued but unpaid dividends<br /><br />
will not bear interest. Dividends payable for any partial semiannual period will be calculated on the basis of a 360-day year<br /><br />
consisting of twelve 30-day months.<br /><br />
If dividends are not paid in full on all outstanding shares<br /><br />
of the Amended Series A Preferred Stock and any other capital<br /><br />
stock of the Company ranking on a parity with the Amended Series<br /><br />
A Preferred Stock as to dividends, all dividends declared on the<br /><br />
Amended Series A Preferred Stock and such other parity stock may<br /><br />
only be declared and paid pro rata so that in all cases the<br /><br />
amount of dividends declared per share on the Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock and such other parity stock will bear to each<br /><br />
other the same ratio that accrued and unpaid dividends per share<br /><br />
on the shares of the Amended Series A Preferred Stock and such<br /><br />
other parity stock bear to each other. So long as they are<br /><br />
outstanding, the Company's existing shares of Series B Preferred<br /><br />
Stock shall rank on a parity with the Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock as to dividends or upon liquidation, dissolution and<br /><br />
winding up. Unless full cumulative dividends on all outstanding<br /><br />
shares of the Amended Series A Preferred Stock have been paid, no<br /><br />
dividends (other than in Common Stock or other stock ranking<br /><br />
junior to the Amended Series A Preferred Stock as to dividends<br /><br />
and upon liquidation, dissolution or winding up) may be paid,<br /><br />
declared or set aside for payment, or any other distributions<br /><br />
made on the Common Stock or on any other stock of the Company<br /><br />
ranking junior to the Amended Series A Preferred Stock as to<br /><br />
dividends or upon liquidation, dissolution or winding up, nor may<br /><br />
any Common Stock or any other stock of the Company ranking junior<br /><br />
to or on a parity with the Amended Series A Preferred Stock be<br /><br />
redeemed, purchased or otherwise acquired for any consideration<br /><br />
by the Company (except by conversion into or exchange for stock<br /><br />
of the Company ranking junior to the Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock as to dividends and upon liquidation, dissolution or<br /><br />
winding up).<br /><br />
Under Delaware law, the Company may declare and pay<br /><br />
dividends or make other distributions on its capital stock only<br /><br />
out of surplus, as defined in the Delaware General Corporation<br /><br />
Law (the "DGCL"). On June 30, 1998, the Company had available<br /><br />
surplus of approximately $48 million. The payment of dividends<br /><br />
and any future operating losses will reduce such surplus of the<br /><br />
Company, which may adversely affect the ability of the Company to<br /><br />
continue to pay dividends on the Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock. In addition, no dividends or distributions may<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
declared, paid or made if the Company is or would be rendered<br /><br />
insolvent by virtue of such dividend or distribution, and the<br /><br />
Indenture limits the Company's ability to pay cash dividends. See<br /><br />
"Dividend Policy."<br /><br />
Conversion Rights<br /><br />
----------------The holder of any shares of Amended Series A Preferred Stock<br /><br />
will have the right, at the holder's option, to convert any or<br /><br />

Initial Conversion Date at a conversion price ("Conversion<br /><br />
Price") of, initially, $0.50 per share (subject to adjustment as<br /><br />
described below), or an initial effective conversion<br /><br />
rate<br /><br />
("Conversion Rate") of 170 shares of Common Stock for each share<br /><br />
of Amended Series A Preferred Stock (subject to adjustment as<br /><br />
described below), except that if the Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock is called for redemption, the conversion right will<br /><br />
terminate as to the shares called for redemption at 5:00 p.m.,<br /><br />
New York City time, on the business day prior to the date fixed<br /><br />
for such redemption. Except as provided in the next paragraph,<br /><br />
no payments or adjustments in respect of dividends on shares of<br /><br />
Amended Series A Preferred Stock surrendered for conversion,<br /><br />
whether paid or unpaid and whether or not in arrears, or on<br /><br />
account of any dividend on the Conversion Stock issued upon<br /><br />
conversion, shall be made by the Company upon the conversion of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
any shares of Amended Series A Preferred Stock, at the option of<br /><br />
the holder, including any conversion described under "-- Special<br /><br />
Conversion Rights" below. The holder of record of shares of<br /><br />
Amended Series A Preferred Stock on a dividend record date who<br /><br />
surrenders such shares for conversion during the period between<br /><br />
such dividend record date and the corresponding dividend payment<br /><br />
date will be entitled to receive the dividend on such dividend<br /><br />
payment date notwithstanding the conversion of such shares;<br /><br />
provided, however, that, unless such shares, prior to such<br /><br />
surrender, had been called for redemption on a redemption date<br /><br />
during the period between such dividend record date and such<br /><br />
dividend payment date, such shares must be accompanied, upon<br /><br />
surrender for conversion, by payment from the holder to the<br /><br />
Company of an amount equal to the dividend payable on such shares<br /><br />
on that dividend payment date. No fractional shares of Common<br /><br />
Stock will be issued upon conversion but, in lieu thereof, an<br /><br />
appropriate amount will be paid in cash based on the Market Price<br /><br />
(as defined below) for the shares of Common Stock on the day of<br /><br />
such conversion. No adjustment in the Conversion Price will be<br /><br />
required unless such adjustment would require an increase or<br /><br />
decrease of at least one percent (1%) in the Conversion Price;<br /><br />
provided, however, that any adjustment which is not made will be<br /><br />
carried<br /><br />
forward and taken into account in any subsequent<br /><br />
adjustment.<br /><br />
If the Company, by dividend or otherwise, declares or makes<br /><br />
a distribution on its Common Stock referred to in clause (d) or<br /><br />
(e) of the next paragraph, the holders of Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock, upon the conversion thereof subsequent to the<br /><br />
close of business on the date fixed for the determination of<br /><br />

of such distribution, will be entitled to receive for each share<br /><br />

with<br /><br />

of<br /><br />
distributing any portion of such distribution not consisting of<br /><br />
cash or securities of the Company, pay such holder cash equal to<br /><br />
the fair market value thereof (as determined by the Board of<br /><br />
Directors).<br /><br />
The Conversion Price and the Conversion Rate will be subject<br /><br />
to adjustment in certain events including, without duplication,<br /><br />
(a) dividends (and other distributions) payable in Common Stock<br /><br />
to all holders of Common Stock; (b) the issuance to all holders<br /><br />
of Common Stock of rights or warrants, entitling holders of such<br /><br />

above<br /><br />
and dividends and distributions<br /><br />

The Company from time to time may voluntarily reduce the<br /><br />

If the Company is party to any transaction pursuant to which<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the Common Stock is converted into the right to receive other<br /><br />

of<br /><br />

The term "Market Price" of the Common Stock for any day<br /><br />

faith by the Board of Directors of the Company.<br /><br />

Conversion Price. The term "Current Market Price" of the Common<br /><br />

way, on such day, as reported on the AMEX, or, if the Common<br /><br />
Stock is not listed or admitted to trading on the AMEX on such<br /><br />
day, on the principal national securities exchange on which the<br /><br />
Common Stock is listed or admitted to trading, if the Common<br /><br />
Stock is listed on a national securities exchange, or the NASDAQ<br /><br />
NSM or, if the Common Stock is not quoted or admitted to trading<br /><br />
on such quotations system, on the principal quotation system in<br /><br />
which the Common Stock may be listed or admitted to trading or<br /><br />
quoted or, if not listed or admitted to trading or quoted on any<br /><br />
national securities exchange or quotation system, the average of<br /><br />
the closing bid and asked prices of the Common Stock in the overthe-counter market on the day in question as reported by the<br /><br />
National Quotation Bureau Incorporated, or similar generally<br /><br />
accepted reporting service, or, if not so available in such<br /><br />

to time by the Board of Directors of the Company for that purpose<br /><br />
or, if not so available in such manner, as otherwise determined<br /><br />
in good faith by the Board of Directors of the Company, which<br /><br />
