The Senior Secured Notes restrict, among other things, the<br /><br />
Company's ability to incur additional debt, incur liens, pay<br /><br />
dividends, or make certain other restricted payments.<br /><br />
It also<br /><br />
limits the Company's ability to consummate certain asset sales,<br /><br />
enter into certain transactions with affiliates, enter into<br /><br />
mergers or consolidations, or dispose of substantially all the<br /><br />
Company's assets. The Company's ability to comply with such<br /><br />
covenants may be affected by events beyond its control. The<br /><br />
breach of any of these covenants could result in a default.<br /><br />
A<br /><br />
default could allow holders of the Notes to declare all amounts<br /><br />
outstanding and accrued interest immediately due and payable.<br /><br />
Absent such payment, the holders could proceed against any<br /><br />
collateral granted to them to secure such indebtedness, which<br /><br />
includes all of the stock of the Company's principal operating<br /><br />
subsidiary, XCL-China, which has guaranteed such indebtedness. A<br /><br />
foreclosure on the stock of XCL China could trigger Apache's<br /><br />
right of first refusal under the Participation Agreement to<br /><br />
purchase such stock or its option to purchase the Company's<br /><br />
interest in the Contract. There can be no assurance that the<br /><br />
assets of the Company and XCL-China (a "Subsidiary Guarantor"),<br /><br />
or any other Subsidiary Guarantors would be sufficient to fully<br /><br />
repay the Notes and the Company's other indebtedness.<br /><br />

Series B Preferred Stock<br /><br />
-----------------------The Series B, Cumulative Convertible Preferred Stock, par<br /><br />
value $1.00 per share (the "Series B Preferred Stock") bears a<br /><br />
cumulative fixed dividend at an annual rate of $10 per share,<br /><br />
payable semiannually, and is entitled to 50 votes per share on<br /><br />
all matters on which Common Stockholders are entitled to vote and<br /><br />
separately as a class on certain matters; ranks senior to the<br /><br />
Common Stock and pari passu with the Amended Series A and Series<br /><br />
F Preferred Stocks of the Company with respect to the payment of<br /><br />
dividends and distributions on liquidation; and has a liquidation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
preference of $100 per share plus accumulated dividends.<br /><br />
On May 16, 1995, the Company received notice from the Series<br /><br />
B Preferred holder exercising its redemption rights. The Company<br /><br />
elected to redeem in shares of Common Stock and the holder<br /><br />
exercised its option to have the Company sell its shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock.<br /><br />
The aggregate redemption price was $5 million,<br /><br />
plus accrued dividends from January 1, 1995 to the date of<br /><br />
redemption. Approximately 5,535 shares had been redeemed at<br /><br />
December 31, 1997, from the sale of approximately 353,333 shares<br /><br />
of Common Stock. In July 1997, the holder of the Series B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock sued the Company and each of its directors with<br /><br />
respect to the alleged failure of the Company to redeem the<br /><br />
Series B Preferred Stock in accordance with the terms of the<br /><br />
Purchase Agreement and Certificate of Designation. In settlement<br /><br />
of that lawsuit in March 1998, the holder of the Series B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock revoked and withdrew its redemption notice and<br /><br />
sold its shares of Series B Preferred Stock and accompanying<br /><br />
warrants.<br /><br />
The purchasers exchanged the stock and warrants for<br /><br />
44,465 shares of Amended Series B Preferred Stock and warrants to<br /><br />
purchase 250,000 shares of Common Stock at an exercise price of<br /><br />
$5.50 per share, subject to adjustment, expiring March 2, 2002,<br /><br />
and received 2,620 shares of Amended Series B Preferred Stock in<br /><br />
payment of all accrued and unpaid dividends on the Series B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock.<br /><br />
Each share of Amended Series B Preferred Stock has a<br /><br />
liquidation value of $100, plus accrued and unpaid dividends.<br /><br />
Dividends on the Amended Series B Preferred Stock are cumulative<br /><br />
from March 3, 1998 and are payable semi-annually on June 30 and<br /><br />
December 31 of each year, at an annual rate of $9.50 per share if<br /><br />
paid in cash. In lieu of payment in cash, the Company may, at<br /><br />
its option, elect to pay any dividend in kind in shares of either<br /><br />
Common Stock or Amended Series B Preferred Stock at the option<br /><br />
of the holder. If such dividend is paid in shares of Amended<br /><br />
Series B Preferred Stock, the dividend will be 0.0475 shares of<br /><br />
dividend stock per share of Amended Series B Preferred Stock<br /><br />
held.<br /><br />
If the dividend is paid in shares of Common Stock, the<br /><br />
dividend shall equal the number of shares of Common Stock equal<br /><br />
to the quotient obtained by dividing $4.75 by the lowest average<br /><br />
closing price per share of Common Stock as calculated for the<br /><br />
last 5, 10 and 30 trading days preceding the dividend payment<br /><br />
date.<br /><br />
Fractional shares will be paid in cash or aggregated and<br /><br />
sold on behalf of the holders. The Amended Series B Preferred<br /><br />
Stock is convertible into Common Stock, at any time after the<br /><br />
earlier of the effective date of the registration of such Common<br /><br />
Stock or August 31, 1998.<br /><br />
Series F Preferred Stock<br /><br />
-----------------------In January 1998, the holders of the Series F Preferred Stock<br /><br />
approved an amendment to the "forced conversion" terms of the<br /><br />
Series F Preferred Stock. Effective January 16, 1998, the<br /><br />
Company forced conversion of the Series F Preferred Stock and an<br /><br />
aggregate of 633,893 shares of Common Stock were issued upon<br /><br />
conversion and in payment of accrued and unpaid dividends.<br /><br />
In<br /><br />
consideration for such amendment the holders of the Series F<br /><br />
Preferred Stock were issued warrants to acquire an aggregate of<br /><br />
153,332 shares of Common Stock at an exercise price of $0.15 per<br /><br />
share.<br /><br />
Dividends<br /><br />
--------Prior to November 1997, dividends with respect to the Series<br /><br />
A Preferred Stock were in arrearage. Effective November 10, 1997,<br /><br />
the Series A Preferred Stock was amended, reclassified and<br /><br />
converted to Amended Series A Preferred Stock. As a consequence<br /><br />
of such consent all dividend arrearages, and accrued and unpaid<br /><br />
dividends were paid in additional shares of Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock.<br /><br />
Dividends during 1997 and 1996 on the Series B Preferred<br /><br />
Stock were paid from proceeds of sales of redemption stock, which<br /><br />
were applied first to accrued dividend then the redemption of<br /><br />
shares of Series B Preferred Stock. On March 3, 1998, all<br /><br />
accrued and unpaid dividends on the Series B Preferred Stock were<br /><br />
paid in shares of Amended Series B Preferred Stock.<br /><br />

During 1996, the Company issued 2,218 shares of Series E<br /><br />

December 31, 1996 and June 30, 1997 dividends on the Series E<br /><br />
Preferred Stock.<br /><br />
Effective November 10, 1997, the Series E<br /><br />

Amended Series A Preferred Stock. As a consequence of such<br /><br />
consent all dividend arrearages, and accrued and unpaid dividends<br /><br />
were paid in additional shares of Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />

During 1997, the Company issued 1,261 shares of Series F<br /><br />
Preferred Stock in payment of the June 30, 1997 dividends payable<br /><br />
on the Series F Preferred Stock.<br /><br />
On November 3, 1997, 12,906 shares of Amended Series A<br /><br />
Preferred Stock were issued in respect of the dividend payable<br /><br />
November 1, 1997, in the amount of $1.1 million. Upon conversion<br /><br />
of the Series A and Series E Preferred Stocks into Amended Series<br /><br />
A Preferred Stock, approximately $9.23 in accrued and unpaid<br /><br />
dividends on Series A Preferred Stock and approximately $0.2 in<br /><br />
accrued and unpaid dividends on the Series E Preferred Stock were<br /><br />
paid through the issuance of 790,613 additional shares of Amended<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock.<br /><br />

(9)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Stock Option Plans<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company's stock option plans, administered by the<br /><br />
compensation committee, provide for the issuance of incentive and<br /><br />
nonqualified stock options. Under these plans the Company is<br /><br />
authorized to grant options to selected employees, directors and<br /><br />
consultants to purchase shares of the Company's Common Stock at<br /><br />
an exercise price (for the Company's incentive stock options) of<br /><br />
not less than the market value at the time such options are<br /><br />
granted and are accounted for in accordance with Accounting<br /><br />
Principles Board Opinion No. 25. In June 1992, the shareholders<br /><br />
of the Company approved the adoption of the Company's Long-Term<br /><br />
Stock Incentive Plan ("LTSIP") under which the Company is<br /><br />
authorized to issue an aggregate of 16.5 million shares of Common<br /><br />
Stock pursuant to future awards granted thereunder.<br /><br />
In December 1997, the shareholders of the Company approved<br /><br />
the amendment and restatement of the Company's LTSIP, effective<br /><br />
as of June 1, 1997, (i) increasing the number of shares issuable<br /><br />
under the LTSIP by 4 million (post-split) shares of Common Stock,<br /><br />
(ii) authorizing 200,000 shares of preferred stock for issuance<br /><br />
under the LTSIP, and (iii) ratifying certain grants of nonqualified stock options and restricted stock awards to certain<br /><br />
officers and directors of the Company. The LTSIP, as amended and<br /><br />
restated, also allows for the grant of appreciation option<br /><br />
awards. A grant of an appreciation option award to Mr. Miller was<br /><br />
ratified at that same meeting.<br /><br />
All of the restricted stock awards entitle the participants<br /><br />
to full dividend and voting rights and are restricted as to<br /><br />
disposition and subject to forfeiture under certain conditions.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
shares become unrestricted upon attainment of certain<br /><br />
increases in the market price of the Company's Common Stock<br /><br />
within four years from date of grant, as provided for in the<br /><br />
plan.<br /><br />
Upon issuance of restricted shares, unearned compensation<br /><br />
is charged to shareholders' equity for the cost of restricted<br /><br />
stock and recognized as expense ratably over the earned period,<br /><br />
as applicable. The amount recognized for 1997 was not material<br /><br />
because the measurement date was December 17, 1997.<br /><br />
The appreciation option awarded to the Chairman provides him<br /><br />
with the right upon his payment of the exercise price (20% of<br /><br />
amount entitled to receive) to additional compensation payable in<br /><br />
cash or in shares of Common Stock based upon 5% of the difference<br /><br />
between the market capitalization (as defined) of the Company as<br /><br />
of June 1, 1997, and the date the option is exercised (no earlier<br /><br />
than June 1, 2002). Because the option contemplates compensation<br /><br />
determined<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
reference to<br /><br />
increases<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
market<br /><br />
capitalization without restriction, there is no effective limit<br /><br />
on<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
amount of compensation which may become<br /><br />
payable<br /><br />
thereunder. Deferred compensation of $3.2 million was recorded in<br /><br />
connection with the appreciation option and is being amortized<br /><br />
over the service period. The appreciation option expires on June<br /><br />
1,<br /><br />
2007.<br /><br />
Compensation expense recognized<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
1997<br /><br />
was<br /><br />
approximately $373,000.<br /><br />
Non-qualified options granted on June 1, 1997 for an option<br /><br />
price of $3.75 per share resulted in compensation expense for<br /><br />
1997 of $481,000.<br /><br />
The measurement date was established on<br /><br />
December 17, 1997, the date of shareholder approval.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Employee Benefit and Incentive Compensation Plans<br /><br />
<br /><br />
In 1989, the Company adopted an employee benefit plan under<br /><br />
Section 401(k) of the Internal Revenue Code, for the benefit of<br /><br />
employees meeting certain eligibility requirements. The Company<br /><br />
has received a favorable determination letter from the Internal<br /><br />
Revenue Service regarding the tax favored status of the 401(k)<br /><br />
plan. Employees can contribute up to 10 percent of their<br /><br />
compensation.<br /><br />
The Company, at its discretion and subject to<br /><br />
certain limitations, may contribute up to 75 percent of the<br /><br />
amount contributed by each participant. There were no Company<br /><br />
contributions in 1997, 1996 or 1995.<br /><br />
(11)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Commitments and Contingencies<br /><br />
Other commitments and contingencies include:<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company acquired the rights to the exploration,<br /><br />
development and production of the Zhao Dong Block by executing a<br /><br />
Production Sharing Agreement with CNODC in February 1993. Under<br /><br />
the terms of the Production Sharing Agreement, the Company and<br /><br />
its partner are responsible for all exploration costs. If a<br /><br />
commercial discovery is made, and if CNODC exercises its option<br /><br />
to participate in the development of the field, all development<br /><br />
and operating costs and related oil and gas production will be<br /><br />
shared up to 51 percent by CNODC and the remainder by the<br /><br />
Company and its partner.<br /><br />
The Production Sharing Agreement includes the following<br /><br />
additional principal terms:<br /><br />
The Production Sharing Agreement is basically divided<br /><br />
into<br /><br />
three periods: the Exploration period,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Development period and the Production period. Work to<br /><br />
be performed and expenditures to be incurred during the<br /><br />
Exploration period, which consists of three phases<br /><br />
totaling seven years from May 1, 1993, are<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
exclusive responsibility of the Contractor (the Company<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
partner as a group). The<br /><br />
Contractor's<br /><br />
obligations in the three exploration phases are as<br /><br />
follows:<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the first three years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill three wildcat wells, perform<br /><br />
seismic data acquisition and processing and expend<br /><br />
a minimum of $6 million. These obligations have<br /><br />
been met.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the next two years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill two wildcat wells, perform<br /><br />
seismic data acquisition and processing and expend<br /><br />
a minimum of $4 million (The Contractor has<br /><br />
elected to proceed with the second phase of the<br /><br />
Contract.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
seismic<br /><br />
data<br /><br />
acquisition<br /><br />
requirement<br /><br />
for the second phase<br /><br />
has<br /><br />
been<br /><br />
satisfied.)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the last two years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill two wildcat wells and expend a<br /><br />
minimum of $4 million.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Production Period for any oil<br /><br />
<br /><br />
and/or<br /><br />
<br /><br />
gas<br /><br />
<br /><br />
field covered by the Contract (the "Contract<br /><br />
Area") will be 15 consecutive years (each of 12<br /><br />
months), commencing for each such field on the<br /><br />
date of commencement of commercial production (as<br /><br />
determined under the terms of the Contract).<br /><br />
However, prior to the Production Period, and<br /><br />
during the Development Period, oil and/or gas may<br /><br />
be produced and sold during a long-term testing<br /><br />
period.<br /><br />
The Production Sharing Agreement may be terminated by<br /><br />
Contractor at the end of each phase of the Exploration<br /><br />
period, without further obligation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(12)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company is in dispute over a 1992 tax assessment by the<br /><br />
Louisiana Department of Revenue and Taxation for the years 1987<br /><br />
through 1991 in the approximate amount of $2.5 million. The<br /><br />
Company has also received a proposed assessment from the<br /><br />
Louisiana Department of Revenue and Taxation for income tax years<br /><br />
1991 and 1992, and franchise tax years 1992 through 1996 in the<br /><br />
approximate amount of $3.0 million. The Company has filed written<br /><br />
protests as to these proposed assessments, and will vigorously<br /><br />
contest the asserted deficiencies through the administrative<br /><br />
appeals process and, if necessary, litigation. The Company<br /><br />
believes that adequate provision has been made in the financial<br /><br />
statements for any liability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On July 26, 1996, an individual filed three lawsuits against<br /><br />
a wholly owned subsidiary with respect to oil and gas properties<br /><br />
held for sale. One suit alleges actual damage of $580,000 plus<br /><br />
additional amounts that could result from an accounting of a<br /><br />
pooled interest. Another seeks legal and related expenses of<br /><br />
$56,473 from an allegation the plaintiff was not adequately<br /><br />
represented before the Texas Railroad Commission. The third suit<br /><br />
seeks a declaratory judgement that a pooling of a 1938 lease and<br /><br />
another in 1985 should be declared terminated and further<br /><br />
plaintiffs seek damages in excess of $1 million to effect<br /><br />
environmental restoration. The Company believes these claims are<br /><br />
without merit and intends to vigorously defend itself.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company is subject to other legal proceedings which<br /><br />
arise in the ordinary course of its business. In the opinion of<br /><br />
Management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to<br /><br />
these actions will not materially affect the financial position<br /><br />
of the Company or results of operations of the Company.<br /><br />

Supplementary Information (Unaudited)<br /><br />
The supplementary information set forth below presents<br /><br />
estimates of discounted future net cash flows from proved oil and<br /><br />
gas reserves and changes in such estimates. This information has<br /><br />
been prepared in accordance with requirements prescribed by the<br /><br />
Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB).<br /><br />
Inherent in the<br /><br />
underlying calculations of such data are many variables and<br /><br />
assumptions, the most significant of which are briefly described<br /><br />
below:<br /><br />
Future cash flows from proved oil and gas reserves were<br /><br />
computed on the basis of (a) contractual prices for oil and gas including escalations for gas - in effect at year-end, or (b) in<br /><br />
the case of properties being commercially developed but not<br /><br />
covered by contracts, the estimated market price for gas and the<br /><br />
posted price for oil in effect at year-end.<br /><br />
Probable and<br /><br />
possible reserves - a portion of which, experience has indicated,<br /><br />
generally become proved once further development work has been<br /><br />
conducted - are not considered. Additionally, estimated future<br /><br />
cash flows are dependent upon the assumed quantities of oil and<br /><br />
gas delivered and purchased from the Company. Such deliverability<br /><br />
estimates are highly complex and are not only based on the<br /><br />
physical<br /><br />
characteristics of a property but<br /><br />
also<br /><br />
include<br /><br />
assumptions relative to purchaser demand. Future prices actually<br /><br />
received may differ from the estimates in the standardized<br /><br />
measure.<br /><br />
Future net cash flows have been reduced by applicable<br /><br />
estimated<br /><br />
operating<br /><br />
costs, production<br /><br />
taxes<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
future<br /><br />
development costs, all of which are based on current costs.<br /><br />
Future net cash flows are further reduced by future income<br /><br />
taxes which are calculated by applying the statutory federal<br /><br />
income tax rate to pretax future net cash flows after utilization<br /><br />
of available tax carryforwards.<br /><br />
To reflect the estimated timing of future net cash flows,<br /><br />
such amounts have been discounted by the Securities and Exchange<br /><br />
Commission prescribed annual rate of 10 percent.<br /><br />
In view of the uncertainties inherent in developing this<br /><br />
supplementary information, it is emphasized that the information<br /><br />
represents approximate amounts which may be imprecise and extreme<br /><br />
caution should accompany its use and interpretation.<br /><br />

to Proved Oil and Gas Reserves<br /><br />

XCL Ltd. and Subsidiaries<br /><br />
NOTES TO UNAUDITED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS<br /><br />
June 30, 1998<br /><br />
(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Basis of Presentation<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The consolidated financial statements at June 30, 1998, and<br /><br />
for the six months then ended have been prepared by the Company,<br /><br />
without audit, pursuant to the Rules and Regulations of the<br /><br />
Securities and Exchange Commission. Certain information and<br /><br />
footnote disclosures normally included in financial statements<br /><br />
prepared<br /><br />
in accordance with generally accepted<br /><br />
accounting<br /><br />
principles have been condensed or omitted pursuant to such Rules<br /><br />
and Regulations. The Company believes that the disclosures are<br /><br />
adequate to make the information presented herein not misleading.<br /><br />
These consolidated financial statements should be read<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
conjunction with the financial statements and the notes thereto<br /><br />
included in the Company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year<br /><br />
ended December 31, 1997. In the opinion of management, all<br /><br />
adjustments, consisting only of normal recurring adjustments,<br /><br />
necessary to present fairly the financial position of XCL Ltd.<br /><br />
and subsidiaries as of June 30, 1998, and 1997, and the results<br /><br />
of their operations for the six months ended June 30, 1998 and<br /><br />
1997, have been included. Certain reclassifications have been<br /><br />
made to prior period financial statements to conform to current<br /><br />
year presentation. These reclassifications had no effect on net<br /><br />
loss or shareholders' equity. The results of the Company's<br /><br />
operations<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
such interim periods are not<br /><br />
necessarily<br /><br />
indicative of the results for the full year.<br /><br />
Revenues and operating expenses associated with oil and gas<br /><br />
properties<br /><br />
held<br /><br />
for sale have become<br /><br />
insignificant<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
accordingly, are recorded in other costs and operating expenses<br /><br />
in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Liquidity and Capital Resources<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company, since its decision in 1995 to dispose of its<br /><br />
domestic properties, has generated minimal annual revenues and is<br /><br />
now devoting all of its efforts toward the development of its<br /><br />
China properties. Although the Company has cash available in the<br /><br />
amount of approximately $16.6 million at June 30, 1998 (including<br /><br />
restricted cash of approximately $5.2 million to pay interest due<br /><br />
November 1, 1998) and a positive working capital position,<br /><br />
additional funds will be needed to meet the Company's working<br /><br />
capital requirements and capital expenditure obligations until<br /><br />
sufficient cash flows are generated from anticipated production<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
sustain its operations and to fund future development<br /><br />
obligations.<br /><br />
Management plans to generate the additional cash needed<br /><br />
through the sale or financing of its domestic oil and gas<br /><br />
properties assets held for sale and investment in land and the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
completion<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
additional equity, debt or<br /><br />
joint<br /><br />
venture<br /><br />
transactions. There is no assurance, however, that the Company<br /><br />
will be able to sell or finance its oil and gas properties held<br /><br />
for sale or investment in land or to complete other transactions<br /><br />
in the future at commercially reasonable terms, if at all, or<br /><br />
that it will be able to meet its future contractual obligations.<br /><br />
If production from the China properties commences in late 1998 or<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
first<br /><br />
half of 1999, as anticipated,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Company's<br /><br />
proportionate share of the cash flow will be available to<br /><br />
partially satisfy its cash requirements.<br /><br />
However, there is<br /><br />
likewise no assurance that such development will be successful<br /><br />
and production will commence as anticipated, and that such cash<br /><br />
flow will be available or sufficient.<br /><br />

(7)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Commitments and Contingencies<br /><br />
Other commitments and contingencies include:<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company acquired the rights to the exploration,<br /><br />
development and production of the Zhao Dong Block by executing a<br /><br />
Production Sharing Agreement (the "Agreement") with CNODC in<br /><br />
February 1993. Under the terms of the Agreement, the Company and<br /><br />
its partner are responsible for all exploration costs. If a<br /><br />
commercial discovery is made, and if CNODC exercises its option<br /><br />
to participate in the development of the field, all development<br /><br />
and operating costs and related oil and gas production will be<br /><br />
shared up to 51 percent by CNODC and the remainder by the Company<br /><br />
and its partner.<br /><br />
The Agreement includes the following additional<br /><br />
principal terms:<br /><br />
The Agreement is basically divided into three periods:<br /><br />
the Exploration period, the Development period and the<br /><br />
Production<br /><br />
period.<br /><br />
Work to<br /><br />
be<br /><br />
performed<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
expenditures to be incurred during the Exploration<br /><br />
period, which consists of three phases totaling seven<br /><br />
years<br /><br />
from<br /><br />
May<br /><br />
1,<br /><br />
1993,<br /><br />
are<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
exclusive<br /><br />
responsibility of the Company and its partner as a<br /><br />
group (the "Contractor"). The Contractor's obligations<br /><br />
in the three exploration phases are as follows:<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the first three years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill three wildcat wells, perform<br /><br />
seismic data acquisition and processing and expend<br /><br />
a minimum of $6 million. These obligations have<br /><br />
been met.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the next two years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill two wildcat wells, perform<br /><br />
seismic data acquisition and processing and expend<br /><br />
a minimum of $4 million. (The Contractor has<br /><br />
elected to proceed with the second phase of the<br /><br />
Agreement.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
seismic<br /><br />
data<br /><br />
acquisition<br /><br />
requirement<br /><br />
for the second phase<br /><br />
has<br /><br />
been<br /><br />
satisfied.)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the last two years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill two wildcat wells and expend a<br /><br />
minimum of $4 million.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Production Period for any oil and/or gas<br /><br />
field<br /><br />
covered by the Agreement will be<br /><br />
15<br /><br />
consecutive years (each of 12 months), commencing<br /><br />
for each such field on the date of commencement of<br /><br />
commercial production (as determined under the<br /><br />
terms of the Agreement). However, prior to the<br /><br />
Production Period, and during the Development<br /><br />
Period, oil and/or gas may be produced and sold<br /><br />
during a long-term testing period.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Agreement may be terminated by the Contractor at the end<br /><br />
of each phase of the Exploration period, without<br /><br />
further obligation.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(8)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company is in dispute over a 1992 tax assessment by the<br /><br />
Louisiana Department of Revenue and Taxation for the years 1987<br /><br />
through 1991 in the approximate amount of $2.5 million. The<br /><br />
Company has also received a proposed assessment from the<br /><br />
Louisiana Department of Revenue and Taxation for income tax years<br /><br />
1991 and 1992, and franchise tax years 1992 through 1996 in the<br /><br />
approximate amount of $3.0 million. The Company has filed written<br /><br />
protests as to these proposed assessments, and will vigorously<br /><br />
contest the asserted deficiencies through the administrative<br /><br />
appeals process and, if necessary, litigation. The Company<br /><br />
believes that adequate provision has been made in the financial<br /><br />
statements for any liability.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On July 26, 1996, an individual filed three lawsuits against<br /><br />
a wholly owned subsidiary with respect to oil and gas properties<br /><br />
held for sale. One suit alleges actual damage of $580,000 plus<br /><br />
additional amounts that could result from an accounting of a<br /><br />
pooled interest. Another seeks legal and related expenses of<br /><br />
$56,473 from an allegation the plaintiff was not adequately<br /><br />
represented before the Texas Railroad Commission. The third suit<br /><br />
seeks a declaratory judgement that a pooling of a 1938 lease and<br /><br />
another in 1985 should be declared terminated, and further,<br /><br />
plaintiffs seek damages in excess of $1 million to effect<br /><br />
environmental restoration. The Company believes these claims are<br /><br />
without merit and intends to vigorously defend itself.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company is subject to other legal proceedings which<br /><br />
arise in the ordinary course of its business. In the opinion of<br /><br />
Management, the amount of ultimate liability with respect to<br /><br />
these actions will not materially affect the financial position<br /><br />
of the Company or results of operations of the Company.<br /><br />

REPORT OF INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTANTS<br /><br />
<br /><br />
To the Board of Directors and Shareholders of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
XCL-China Ltd.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
We have audited the financial statements of XCL-China Ltd. listed<br /><br />
in the Index on page F-1. These financial statements are the<br /><br />
responsibility of the Company's management. Our responsibility is<br /><br />
to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our<br /><br />
audits.<br /><br />
We conducted our audits in accordance with generally accepted<br /><br />
auditing standards. Those standards require that we plan and<br /><br />
perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether<br /><br />
the financial statements are free of material misstatement.<br /><br />
An<br /><br />
audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting<br /><br />
the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.<br /><br />
An<br /><br />
audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and<br /><br />
significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating<br /><br />
the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that<br /><br />
our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.<br /><br />
In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above<br /><br />
present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position<br /><br />
of XCL-China Ltd. as of December 31, 1997 and 1996, and the<br /><br />
results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the<br /><br />
three years in the period ended December 31, 1997, in conformity<br /><br />
with generally accepted accounting principles. In addition, in<br /><br />
our opinion, the financial statement schedule referred to above,<br /><br />
when considered in relation to the basic financial statements<br /><br />
taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all material respects, the<br /><br />
information required to be included therein.<br /><br />
The accompanying financial statements have been prepared assuming<br /><br />
that the Company will continue as a going concern. As discussed<br /><br />
in Note 2 to the financial statements, the Company has not<br /><br />
generated production revenues, is dependent on its parent to meet<br /><br />
its cash flow requirements and must, in conjunction with its<br /><br />
parent company, generate additional cash flows to satisfy its<br /><br />
development and exploratory obligations with respect to its oil<br /><br />
and gas properties. There is no assurance that the Company or its<br /><br />
parent will be able to generate the necessary funds to satisfy<br /><br />
these<br /><br />
contractual<br /><br />
obligations and to<br /><br />
ultimately<br /><br />
achieve<br /><br />
profitable operations, which creates substantial doubt about<br /><br />
their ability to continue as a going concern. Managements' plans<br /><br />
in regard to these matters are described in Note 2.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
financial statements do not include any adjustments that might<br /><br />
result from the outcome of this uncertainty.<br /><br />

(1)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Summary of Significant Accounting Policies:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Basis of Presentation:<br /><br />
--------------------The financial statements include the accounts of XCL-China<br /><br />
Ltd. (the "Company"), a wholly owned subsidiary of XCL Ltd. (the<br /><br />
"parent").<br /><br />
Use of Estimates in the Preparation of Financial Statements:<br /><br />
----------------------------------------------------------The preparation of the Company's financial statements, in<br /><br />
conformity<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
generally accepted accounting<br /><br />
principles,<br /><br />
requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect<br /><br />
reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses<br /><br />
and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.<br /><br />
Actual<br /><br />
results could differ from those estimates.<br /><br />
Oil and Gas Properties:<br /><br />
---------------------The Company accounts for its oil and gas exploration and<br /><br />
production activities using the full cost method of accounting<br /><br />
for oil and gas properties. Accordingly, all costs associated<br /><br />
with acquisition, exploration, and development of oil and gas<br /><br />
reserves, including appropriate related costs, are capitalized.<br /><br />
The Company capitalizes internal costs that can be directly<br /><br />
identified with its acquisition, exploration and development<br /><br />
activities<br /><br />
and does not capitalize any costs related<br /><br />
to<br /><br />
production, general corporate overhead or similar activities.<br /><br />
The capitalized costs of oil and gas properties, including<br /><br />
the estimated future costs to develop proved reserves, are<br /><br />
amortized on the unit-of-production method based on estimates of<br /><br />
proved oil and gas reserves. The reserves in 1997 and 1996 were<br /><br />
estimated by independent petroleum engineers. Investments in<br /><br />
unproved properties and major development projects are not<br /><br />
amortized until proved reserves associated with the projects can<br /><br />
be determined or until impairment occurs. If the results of an<br /><br />
assessment indicate that properties are impaired, the amount of<br /><br />
the impairment is added to the capitalized costs to be depleted.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company capitalizes interest on expenditures made<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
connection with exploration and development projects that are not<br /><br />
subject to current amortization. Interest is capitalized for the<br /><br />
period that activities are in progress to bring these projects to<br /><br />
their intended use.<br /><br />
The Company reviews the carrying value of its oil and gas<br /><br />
properties each quarter on a country-by-country basis, and limits<br /><br />
capitalized costs of oil and gas properties to the present value<br /><br />
of estimated future net revenues from proved reserves, discounted<br /><br />
at 10 percent, plus the lower of cost or fair value of unproved<br /><br />
properties as adjusted for related tax effects and deferred tax<br /><br />
reserves. If capitalized costs exceed this limit, the excess is<br /><br />
charged to depreciation and depletion expense.<br /><br />
Proceeds from the sale of proved and unproved properties are<br /><br />
accounted for as reductions to capitalized costs with no gain or<br /><br />
loss recognized unless such sales would significantly alter the<br /><br />
relationship between capitalized costs and proved reserves of oil<br /><br />
and gas. Abandonments of properties are accounted for<br /><br />
as<br /><br />
adjustments of capitalized costs with no loss recognized.<br /><br />
The Company accounts for site restoration, dismantlement and<br /><br />
abandonment costs in its estimated future costs of proved<br /><br />
reserves.<br /><br />
Accordingly, such costs are amortized on a unit of<br /><br />
production basis and reflected with accumulated depreciation,<br /><br />
depletion and amortization. The Company identifies and estimates<br /><br />
such costs based upon its assessment of applicable regulatory<br /><br />
requirements, its operating experience and oil and gas industry<br /><br />
practice in the areas within which its properties are located.<br /><br />
To date the Company has not been required to expend any material<br /><br />
amounts to satisfy such obligations. The Company does not expect<br /><br />
that future costs will have a material adverse effect on the<br /><br />
Company's operations, financial condition or cash flows.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
standardized measure of discounted future net cash flows includes<br /><br />
a deduction for any such costs.<br /><br />
Capitalized Interest:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
- -------------------During fiscal 1997, 1996 and 1995, interest and associated<br /><br />
costs of approximately $5.8 million, $2.8 million and $3.1<br /><br />
million, respectively were capitalized on significant investments<br /><br />
in<br /><br />
oil<br /><br />
and gas properties that are not being currently<br /><br />
depreciated, depleted, or amortized and on which exploration or<br /><br />
development activities are in progress.<br /><br />
Revenue Recognition:<br /><br />
------------------Oil and gas revenues will be recognized using the accrual<br /><br />
method at the price realized as production and delivery occurs.<br /><br />
Foreign Operations<br /><br />
-----------------The Company's future operations and earnings will depend<br /><br />
upon the results of the Company's operations in China. There can<br /><br />
be no assurance that the Company will be able to successfully<br /><br />
conduct such operations, and a failure to do so would have a<br /><br />
material adverse effect on the Company's financial position,<br /><br />
results of operations and cash flows. Also, the success of the<br /><br />
Company's operations will be subject to numerous contingencies,<br /><br />
some<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
which<br /><br />
are beyond management's<br /><br />
control.<br /><br />
These<br /><br />
contingencies include general and regional economic conditions,<br /><br />
prices for crude oil and natural gas, competition and changes in<br /><br />
regulation.<br /><br />
Since the Company is dependent on international<br /><br />
operations, specifically those in China, the Company will be<br /><br />
subject to various additional political, economic and other<br /><br />
uncertainties. Among other risks, the Company's operations will<br /><br />
be subject to the risks of restrictions on transfer of funds;<br /><br />
export duties, quotas and embargoes; domestic and international<br /><br />
customs and tariffs; and changing taxation policies, foreign<br /><br />
exchange restrictions, political conditions and governmental<br /><br />
regulations.<br /><br />
(2)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Liquidity and Management's Plan<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company's parent, in connection with its 1995 decision<br /><br />
to dispose of its domestic properties, is devoting all of its<br /><br />
efforts toward the development of the Company's properties.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
Company has historically relied on its parent to meet its cash<br /><br />
flow requirements. Although the parent has cash available in the<br /><br />
amount of approximately $32 million as of December 31, 1997<br /><br />
(including restricted cash of approximately $10 million) and a<br /><br />
positive working capital position, management anticipates that<br /><br />
the Company and its parent will need additional funds to meet all<br /><br />
of the development and exploratory obligations until sufficient<br /><br />
cash flows are generated from anticipated production to sustain<br /><br />
operations<br /><br />
and to fund future development and exploration<br /><br />
obligations.<br /><br />
The parent plans to generate the additional cash needed<br /><br />
through the sale or financing of its domestic assets held for<br /><br />
sale and the completion of additional equity, debt or joint<br /><br />
venture transactions. There is no assurance, however, that the<br /><br />
parent will be able to sell or finance its assets held for sale<br /><br />
or to complete other transactions in the future at commercially<br /><br />
reasonable terms, if at all, or that the Company will be able to<br /><br />
meet its future contractual obligations. If production from the<br /><br />
Company's properties commences in late 1998 or the first half of<br /><br />
1999, as anticipated, the Company's proportionate share of the<br /><br />
related cash flow will be available to help satisfy cash<br /><br />
requirements. However, there is likewise no assurance that such<br /><br />
development will be successful and production will commence, and<br /><br />
that such cash flow will be available.<br /><br />
(3)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Supplemental Cash Flow Information<br /><br />
<br /><br />
There were no income taxes paid for the years ended December<br /><br />
31, 1997, 1996 and 1995.<br /><br />
(4)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Income Taxes<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Foreign income taxes are accounted for under the tax<br /><br />
structure in that country, principally China. As of December 31,<br /><br />
1997, the Company does not have undistributed earnings available<br /><br />
to its parent because of accumulated losses.<br /><br />
Further, such<br /><br />
<br /><br />
losses<br /><br />
have provided no tax benefit to the parent company and<br /><br />
accordingly, there has been no tax impact. When necessary the<br /><br />
Company will enter into an appropriate tax sharing arrangement<br /><br />
with its parent.<br /><br />
(5)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Other Commitments and Contingencies<br /><br />
Other commitments and contingencies include:<br /><br />
o<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company acquired the rights to the exploration,<br /><br />
development and production of the Zhao Dong Block by executing a<br /><br />
Production Sharing Agreement with CNODC in February 1993. Under<br /><br />
the terms of the Production Sharing Agreement, the Company and<br /><br />
its partner are responsible for all exploration costs. If a<br /><br />
commercial discovery is made, and if CNODC exercises its option<br /><br />
to participate in the development of the field, all development<br /><br />
and operating costs and related oil and gas production will be<br /><br />
shared up to 51 percent by CNODC and the remainder by the<br /><br />
Company and its partner.<br /><br />
The Production Sharing Agreement includes the following<br /><br />
additional principal terms:<br /><br />
The Production Sharing Agreement is basically divided<br /><br />
into<br /><br />
three periods: the Exploration period,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Development period and the Production period. Work to<br /><br />
be performed and expenditures to be incurred during the<br /><br />
Exploration period, which consists of three phases<br /><br />
totaling seven years from May 1, 1993, are<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
exclusive responsibility of the Contractor (the Company<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
its<br /><br />
partner as a group). The<br /><br />
Contractor's<br /><br />
obligations in the three exploration phases are as<br /><br />
follows:<br /><br />
1.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the first three years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill three wildcat wells, perform<br /><br />
seismic data acquisition and processing and expend<br /><br />
a minimum of $6 million. These obligations have<br /><br />
been met;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
2.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the next two years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill two wildcat wells, perform<br /><br />
seismic data acquisition and processing and expend<br /><br />
a minimum of $4 million (The Contractor has<br /><br />
elected to proceed with the second phase of the<br /><br />
Contract.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
seismic<br /><br />
data<br /><br />
acquisition<br /><br />
requirement<br /><br />
for the second phase<br /><br />
has<br /><br />
been<br /><br />
satisfied.);<br /><br />
<br /><br />
3.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During the last two years, the Contractor is<br /><br />
required to drill two wildcat wells and expend a<br /><br />
minimum of $4 million.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
4.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Production Period for any oil and/or gas<br /><br />
field covered by the Contract (the "Contract<br /><br />
Area") will be 15 consecutive years (each of 12<br /><br />
months), commencing for each such field on the<br /><br />
date of commencement of commercial production (as<br /><br />
determined under the terms of the Contract).<br /><br />
However, prior to the Production Period, and<br /><br />
during the Development Period, oil and/or gas may<br /><br />
be produced and sold during a long-term testing<br /><br />
period.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Production Sharing Agreement may be terminated by<br /><br />
Contractor at the end of each phase of the Exploration<br /><br />
period, without further obligation.<br /><br />
(6)<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Related Party Transactions<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company has consistently borrowed money from its parent<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
the acquisition and development of its oil and<br /><br />
gas<br /><br />
properties. The amount due the parent as of December 31, 1997 is<br /><br />
approximately $52 million. All of the Common Stock of the<br /><br />
Company has been pledged as collateral for parent company debt<br /><br />
and the Company is a guarantor on certain Senior Secured Notes<br /><br />
described below.<br /><br />
Senior Secured Notes of Parent Company<br /><br />
--------------------------------------<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
On May 20, 1997, the parent company sold in an unregistered<br /><br />
offering<br /><br />
to qualified institutional buyers and<br /><br />
accredited<br /><br />
institutional investors 75,000 Note Units, each consisting of<br /><br />
$1,000 principal amount of 13.5% Senior Secured Notes due May 1,<br /><br />
2004 and one Common Stock Purchase Warrant to purchase 85 shares<br /><br />
of the parent's common stock, par value $0.01 per share (the<br /><br />
"Common Stock"), at an exercise price of $3.09 per share, first<br /><br />
exercisable after May 20, 1998.<br /><br />
Interest on the Notes is payable semi-annually on May 1 and<br /><br />
November 1, commencing November 1, 1997. The Notes will mature<br /><br />
on May 1, 2004. The Notes are not redeemable at the option of the<br /><br />
parent prior to May 1, 2002, except that the parent may redeem,<br /><br />
at its option prior to May 1, 2002, up to 35% of the original<br /><br />
aggregate principal amount of the Notes, at a redemption price of<br /><br />
113.5% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes, plus<br /><br />
accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date of redemption,<br /><br />
with the net proceeds of any equity offering completed within 90<br /><br />
days prior to such redemption; provided that at least $48.75<br /><br />
million in aggregate principal amount of the Notes remain<br /><br />
outstanding.<br /><br />
On or after May 1, 2002, the Notes are redeemable<br /><br />
at the option of the parent, in whole or in part, at an initial<br /><br />
redemption price of 106.75% of the aggregate principal amount of<br /><br />
the Notes until May 1, 2003, and at par thereafter, plus accrued<br /><br />
and unpaid interest, if any, to the date of redemption.<br /><br />
The Senior Secured Notes restrict, among other things, the<br /><br />
parent's and its subsidiaries ability to incur additional debt,<br /><br />
incur liens, pay dividends, or make certain other restricted<br /><br />
payments.<br /><br />
It also limits the parent's ability to consummate<br /><br />
certain asset sales, enter into certain transactions<br /><br />
with<br /><br />
affiliates, enter into mergers or consolidations, or dispose of<br /><br />
substantially all the parent's assets. The parent's ability to<br /><br />
comply with such covenants may be affected by events beyond its<br /><br />
control. The breach of any of these covenants could result in a<br /><br />
default.<br /><br />
A default could allow holders of the Notes to declare<br /><br />
all amounts outstanding and accrued interest immediately due and<br /><br />
payable. A foreclosure on the stock of the Company could trigger<br /><br />
Apache's right of first refusal under the Participation Agreement<br /><br />
to purchase such stock or its option to purchase the parent's<br /><br />
interest in the Contract. There can be no assurance that the<br /><br />
assets of the parent and the Company, or any other Subsidiary<br /><br />
Guarantors would be sufficient to fully repay the Notes and the<br /><br />
parent's other indebtedness.<br /><br />

<br /><br />
Supplementary Information (Unaudited)<br /><br />
The supplementary information set forth below presents<br /><br />
estimates of discounted future net cash flows from proved oil and<br /><br />
gas reserves and changes in such estimates. This information has<br /><br />
been prepared in accordance with requirements prescribed by the<br /><br />
Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB).<br /><br />
Inherent in the<br /><br />
underlying calculations of such data are many variables and<br /><br />
assumptions, the most significant of which are briefly described<br /><br />
below:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
5,298<br /><br />
135<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Future cash flows from proved oil and gas reserves were<br /><br />
computed on the basis of (a) contractual prices for oil and gas including escalations for gas - in effect at year-end, or (b) in<br /><br />
the case of properties being commercially developed but not<br /><br />
covered by contracts, the estimated market price for gas and the<br /><br />
posted price for oil in effect at year-end.<br /><br />
Probable and<br /><br />
possible reserves - a portion of which, experience has indicated,<br /><br />
generally become proved once further development work has been<br /><br />
conducted - are not considered. Additionally, estimated future<br /><br />
cash flows are dependent upon the assumed quantities of oil and<br /><br />
gas delivered and purchased from the Company. Such deliverability<br /><br />
estimates are highly complex and are not only based on the<br /><br />
physical<br /><br />
characteristics of a property but<br /><br />
also<br /><br />
include<br /><br />
assumptions relative to purchaser demand. Future prices actually<br /><br />
received may differ from the estimates in the standardized<br /><br />
measure.<br /><br />
Future net cash flows have been reduced by applicable<br /><br />
estimated<br /><br />
operating<br /><br />
costs, production<br /><br />
taxes<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
future<br /><br />
development costs, all of which are based on current costs.<br /><br />
Future net cash flows are further reduced by future income<br /><br />
taxes which are calculated by applying the statutory federal<br /><br />
income tax rate to pretax future net cash flows after utilization<br /><br />
of available tax carryforwards.<br /><br />
To reflect the estimated timing of future net cash flows,<br /><br />
such amounts have been discounted by the Securities and Exchange<br /><br />
Commission prescribed annual rate of 10 percent.<br /><br />
In view of the uncertainties inherent in developing this<br /><br />
supplementary information, it is emphasized that the information<br /><br />
represents approximate amounts which may be imprecise and extreme<br /><br />
caution should accompany its use and interpretation.<br /><br />
Standardized Measure of Discounted Future Net Cash Flows Related<br /><br />
to Proved Oil and Gas Reserves<br /><br />
The standardized measure of discounted future net cash flows<br /><br />
from proved oil and gas reserves, determined in accordance with<br /><br />
rules prescribed by FASB No. 69 is summarized below, and does not<br /><br />
purport to present the fair market value of the Company's oil and<br /><br />
gas assets, but does present the present value of estimated<br /><br />
future cash flows that would result under the assumptions used.:<br /><br />
The Company previously excluded from this table, the effect of<br /><br />

Item 14.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
expenses<br /><br />
<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Indemnification of Directors and Officers<br /><br />
<br /><br />
The Company's Amended and Restated<br /><br />
Incorporation (the "Certificate") provides that:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Certificate<br /><br />
<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(A)<br /><br />
No director of the Company will be personally<br /><br />
liable to the Company or its stockholders for monetary damages<br /><br />
for breach of fiduciary duty as a director, except for liability<br /><br />
(i) for any breach of the director's duty of loyalty to the<br /><br />
Company or its stockholders, (ii) for acts or omissions not in<br /><br />
good faith or which involve intentional misconduct or a knowing<br /><br />
violation of law, (iii) under Section 174 of the Delaware General<br /><br />
Corporation Law, or (iv) for any transaction from which the<br /><br />
director derived an improper personal benefit.<br /><br />
(B)<br /><br />
Each person who was or is made a party or is<br /><br />
threatened to be made a party to or involved in any action suit<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
proceeding<br /><br />
whether civil, criminal, administrative<br /><br />
or<br /><br />
investigative (hereinafter a "proceeding"), by reason of the fact<br /><br />
that he or she is or was a director, officer or employee of the<br /><br />
Company or is or was serving at the request of the Company as a<br /><br />
director, officer, employee or agent of another corporation or of<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
partnership, joint venture, trust or other<br /><br />
enterprise,<br /><br />
including service with respect to an employee benefit plan,<br /><br />
whether the basis of such proceeding is alleged action in an<br /><br />
official capacity as a director, officer, employee or agent or in<br /><br />
any other capacity while serving as a director, officer, employee<br /><br />
or agent, will be indemnified and held harmless by the Company to<br /><br />
the fullest extent authorized by the Delaware General Corporation<br /><br />
Law, as the same exists or may hereafter be amended (but in the<br /><br />
case of any such amendment, only to the extent that such<br /><br />
amendment permits the Company to provide broader indemnification<br /><br />
rights than said law permitted the Company to provide prior to<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
amendment), against all expense, liability and<br /><br />
loss<br /><br />
(including attorneys' fees, judgments, fines, including excise<br /><br />
taxes with respect to an employee benefit plan, or penalties and<br /><br />
amounts paid in settlement) reasonably incurred or suffered by<br /><br />
such person in connection therewith and such indemnification will<br /><br />
continue as to a person who has ceased to be a director, officer,<br /><br />
employee or agent and will inure to the benefit of his or her<br /><br />
heirs, executors and administrators; provided, however, that,<br /><br />
except as described in (C) below, the Company will indemnify any<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
person seeking indemnification in connection with<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
proceeding (or part hereof) initiated by such person only if such<br /><br />
proceeding (or part thereof) was authorized by the board of<br /><br />
directors of the Company. The right to indemnification described<br /><br />
in this paragraph B includes the right to be paid by the Company<br /><br />
the expenses incurred in defending any such proceeding in advance<br /><br />
of its final disposition; provided, however, that if the Delaware<br /><br />
General Corporation Law requires, the payment of such expenses<br /><br />
incurred by a director or officer in his or her capacity as a<br /><br />
director or officer (and not in any other capacity in which<br /><br />
service was or is rendered by such person while a director or<br /><br />
officer, including, without limitation, service to an employee<br /><br />
benefit plan) in advance of the final disposition<br /><br />
of<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
proceeding, will be made only upon delivery to the Company of an<br /><br />
undertaking, by or on behalf of such director or officer, to<br /><br />
repay all amounts so advanced if it will ultimately be determined<br /><br />
that such director or officer is not entitled to be indemnified<br /><br />
under the Certificate or otherwise.<br /><br />
(C)<br /><br />
If a claim described in paragraph (B) above is<br /><br />
not paid in full by the Company within thirty (30) after written<br /><br />
claim has been received by the Company, the claimant may at any<br /><br />
time thereafter bring suit against the Company to recover the<br /><br />
unpaid amount of the claim and, if successful in whole or in<br /><br />
part, the claimant will be entitled to be paid also the expense<br /><br />
of prosecuting such claim. It will be a defense to any such<br /><br />
action (other than an action brought to enforce a claim for<br /><br />
expenses incurred in defending any proceeding in advance of its<br /><br />
final disposition where the required undertaking, if any is<br /><br />
required, has been tendered to the Company) that the claimant has<br /><br />
not met the standards of conduct which make it permissible under<br /><br />
the Delaware General Corporation Law for the Company to indemnify<br /><br />
the claimant for the amount claimed, but the burden of proving<br /><br />
such defense will be on the Company. Neither the failure of the<br /><br />
Company (including its board of directors, independent legal<br /><br />
<br /><br />
counsel, or its stockholders) to have made a determination prior<br /><br />
to the commencement of such action that indemnification of the<br /><br />
claimant is proper in the circumstances because he or she has met<br /><br />
the applicable standard of conduct set forth in the Delaware<br /><br />
General Corporation Law, nor an actual determination by the<br /><br />
Company (including its board of directors, independent legal<br /><br />
counsel, or its stockholders) that the claimant has not met such<br /><br />
applicable standard of conduct, will be a defense to the action<br /><br />
or create a presumption that the claimant has not met the<br /><br />
applicable standard of conduct.<br /><br />
(D)<br /><br />
The right to indemnification and the payment of<br /><br />
expenses incurred in defending a proceeding in advance of its<br /><br />
final disposition conferred in the Certificate will not be<br /><br />
exclusive of any right which any person may have or hereafter<br /><br />
acquire under any statute, provision of the Certificate, the<br /><br />
Amended and Restated Bylaws of the Company (the "Bylaws"),<br /><br />
agreement, vote of stockholders or disinterested directors or<br /><br />
otherwise.<br /><br />
(E)<br /><br />
The Company may maintain insurance, at its<br /><br />
expense, to protect itself and any director, officer, employee or<br /><br />
agent of the Company or another corporation, partnership, joint<br /><br />
venture, trust or other enterprise, including an employee benefit<br /><br />
plan, against any such expense, liability or loss, whether or not<br /><br />
the Company would have the power to indemnify such person against<br /><br />
such expense, liability or loss under the Delaware General<br /><br />
Corporation Law.<br /><br />
(F)<br /><br />
Upon resolution passed by the board of<br /><br />
directors, the Company may establish a trust or other designated<br /><br />
account, grant a security interest or use other means (including,<br /><br />
without limitation, a letter of credit) to ensure the payment of<br /><br />
certain of its obligations arising under the indemnification<br /><br />
provisions contained in the Certificate.<br /><br />
(G)<br /><br />
If any part of the indemnification provisions<br /><br />
contained in the Certificate will be found, in any action, suit<br /><br />
or proceeding or appeal therefrom or in any other circumstances<br /><br />
or as to any particular officer, director or employee to be<br /><br />
unenforceable, ineffective or invalid for any reason,<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
enforceability, effect and validity of the remaining parts or of<br /><br />
such parts in other circumstances will not be affected, except as<br /><br />
otherwise required by applicable law.<br /><br />
The Bylaws provide that:<br /><br />
(i)<br /><br />
the Company will indemnify to the full<br /><br />
extent permitted by, and in the manner permissible<br /><br />
under, the laws of the State of Delaware any person<br /><br />
made, or threatened to be made, a party to an action or<br /><br />
proceeding, whether criminal, civil, administrative or<br /><br />
investigative, by reason of the fact that he, his<br /><br />
testator or intestate is or was a director or officer<br /><br />
of the Company or any predecessor of the Company, or<br /><br />
served any other enterprise as a director or officer at<br /><br />
the request of the Company or any predecessor of the<br /><br />
Company.<br /><br />
(ii)<br /><br />
the rights of indemnification described<br /><br />
in paragraph (i) above will be deemed to be a contract<br /><br />
between the Company and each director and officer who<br /><br />
serves in such capacity at any time while<br /><br />
such<br /><br />
provision is in effect, and any repeal or modification<br /><br />
thereof will not affect any rights or obligations then<br /><br />
existing or any action, suit or proceeding theretofore<br /><br />
brought based in whole or in part upon any such state<br /><br />
of facts;<br /><br />
(iii)<br /><br />
the rights of indemnification described<br /><br />
in paragraphs (i) and (ii) above will not be deemed<br /><br />
exclusive of any other rights to which any director or<br /><br />
officer may be entitled apart from the provisions of<br /><br />
Article VIII of the Bylaws (governing indemnification);<br /><br />
and<br /><br />
(iv)<br /><br />
the board of directors in its discretion<br /><br />
will have power on behalf of the Company to indemnify<br /><br />
any person, other than a director or officer, made a<br /><br />
party to any action, suit or proceeding by reason of<br /><br />
<br /><br />
the fact that he, his testator or intestate, is or was<br /><br />
an employee of the Company.<br /><br />
Insofar as indemnification for liabilities arising<br /><br />
under the Securities Act may be permitted to directors, officers<br /><br />
or persons controlling the registrant pursuant to the foregoing<br /><br />
provisions, the Company has been informed that in the opinion of<br /><br />
the Securities and Exchange Commission such indemnification is<br /><br />
against public policy as expressed in the Securities Act and is<br /><br />
therefore unenforceable.<br /><br />

Series A Preferred Stock<br /><br />
------------------------<br /><br />
<br /><br />
During 1990, the Company completed a rights offering of<br /><br />
600,000 units of 50 U.K. Pounds Sterling per "unit," each unit<br /><br />
consisting of 1 share of Series A, Cumulative Convertible<br /><br />
Preferred Stock, par value $1.00 per share ("Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock") and 10 warrants to purchase Common Stock which expired<br /><br />
unexercised pursuant to their terms. Until November 10, 1997 the<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock was listed on the London Stock Exchange,<br /><br />
and: ranked senior to Common Stock and pari passu with the<br /><br />
Company's Series B, Series E and Series F Preferred Stock with<br /><br />
respect to payment of dividends and distributions on liquidation;<br /><br />
had a liquidation preference of 50 U.K. Pounds Sterling per share<br /><br />
plus accrued and unpaid dividends; was not redeemable in certain<br /><br />
limited circumstances; was nonvoting as a class, except in certain<br /><br />
circumstances, including the right to cast 21 votes for each share<br /><br />
of Series A Preferred Stock held on all resolutions proposed at a<br /><br />
meeting of shareholders if, at the date of notice convening a meeting<br /><br />
of shareholders, the dividend on the Series A Preferred Stock was<br /><br />
six months or more in arrears.<br /><br />
The Series A Preferred Stock was<br /><br />
convertible, at the holder's option, on the basis of 21 shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock for every one share of Series A Preferred Stock,<br /><br />
subject<br /><br />
to adjustment and bore a cumulative dividend fixed at an<br /><br />
annual rate of 4.50 U.K. Pounds Sterling per share, payable semiannually in cash, or, at the Company's election, in additional<br /><br />
shares of Series A Preferred Stock.<br /><br />
During the second quarter of 1996, the Company issued<br /><br />
450,261 shares of Common Stock upon conversion of 21,441 shares<br /><br />
of Series A Preferred Stock, pursuant to the terms thereof.<br /><br />
During March 1997 an additional 39 shares of Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock were converted into 819 shares of Common Stock.<br /><br />
During February 1997, the Company sold 13,458 shares of<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock to accredited investors for $157,240.<br /><br />
The<br /><br />
proceeds were used to pay the withholding taxes and<br /><br />
fractional interests with respect to the December 31, 1995<br /><br />
dividend payment. The securities issued by the Company in this<br /><br />
transaction were not registered under the Securities Act in<br /><br />
reliance upon the exemption provided by Section 4(2) thereof. In<br /><br />
<br /><br />
March 1997, the Company issued an additional 50,137 shares of<br /><br />
Series A Preferred Stock to holders of Series A Preferred Stock<br /><br />
in payment of this dividend, therefore fulfilling its obligation<br /><br />
for such dividend period. Effective November 10, 1997, the<br /><br />
Company recapitalized and combined the Series A Preferred Stock<br /><br />
into an aggregate of 726,907 shares of Amended Series A Preferred<br /><br />
Stock (including approximately $900,000 in unpaid dividends<br /><br />
declared for June 30, 1995 and accrued and unpaid dividends from<br /><br />
June 30, 1996 through November 9, 1997).<br /><br />
Series B Preferred Stock/Amended Series B Preferred Stock<br /><br />
-----------------------------------------------------------The Series B, Cumulative Convertible Preferred Stock,<br /><br />
par value $1.00 per share (the "Series B Preferred Stock") bears<br /><br />
a cumulative fixed dividend at an annual rate of $10 per share,<br /><br />
payable semiannually, and is entitled to 50 votes per share on<br /><br />
all matters on which Common Stockholders are entitled to vote and<br /><br />
separately as a class on certain matters; ranks senior to the<br /><br />
Common Stock and pari passu with the Series A and Series E<br /><br />
Preferred Stocks of the Company with respect to the payment of<br /><br />
dividends and distributions on liquidation; and has a liquidation<br /><br />
preference of $100 per share plus accumulated dividends.<br /><br />
The Company had the option through May 1994, to pay the<br /><br />
dividend in shares of Common Stock, in which case the annual<br /><br />
dividend rate was $12 per share, with the holder being entitled<br /><br />
to require the Company to use its best efforts to sell such<br /><br />
shares on their behalf and to reimburse such holder for the<br /><br />
difference, if any, between such net proceeds and $11 per share<br /><br />
per annum.<br /><br />
The Company is currently entitled to pay the<br /><br />
redemption price of the Series B Preferred Stock in shares of<br /><br />
Common Stock.<br /><br />
Effective June 30, 1994, the terms of the Series B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock were amended to permit the Company to issue<br /><br />
shares of Common Stock in lieu of cash dividends for so long as<br /><br />
the<br /><br />
Series<br /><br />
B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock remains<br /><br />
outstanding.<br /><br />
In<br /><br />
consideration for this amendment, the Series B Preferred Stock<br /><br />
was further amended: (i) to reduce the exercise price of the<br /><br />
remaining 2.5 million warrants outstanding from $2.00 to $1.50<br /><br />
per share and to increase the number of shares of Common Stock<br /><br />
covered by such warrants to 3.325 million shares and (ii) to<br /><br />
extend the option of the holders to redeem their shares of Series<br /><br />
B Preferred Stock, which were only redeemable on the third,<br /><br />
fourth and fifth anniversaries of the dates of their issuance and<br /><br />
automatically upon exercise of the remaining warrants, upon<br /><br />
ninety days notice to the Company, at any time and from time to<br /><br />
time, after August 31, 1994, with the Company retaining the right<br /><br />
to pay the redemption price in Common Stock.<br /><br />
In May 1995, the holder of the Series B Preferred Stock<br /><br />
exercised its redemption rights. In July 1997, the holder<br /><br />
commenced a lawsuit against the Company and its then-directors<br /><br />
regarding the redemption of the shares. Effective December 31,<br /><br />
1997, the Company and the holder of the Series B Preferred Stock<br /><br />
entered into an interim settlement with respect to the action,<br /><br />
conditioned upon the closing of the final settlement on or before<br /><br />
February 27, 1998 which was later extended to March 6, 1998. The<br /><br />
closing of the final settlement took place on March 3, 1998, and<br /><br />
on that date the holder of the Series B Preferred Stock sold the<br /><br />
stock and accompanying warrants to Arbco Associates, L.P., Kayne<br /><br />
Anderson<br /><br />
Non-Traditional Investments, L.P.,<br /><br />
Offense<br /><br />
Group<br /><br />
Associates, L.P. and Opportunity Associates, L.P., each<br /><br />
a<br /><br />
California limited partnership whose general partner is KAIM NonTraditional, L.P.<br /><br />
The purchasers exchanged the<br /><br />
Series<br /><br />
B<br /><br />
Preferred Stock and accompanying warrants for an aggregate of<br /><br />
44,465 shares of Amended Series B Preferred Stock and warrants to<br /><br />
purchase 250,000 shares of Common Stock, subject to adjustment,<br /><br />
and received 2,620 shares of Amended Series B Preferred Stock in<br /><br />
payment of all accrued and unpaid dividends on the shares of<br /><br />
Series B Preferred Stock exchanged by them.<br /><br />
On June 30, 1998, the Company issued 1,320 shares of<br /><br />
Amended Series B Preferred Stock in respect of an in-kind<br /><br />
dividend payable on that date.<br /><br />

Undertakings<br /><br />
The undersigned registrant hereby undertakes:<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(1) To file, during any period in which offers or sales<br /><br />
are being made, a post-effective amendment to this registration<br /><br />
statement:<br /><br />
(i) To include any prospectus required<br /><br />
10(a)(3) of the Securities Act of 1933;<br /><br />
<br /><br />
by<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Section<br /><br />
<br /><br />
(ii) To reflect in the prospectus any facts or events<br /><br />
arising after the effective date of the registration statement<br /><br />
(or the most recent post-effective amendment thereof) which,<br /><br />
individually or in the aggregate, represent a fundamental change<br /><br />
in the information set forth in the registration statement.<br /><br />
Notwithstanding the foregoing, any increase or decrease in volume<br /><br />
of securities offered (if the total dollar value of securities<br /><br />
offered would not exceed that which was registered) and any<br /><br />
deviation from the low or high and of the estimated maximum<br /><br />
offering range may be reflected in the form of prospectus filed<br /><br />
with the Commission pursuant to Rule 424(b) if, in the aggregate,<br /><br />
the changes in volume and price represent no more than 20 percent<br /><br />
change in the maximum aggregate offering price set forth in the<br /><br />
"Calculation<br /><br />
of Registration Fee" table in the<br /><br />
effective<br /><br />
registration statement;<br /><br />
(iii) To include any material information with respect<br /><br />
to the plan of distribution not previously disclosed in the<br /><br />
registration statement or any material change to such information<br /><br />
in the registration statement.<br /><br />
(2) That, for the purpose of determining any liability<br /><br />
under the Securities Act of 1933, each such post-effective<br /><br />
amendment shall be deemed to be a new registration statement<br /><br />
relating to the securities offered therein, and the offering of<br /><br />
such securities at that time shall be deemed to be the initial<br /><br />
bona fide offering thereof.<br /><br />
(3) To remove from registration by means of a<br /><br />
effective amendment any of the securities being registered<br /><br />
remain unsold at the termination of the offering.<br /><br />
<br /><br />
postwhich<br /><br />
<br /><br />
Insofar as indemnification for liabilities arising under the<br /><br />
Securities Act may be permitted to directors, officers and<br /><br />
controlling persons of the undersigned registrant pursuant to the<br /><br />
provisions described under Item 14 above, or otherwise, the<br /><br />
undersigned registrant has been advised that, in the opinion of<br /><br />
the Securities and Exchange Commission, such indemnification is<br /><br />
against public policy as expressed in the Securities Act and is,<br /><br />
therefore, unenforceable.<br /><br />
In the event that a claim<br /><br />
for<br /><br />
indemnification against such liabilities (other than the payment<br /><br />
by the undersigned registrant of expenses incurred or paid by a<br /><br />
director, officer or controlling person of the undersigned<br /><br />
registrant in the successful defense of any action, suit or<br /><br />
proceeding) is asserted by such director, officer or controlling<br /><br />
person in connection with the securities being registered, the<br /><br />
undersigned registrant will, unless, in the opinion of its<br /><br />
counsel, the matter has been settled by controlling precedent,<br /><br />
submit to a court of appropriate jurisdiction the question<br /><br />
whether such indemnification by it is against public policy as<br /><br />
expressed in the Securities Act and will be governed by the final<br /><br />
adjudication of such issue.<br /><br />
